0.22: Þey come rennyng, boþe lesse and more, And wende haue herd sum holy lore. And when þey werë come echone, To hem he made of sorow hys mone: "hyt may no lenger be forholne; Falsly, wurschyp haue y stolne; y am nat, breþren, as &yogh;e wene, Of holy lyfe, as haþ be sene; Þat y fasted when &yogh;e lete; For twyys pryuyly y &yogh;ete; And whan &yogh;e wende y had be holy, Y ete and drank ful lustyly. To warnë &yogh;ow, þus y telle, For me ys come þe fende of helle. wyþ hys tayle my knes he haþ kny&yogh;t, And wyþ hys hede my mouþ y-dyt. stoppyd Alas þe tyme þat y was bore! As an ypocryte y am forlore. Ry&yogh;t now shal he me strangle and cheke, Ne shal y neuer aftyr speke." Be-fore hem alle he deyde astyte O . gloss 'anone.' Þat ychë proud ypocryte.

0.30: Of ladyys wulde y leue my sawe, But y dar nat for goddys awe; drede Of hem behoueþ to sey sumdeyl, yn what poyntës þey do nat wel. God haþ shewed, and sheweþ euery day, Þat swychë pryde ys noght to pay. A tale y shal þerforë telle, A tale How a lady was pyned yn helle.
0.31: [The Tale of the Proud Lady, who was burnt to ashes again and again in Hell by a Burning Wheel.] þer was a lady, a lordys wyfe, here fayrhede was yn renoun ryfe; Moche she loued feyre tyfyng, tyffynge. On here hede, ouer al þyng, For to be holde þe feyryst lady Of al þo þat woned here by; And whan she wened best best wende. to haue lyuyd, Þe deþ here toke; here dayys were fyllyd; For when men wene to lyfe haue space, Þan ys deþ sunnest yn place. Whan she was dede, sone aftyrward here squyer toke a syknes hard, Þat here lorde helde of grete prys, For he was a man yn seruyse wys.
0.32: As he lay yn hys bed a ny&yogh;t, hym þoght hys lady come to hym ry&yogh;t, And seyd þus, "rys, and go wyþ me, A merueyle shal y shewe to þe." Þys ychë man graunted here noght, For hyt ran weyl hym yn þoght Þat shé was dede and leyd yn graue, Þat hym of hys beddë wulde haue. But wheþer he wulde or noght, wyþ wel wele. & wo, She had hym vp with here to go. Þus tolde he seþyn with moche drede; A&yogh;ens hys wylle with here he &yogh;ede; She ledde hym to a mochë felde, So grete one neuer he behelde. Þan stodë styl, þys lady, And he by here ful dredfully. As þey hadd stondë but a þrowe, Come furþ foure. deuylys þat fast gun blowe; With hem þey broght a brennyng wheyl, Þat on here hede was set eche deyl. Þys whel þat was set on here heuede, heuede O, hede H. Brende here alle, þat noght was leued. Efte she ros, when she was brent, And had þe samë turment, And brende ry&yogh;t as she dede before; To se þat peyne hys herte was sore. &YOGH;yt she ros þe samë wey; For saule may neuer for peynë deye. And efte þey set sette. hyt on here krowne, And brende here al to asshen doune; And euermore she leuyd a&yogh;en, For peynë my&yogh;t she neuer be sleyn.
0.33: Þan askede he here, why þat hyt was Þat she suffred swyche peyne. "alas, alas," She seyd, "y suffre þys mys-auenture For on my heuede hede. ouer feyre tyfure; For when y shuld agher go or ryde, y dyghte my heuede hede. ry&yogh;t ful. moche with pryde For to be presyd ouer alle ladyys, And of prydë to bere þe prys, And among kny&yogh;tës yn halle y wulde be holde feyrest of alle. þer-for þys ychë peyne y drygh suffre For y bare me yn pryde so hygh. But warne my lordë, y pray þe, hys pryde and bobaunce þat he late be; But &yogh;yf he do, he shal be forlore, Þat y warne hym weyl before; For on one of þys dayys shul &yogh;e deye, My lorde and þou: þe soþe y seye." Ryght at þe termë, as þat. she seyde, Þe kny&yogh;t, and þat squyer, deyde.

0.39: [The Tale of the Knight and Monk who lovd new Fashions.] Þer was a kny&yogh;t þat loued nouelrye, As many one haunte now þat folye; he dede to make, do make hym. yn þe somers tyde, A kote perced queyntly with pryde; And God was nat þer-of payd, For yn hys pryde he was betrayd.
0.40: Þys kny&yogh;t &yogh;ede, vpp-on a day, Aboute roberye, to gete hys pray; Homward as he hys pray ledde with hys enmys he was bestedde; with fors þey gun with hym hym to. fyght, And slogh þere þys ychë kny&yogh;t. A clerk stodë þo þere be syde, And, prayd for þe kote of pryde. To werne hyt hym, þey þoght hem þught. loþe; Þey toke and &yogh;aue þys clerk þe cloþe. 0.43: And a clerk ys moche for to blame Þat bryngyþ brynth. hym self yn foule fame, Clerk ordeyned yn dignyte Þat haunteþ swyche Iolyte; Noþeles, of þe newë gyse Þe deuyl haþ made hymself chefe iustyse; And &yogh;yf he yn folye begynne to stoute, Þan bereþ he þe deuylys baner aboute; Mochë folk ys þerwyþ blent; God do þerof amendment.
0.44: &YOGH;yf þou hauë grete desyre To be clepyd lorde or syre, For to glosë þe, and slyppe, And to haue þe wurdys of wurschyp; Or &yogh;e wymmen also, comunly, wulde be kallede 'madame' or 'lady;' Al þys comþ of gretë pryde; yn þy shryfte þou noght hyt hyde. he ys ry&yogh;t lorde, þe kyng of heuene; wrong hyt ys þat men any oþer neuene.

0.60: [The Tale of the backbiting English Monk.] þer was a man of relygyun, A Tale þat yn þys he was a felun, Yn bakbytyng, as &yogh;e han herde, As many one are now yn þys werlde. He was wunt to seye wykked sawes Behynde þe bak of hys felaws; For he wulde be holde þe beste Of all hys breþer, and þe wylyeste. A syknes toke þys munke, and deyde, As God had of hym purueyde, And went yn-to peynë hard, As was shewed aftyrward. Befel þe tyme, as hyt ys ry&yogh;t, Munkës to rysë at mydny&yogh;t; And when matynes were al done, Þe couent &yogh;ede to beddë sone. A munkë lefte be-hynde a throwe, a trowe. Þat þe dede was wunt to knowe; whan þys munke come before þe chapytyl, As ordyr askyþ, he louted a lytyl; And as he louted, hys ye e&yogh;e. gan blenche, And say sagh. one sytte before þe benche, A foulë þyng, and a grysly, he sagh neuer none so loþly; he shette hys tunge tunge out. before þe grecys, And gnogh hyt Harl . hys. ynwarde al to pecys. hys tunge was brennynge O, brenned Harl . þat he so gnogh, yn-to hys mouþe a&yogh;en he hyt drogh; And eft, oute out. he dede hyt shete, And gnogh hyt eft with peynës grete. Many tymes þan dede he so; Þys munke stode and loked þarto, And had þerof so mochë drede Þat he wende hauë go to wede. mad As he stode so sore a glyfte, feryd Hys ry&yogh;t hand vp he lyfte And blessede hym-self stedfastly; And seþþen, he wax more hardy, And þoght, 'þys ys sum pryuyte Þat God almy&yogh;ty sheweþ to me.' hastyly O, hastly Harl . þer-to he &yogh;ede, And hadde þer-of no morë drede; And seyd, "best, y cóniure þe, Yn God þat ys persónës thre, Þat þou me telle why þou syttest here, Yn swych forme, and yn swych manere."

John Morley, Speech in Daily News , June 27, 1894:— "There is no better test of character in my judgment—whether individually or in public life—there is no better test of character than being able to work with other people. A friend of mine came back from the States the other day, and he said the worst feature in American life is the extraordinary distrust and suspicion which men there entertain of one another, and the readiness in which an inferior motive is found for conduct. I do not know whether that is a true account of America or not, but I am perfectly sure it is not true of my own country. (Hear, hear.) Englishmen are not suspicious, they are not jealous, they are not envious , and I think if they find themselves differing from this man or that upon this question or the other, that does not prevent them from being willing to listen to him upon other subjects upon which they have the happiness to agree. (Hear, hear.) Gentle|men, we hear a great deal of war between in|dividualists and collectivists. Well, I tell you frankly in practical affairs I for one am not very fond of these tickets and labels and solemn nick|names. They are very convenient for the purpose of vituperation, and no doubt a compact and handy nickname saves a lazy mind the trouble of thinking things out for itself; but I for one will never quarrel about a word, providing we are working for the same ends and marching towards the same goal. A great poet, who is the glory of the English race, name, and tongue, once used a sublime phrase. He speaks of the prophetic soul of the wide world dreaming on things to come. [Tennyson.] These beneficent dreams of a society elevated, purified, and renewed, must lead by many diverse ways and many hidden paths to their own realisation. I find no fault with them. They will enrich and vivify Liberalism. The great mission of realising, so far as realisation is practicable, those golden dreams, is the mission confided to our party, and I hope and believe that neither you nor I, in the various calls that may be made upon us, will be found unworthy of our trust." (Great cheering, amid which Mr. Morley resumed his seat.) lecherye ys flesshly synne; Enuye cumþ of þe soule wyþ-ynne; lechery ys þe lesse, we fynde, And enuye ys þe more vnkynde; For y se noun yn hys lyue Þat of enuye kan hym shryue; Þogh euery day a man hyt haunte, &YOGH;yt wyl no man be hyt a-graunte. 3.11: [The Tale of the English Squire who put off his Repentance till too late.] Þyr was a kyng, 'Conred' coured O. he hyght, Atale. 3.16: "when y hadde reddeþat y myght rede, Þey shette here boke, and furþ þey &yogh;ede. Sone aftyrward whan þey were gone, Come ouþer two, sone anone; Blak þey were, and foule stynkyng, wyþ glesyng y&yogh;en, and mouþe grennyng; Þey come and stodë on my bedde; Me þoght y wax nygh wode for dredde; Y turned me on euery syde, From hem myght y nat me me nat. hyde; And as y me went hem to fle Euer þey werë a&yogh;ens me. But whan y sagh no better bote, Y lay stylle boþe hand and fote; whan þey had traueyled me so with yl, A stoundë sate þey by me styl And drogh furþ a mochë boke,— Þe most þat y euer on gan loke: So grete hyt was and so orryble, þer-yn was more þan yn a byble;— For alle þat y haue do wyþ synne, Euery dele ys wryte þerynne, And euery wurde with sorow and pyne Þey made me redë, maugre myne; Þe lestë wurde þat euer y þoght, Þat vnto synne a-mountede oght, was yn þat boke ful þykly dreuyn, was none for&yogh;etyn ne for&yogh;euyn; And alle y redde, boþe lesse and more; Þat was þe pyne þat pyned me sore.

But whan men heryn of þys preche, Þat god of swyche wyl takë wreche; 'A!' lyghtly þey sey, as hyt may falle, 'God haue mercy on vs alle;' As who seye '&yogh;yf he wyl vs saue, Or &yogh;yf he wyl nat; late vs al. beleue.'
3.25: Nay, nay, hyt may nat be so, Þyr behoueþ more þarto; Þou gettyst nat heuene so lyghtly But þou do yn dede more why. Prey hym fyrst he &yogh;eue þe þat mede Þat þou mayst serue hym wel yn dede: &YOGH;yf þou praye þus and syþen wel do, So mayst þou come hys mercy to; And nat yn ydylnes, as &yogh;e þynke, wel to ete and wel to drynke, And ofte to swerë at youre wyl, whan no man chargeþ &yogh;ow þar tyl: So come to heuene, hyt may nat be, For, God hadde hyt neuer so fre.
3.26: [Against Tournaments.] Of tournamentys þat are forbede yn holy cherchë, as men rede, Of tournamentys y preue þerynne, Seuene poyntës of dedly synne: Fyrst, ys pryde, as þou wel wost, Auauntëment, bobaunce, and bost; Of ryche atyre ys here auaunce, Prykyng here hors with olypraunce. wete þou wel þer þyr. ys enuye whan one seeþ anoþer do maystrye, more maystrie. Oþer yn wurdys, oþer yn dedys; Enuye moste of alle hem ledys. Yre and wraþþe may þey nat late; Ofte are tournamentys made for hate. &YOGH;yf euery kny&yogh;t louede oþer weyl, Tournamentes shulde be neuer a deyl; And certys þey falle yn sloghnes, Þey loue hyt more þan God oþer or. messe; And, þerof ys hyt no doute, þey dyspende more gode þer þyr. aboute— þat ys &yogh;eue allë al. to folye— Þan to any dede of mercy.
3.27: And &yogh;yt may nat, on no wyse, Be forgete dame coueytyse, For she shal fonde, on allë al. wyse, To wynnë hors, and harnyse. And &yogh;yt shal he make sum robbery, Or bygyle hys hoste þer he shal lye.
3.28: Glotonye also ys hem among, Delycyus metes to make hem strong; And drynke þe wyne þat he were lyght, wyþ glotonye to make hym wyght.
3.29: &YOGH;yt ys þere dame lecherye; Of here cumþ allë here maystrye. Many tymes, for wymmen sake, knyghteys tournamentys make; And whan he wendyþ to þe tournament She sendyþ hym sum pryuy present, And byt hym do for hys lemman Yn vasshelage vasselage. alle þat he kan; So ys he bete þere, for here loue, Þat he ne may sytte hys hors aboue, Þat perauenture, yn alle hys lyue Shal he neuer aftyr þryue. loke now whedyr swyche tournours tourneours. Mow be kallëd turmentours? For, þey turmente alle with synne; Þere tourment ys, þer shul þey ynne, But þey leuë swyche myschaunce, And for here synnë do penaunce.
3.30: Also y tellë by iustyng, Þér-of cumþ myschefful þyng; Alle ys þe toon with þe touþer, As a shyppe þat ys turned with þe roþer.
3.31: And þese bourdys of þese squyers, Also haue þey made for swyche maners Of prydë, hatë, and enuye, Sloghtnesse, Sloghnes. coueytyse, and glotonye: lecherye makþ hem alle to bygynne; Þese wymmen are partyners of þere synne.
3.32: A clerk of order þat haþ þe name, &YOGH;yf he iuste, he ys to blame, Hyt were wurþy þat had þe gre, Brokyn þe armë, legge, or lege. or thee; hyt ys forsoþe, &yogh;yf he so werche, A&yogh;ens þe state of holy cherche.
3.33: hyt ys forbode hym, yn þe decre, Myrácles for to make or se; For, myrácles &yogh;yf þou bygynne, Hyt ys a gaderyng, O, gaderynt, H. a syght of synne,
3.34: He may yn þe cherche, þurgh þys resun, Pley þe resurreccyun,— Þat ys to seyë, how God ros, God and man yn my&yogh;t and los,— To make men be yn beleuë gode Þat he ros with flesshe and blode; And he may pleye, withoutyn plyght howe God was bore yn &yogh;olë nyght, To make men to beleue stedfastly Þat he lyght yn þe vyrgyne Mary.
3.35: &YOGH;if þou do hyt yn weyys or greuys, A syght of synne truly hyt semys. Seynt Ysodre, Isidre. y take to wyttnes, For he hyt seyþ, þat soþe hyt es; þus hyt seyþ, yn hys boke, Þey forsakë þat þey toke— God and herë crystendam— Þat make swyche pleyys to any man As myrácles and or. bourdys, Or tournamentys of grete prys. þese are þe pompes þat þou forsoke, Fryst Fyrst. whan þou þy crystendam toke. At þe fonte, seyþ þe lewed man, "y forsake þe, here, Satan, And alle þy pompes and all thy werkys:" Þys ys þy lore, aftyr þe clerkys. haldyst þou forward, e, certys nay, whan þou makyst swyche a-dray? A&yogh;ens God þou brekest cunnaunt, cumnaunt. And seruyst &yogh;oure syre, Termagaunt. Seynt Ysodre seyþ yn hys wrytyng, 'Alle þo þat delyte to se swyche þyng, Or hors or harneys lenyþ þar-tyl; O. gloss 'to.' &YOGH;yt haue þey gylt of here peryl.'
3.36: &YOGH;yf prest or clerk lene vestëment Harl . vestment. Þat halwed ys þurgh sacrament; More þan ouþer þey are to blame, Of sacrylege þey haue þe fame: Famë, for þey falle yn plyght, Þey shuld be chastysed chastyed. þerfor with ry&yogh;t.
3.37: Daunces, karols, somour games, Of many swych come many shames; whan þou stodyst stodyyst. to makë þyse, Þou art slogh yn Goddys seruyse; And þat synnen yn swych þurgh þe, For hem þou shalt a-couped be.
3.38: what seye &yogh;e by euery mynstral, Þat yn swyche þynges delyte hem alle? Here doyng ys ful perylous, Hyt loueth noþer God ne goddys house; Hem were leuer here of a daunce, Of host, and of olypraunce, Þan any gode of God of heuene, Or ouþer wysdom þat were to neuene. Yn foly ys allë þat þey gete, here cloth, here drynkë, and here mete. And, for swych þyng, telle y shal, what byfyl onys of a mynstral: Seynt Gregorye telleþ yn hys spell how hyt of a mynstral fell.
3.39: [The Tale of the Minstrel who was kild for disturbing a Bishop.] A mynstralle, a gulardous, Come onys to a bysshopes hous A tale And asked þere þe charyte; Þe porter lete hym haue entre;
3.40: At tyme of mete, þe bourde was leyd, And þe benesun shuld be seyd; Þys mynstral made hys melody with gretë noyse, and loude, and hy. Of þe bysshope, þe famë ran Þat he was an holy man; Þe bysshope sette hym at þe bourde, And shuld haue blessed hyt with wurde; So was he sturbled with þe mynstral, Þat he hadde no grace to sey with weyl. -alle His graces ryght deuoutëly For þe noyse of þe mynstralsy.
3.41: Þe bysshope pleyned hym ful sore, And seyd to allë þat were þore, Þat he ne shulde make hys nycete Before the graces of þe charyte. He sagh hyt weyl, þurgh þe spryt, spyryt. Þat þer shuld come veniaunce astyt. alstyt. "&YOGH;yueþ hym þe charyte, & latyþ hym go; Hys deþ ys nygh, þat shal hym slo." He toke charyte, and toke hys gate; O. gloss 'weye.' And as he passed out at þe &yogh;ate, A stonë fyl down of þe wal, And slogh þerë þe mynstral.
3.42: Þat betokened þat God was noght Payd of þat þe mynstral wroght, Þat he desturbled þe benesoun And þe gode mannys deuocyoun.
3.43: Þys tolde y for þe glemennes sake, To loke whan þey here gle shuld shul. make; And also for þo þat shuld hyt here, Þat þey loue hyt nat so dere, Ne haue þerynne so grete lykyng, Þe lesse to wurschyp heuene kyng.
3.44: [A Tale of Bishop St. Robert Grostest of Lincoln, and why he lovd Music.] Y shall &yogh;ow telle, as y haue herd, Of þe bysshope Seynt Roberd; Hys tonamë ys 'Grostest Of Lynkolne,' so seyþ þe gest. he loued moche to here þe harpe, For mannys wytte hyt makyþ sharpe; Next hys chaumbre, besyde hys stody, Hys harpers chaumbre was fast þerby. Many tymes, be ny&yogh;tys and dayys, He had solace of notes and layys. One asked hym onys, resun why he hadde delyte yn mynstralsy: he answerede hym on þys manere, why he helde þe harper harpe. so dere, "Þe vertu of þe harpe, þurgh skylle & ry&yogh;t, wyl destroye þe fendës my&yogh;t, And to þe croys by godë skylle Ys þe harpë lykened weyle.
3.45: Anoþer poynt cumfórteþ me, Þat God haþ sent vnto O, to H. a tre So mochë ioye to here with eere; Moche þan morë ioye ys þere with God hym-selfë, þere he wonys; Þe harpe þerof me oftë mones; Of þe ioye and of þe blys where God hym-self wonys woneþ. and ys. Þare-for, gode men, &yogh;e shul lere, whan &yogh;e any glemen here, To wurschep God at &yogh;oure powere, As Dauyd seyþ yn þe sautere, "yn harpe, yn thabour, and symphan gle, wurschepe God, yn troumpes, and sautre, yn cordys, an yn. organes, and bellys ryngyng, yn al þese, wurschepe &yogh;e heuene kyng." &YOGH;yf &yogh;e do þus, y sey hardly, &YOGH;e mow here &yogh;oure mynstralsy.
3.46: &YOGH;yf þou lyggë long yn synne, And wylt nat ryse, ne þerof blynne, Certeynly, for euery oure Þou shalt &yogh;elde a-counte ful soure; For euery oure þat þou þeryn lay Yn purgatorye þou gest þy pay. Hyt ys sloghnes, and kalled 'accyde,' Fro Goddys seruyse so long þe hyde.
3.47: And some, alle þe &yogh;ere wyllyn abyde Of shryftë tyl þe lentyn tyde; And nygh tyl lentyn be al gone Mede for fastyng gete þey none; Þat ys, for sloghnes þey wyl nat ryse; lyggyng yn synne, ys lore seruyse.
3.48: And, sum men, yn alle here lyue, Clenly ne wylë þey hem shryue; For þey synne alle yn hope of grace, At here endyng wene þey haue space; Þan þenkë þey to shryue hem clene: To swyche men, God sheweþ hys tene. Hyt ys seyd al day, for þys skyl, "he þat wyl nat whan he may, He shal nat, when he wyl, [haue pay.]" And þer byþ many one ful euyl to wynne To any godenes fro vylë synne; Euyl tokyn hyt ys Harl . omits 'ys.' of swyche a man, God hym deme; for y ne kan.
3.49: And þyr are ouþer þat mys dous, As a best, beste. for defaute þat goþ lous. But whan men techë hem þe wey, And þey wyl do as men hem sey; A tokyn hyt ys, þey shul haue grace To come to God, and hauë space. And he may hope of euyl endyng Þat nonë may to Godë brynge.
3.50: A slogh messagere, hys wylland, Þat charged ys wyþ lordes erand, &YOGH;yf he go nat as he ys sent, He ys wurþy to be shent. Man þat wel spedyþ hym yn dede, And messáger smart at nede, Þey shul stonde byfore þe kyng, And hauë mede to here askyng.
3.51: A persone ys slogh yn holy cherche Þat on hys shepë wyl nat werche How þey shul hem-self[ë] &yogh;eme, And God and holy cherche to queme. Þe hyghë shepard shal hym blame, how he lateþ hem go to shame.
3.52: &YOGH;yf he se yn any þyng Þat þey haue defaute of chastysyng, But he teche hem and chastyse so Þat þey forward better do, For hem he shal, at þe assyse, Be ponysshed before þe hygh Iustyse. Also behoueþ hym, for hem pray, Þat God, of grace, wysse hem þe wey.
3.53: &YOGH;yf any of hem defautë has, And he may helpe hem yn þat kas, And wyl nat, for vnkyndhede, But late hem perysshe þer for nede, Ful harde a-countë shal he &yogh;elde Þat he my&yogh;t helpe whan he ne welde. &YOGH;yf he kyndly vndyrstode, Of hem he haþ al hys gode; For, God seyþ yn þe gospel þys, Vpbreydyng hem when þey do mys: Þe mylke, þe wulle, þey wyl receyue; And syþþen þe shepe þey wyle late weyue. Holy wrytë swyche men holdes As wyldë wuluës brekyng foldes. Swyche a personë ys ful slogh, Be he hygh, or be he logh.
3.54: Man or womman þat haþ a chylde Þat wyþ vnþewys wexyþ wylde, Þat wyl boþe myssey and do, Chastysment behoueþ þarto; But &yogh;e hem chastyse at &yogh;oure my&yogh;t, &YOGH;e falle, ellys, for hem yn ply&yogh;t. Better were þe chylde vnbore Þan fayle chastysyng, and syþþen lore. Þus seyth þe wys kyng Salamonn To men and wymmen euerychonn, "wyle &yogh;e þat Harl . þet. &yogh;oure chyldryn chylder. be a-ferd, &YOGH;yueþ &yogh;euyf. hem þe smert ende of þe &yogh;erde;" And techeþ hem gode þewys echone; &YOGH;yt dur &yogh;ow brekë hem no bone.
3.55: [The Tale of the Father that would not chastise his Child.] y shal &yogh;ow telle a wundyr þyng A tale. Þat fylle for defaute of chastysyng: Seynt Gregory telleþ, þat mochë kan, Of a folë husbunde man Þat hatede a chylde þat he furþe broght wykkedly, for he chastyed hym noght. Þys chylde was wurþy for to blame, For ofte he cursed Goddys name; whan aght was do a&yogh;ens hys wylle, He cursede Goddys name wyþ ylle. Seynt Gregory tellyþ hyt wyþ grete eye; But as he seyþ, þan dar y seye.
3.56: Þys ychë chyld [sone] aftyrward Fyl yn[to] a syknes hard; Þe fadyr hadde þerof pyte, Þe chyld he daunted on hys kne, And haddë þarfor mochë kare Þat he sagh hys chylde so fare; For hyt began to braye and crye As, þogh hyt shuld al to-flye.
3.57: Þe fadyr asked, why hyt so ferde, Or what hyt sagh, or what hyt herde. Þe chyldë seyd "blake men, blake, Are aboutë, me to take; Me, wyþ hem, wyl þey lede, Y ne shal skapë for no nede." Yn þe fadrys faders. bosum hyt wulde hym hyde, But þe fende, þat ychë tyde, Refte þe saulë vnto helle. Þan began þe chylde to &yogh;elle, And cursed onys Goddys name, And deyde, and &yogh;ede wente. to helle with shame.
3.58: Þys yche chylde þat y haue of tolde, was but fyuë wyntyr olde. Þus þe chylde þat was so &yogh;unge was lore for faute of chastysynge. But þe fadyr, þat O . omits 'þat.' no gode couþe, My&yogh;te haue chastyëd hym hyt. with mouþe, Stoutly, for euery a lak, And betë hyt, whan hyt so spak.
3.59: Oueral y se þys custome wonys; Rychë men haue shrewed sonys,— Shrewys yn dedë and yn sawe,— why? For þey haue nonnë awe. Yn hys &yogh;ouþe shal he mysseye And skornë ouþer by þe weye; Þan seyþ þe fadyr "þys chyldys wurde Ne shal nat ley allë yn hurde." And &yogh;yf he lernë gylerye, Fals wurde and feynt trenlyng tremlynge. with ye, eye. Þat halte hys fadyr a queyntyse And of slygh wyt, to knowe þat wyse. &YOGH;yf he do skaþe gladly with fyght, Þan seyþ þe fadyr "he shal be wyght; He shal be hardy, and no man drede, He begynneþ be tyme be doghty dughty. yn dede." But ryght so shal hyt of hem falle As dyd of Ely sonys alle. y shal &yogh;ow telle, to preue my sawe, what fyl yn þe oldë lawe. dawe O. has 1 (dotted under) and d written over. A tale yn þe byble hyt tellyþ, þat toucheþ swych þynges, yn þe holy boke of kynges; And wrytë hyt ys ys þere. opunly, Of a patryark, syre Ely.
3.60: [The tale of 'Syre Ely' and his wicked Sons.] Þys Ely was a man ry&yogh;t ryche, And, to hys chyldrén ryght blyche; he hadde twey sonys, þat ys no les, 'Ofnee' the toon hyght, þe touþer 'Fynees.' Þese twey chyldryn dyd ful wykkedly To man and woman þat þey come by; Lyers, robbours, and lechours, Skorners, and also auoutours; wymmen þat to þe temple come, here offryng from hem þey nome. Þese wymmen come to syre Ely, And pleyned hem of grete vyleynye, 'Þat hys sonys were vnhende, hem also for to shende. O defaute was, þey by hem lay; A-noþer, þey bare here offryng away.' "Do þerof sum chástysyng, For þe loue of heuene kyng!"
3.61: Here fadyr Ely þan was wo, For þat yche fame shulde of hem go. Ely kalled hys sone, "Ofnee And Fyneës, come &yogh;e to me! Sonës," he seyde, 'he seyde' O, H. omits. "&yogh;e are me dere; y bydde &yogh;ow boþe, on feyre manere, Þat &yogh;e leue &yogh;oure foly dedes, And ouþer foly þat &yogh;ow ledys; Y herë of &yogh;ow foulë fame, Þe folkë seyn &yogh;e are to blame; Y rede &yogh;e leue alle swych foly, Þat y of &yogh;ow here no more cry."
3.62: Þese chyldryn were strong and stout; Of fadres byddyng þey hadde had þey. no dout, But werë shrewys for þe more, forþermore. Or werse þan þey hadde be byfore; And God was wroþe wyþ here mysdede Þat þey ne leftë for no drede; And, God was wyþ Ely wroþe, For he dyd hys sones no loþe, To chastyse hem wyþ fyn awe And with þe smartnes of þe lawe.
3.63: Þarfor toke god hys venïaunce Of hem, and mo, for þat myschaunce; He lete þe fals Phylystyens, Þe folk of Isrel to werre a&yogh;ens. Ely and hys, þey gunne assayle, And ouercome hem tweys yn batayle.
3.64: Þese Phylystyens þat hadde þe maystry, Beleuyd on Dagoun, a maumettry. On a god þat þey kalled Dagoun, Beleued þe Phylystynes echoun. Þarefor hyt was but Goddys suffraunce Þat shewyd why þey hadde swych chaunce.
3.65: Þe folk of Isrel had þoght, and syghte, For þey were twyys scumfyghte; Þey ordeyned hem on allë wyse how þey shulde best to batayle ryse, A&yogh;ens þe Phylystynes for to go, And hem dyscumfytë and slo. þey ordeyned hem for to bere Goddys arke with hem yn to were. O . gloss 'bateyle.' Ely sones were stoute and stark, And were chose to bere Goddys ark; For reuerence þey ded hyt, of Ely, And for þey were of body doghty.
3.66: Goddys ark was of swych manere As men make now shrynës here. yn þys ark werë þre þynges Þat men &yogh;aue to here offrynges; Þar-yn was Moyses table whar-on God wrote þe lawë stable; And Aarons &yogh;erd, and a potte of golde: Þese þre relykes þey helde ful holde. Yn þe pottë was a floure, whyte, and swete of al sauoure, Þat floure ys kalled 'aungelys mete' Þat God &yogh;afe þe folke to ete whan þey were yn wyldernes Forty wyntyr, yn hard stres. Þese þyngës þan bare Ely sones yn-to þe batayle þat &yogh;yt of mones.
3.67: Þe phylystyens come hem for O . omits 'for.' to assayle, And slogh Ely sonës sones boþe. yn batayle, And rauysshed Goddys ark þere, And slogh þe folk þat þer were, And þe relykys þat þere were were þer. ynne: Alle were lore for þe sonys synne.
3.68: whan þe folk to þe batayle fore, &yogh;ede Ely sette hym at þe temple dore yn a chayre, and was herkenyng Fro þe batayle sum tydyng, On what manere þe folk shulde spede, For of Goddys ark he had grete drede.
3.69: One come rennyng hastyly, And broghte þys tydyng to Ely Þat hys sonys were boþe slayn, And Goddys ark with myght and mayn strenkþ was bore away for euermore. Alas, þe sorow þat he hadde þerfore! whan Ely herd þys euyl tydyng, For sorowe he gan hys handys wryng, And fyl bakward of hys chayre, And brak on þer on. two hys swyer; nekke And of hys hede he brake þe bone, Þe harnës brayn O . omits the gloss. lay vpp-on þe stone.
3.70: Þys ychë tale ys no tryfyl, For hyt ys wryte yn þe bybyl; And to &yogh;ow y telle hyt here, &YOGH;oure sonys to chastyse and to lere, O . gloss 'teche.' Þat &yogh;e, ne þey, be nat shent For defaute of chastysment Bodyly, yn þys worlde here, And aftyr þat, þe soule so dere.
3.71: Þenkeþ on Ely and on O. omits 'on.' hys sonys; And to gode &yogh;oure chyldryn wones. For, ryght so as hem gan tyde, Swyche as þey were, þe same mow byde. Of sloghnes þys ys þe assyse whan þou wylt nat betyme chastyse.
3.72: &YOGH;yt ys þyr an ydulnes,— A grete vnwysdom for soþe hyt ys,— whan a &yogh;unge man dragh draghþ. lyte on lenkþe, And wyl nat trauayle yn hys &yogh;ungþe, &YOGH;enþe. Ne lernë hym craft for to wynne, Yn hys agë to leue wel ynne. Certes me þenkeþ hym ful slogh; Hys þryfte wyl melte away with snogh. And þogh a man haue oght oght of. erytage Þat he may lyue wyþ weyl yn age, Certes &yogh;yt behoueþ hym lere Manhede and curtesye yn fere. A man hys manhedë shal &yogh;erne desyre hymself and hys meynë to gouerne.
3.73: Þus seyþ þe kyng Salamon, And þese holy men echone; "Hyt ys an ydulnes yn here lyfe, Alle þat ouþer man or wyfe Trauayleþ for þe lyuës fode, And lytyl for þe soulës gode.
3.74: Þogh þou trauayle alle þat þou may, Ne be þou neuer so ryche ne gay, But þou serue God yn alle þy þoght Þat þy soule to heuene be broght, Sykyrlyche alle ys hyt but lore, Þy grete trauayle syn þou were bore; Alle for sloghthede be tolde hyt shal, To werche al day, and lese hyt alle.
3.75: &YOGH;yt us þyr an vnkynde sloghþhede, Þat a man vnneþ, for no gode dede, wyl wurschep God derwrþly, But more þarfor a&yogh;ens hym ly. And And þat. mayst þou þe soþë se Of rychë men, how stout þey be; For many one þat he &yogh;yfþ to rychesse, Of God and man þey &yogh;yue no þe. lesse. &YOGH;yf he &yogh;yue to any hys ryght lemes, lymes. To þanke hym þerof, no man &yogh;eue &YOGH;eme. nymes. loke alle þy lymës, fete and hondes, And, &yogh;yf þou weyl vndyrstondys Þat þou ne hast nedë of þo, Þank hym noþer yn wele no wo; And &yogh;yf þou mayst forberë noun, Þank þan hym hym þan. of euerychoun; y rede we þanke hym of euery poynt, Syn we may nat ne may. forbere þe lest Ioynt.
3.76: &yogh;yt þyr ys a sloghþehede yn þys synne; Vnkynde men are alle þer-ynne; yn sum man, vnkyndehede ys so rank Þat he ne may cunne no man þank For no gode dede þat þat O, þan H. men hym dous. A dogge ys kynder, þat goþ lous, For, &yogh;yue a dogge þryd part hys fode, And he shal euer weyte þe gode, And euermorë be wyþ þe, For lyfë ne deþ wyl he fle.
3.77: By þys skyl mayst þou se how An hounde ys kynder þan art þou; And &yogh;yt may hyt preuyd be Þat þou art as vnkynde as he. Of þe houndë, þys y fynde, Þat most he hateþ hys owne kynde; For that yche houndë þat hym gat, Most of allë hateþ he þat; And hys modyr he hateþ also; He byt here, &yogh;yf he may cum here to. &YOGH;yf &yogh;e vndyrstondë kan, Þus faryþ hyt of a an. vnkynd man; For he loueþ more an ouþer kynde, And þarto ys wel morë mynde, Þan he douþ þat ychë flesshe Of whos kynde he cum forþe ys. ysse.
3.78: A-noþer þyng &yogh;yt ys, O . omits 'ys.' &yogh;yf þou &yogh;eue kepe, Þat many loue more nete and and O, þan H. shepe Þan he douþ hys emcrystene, Or of hys harme wyl oght bemene. And þys ys a grete vnkyndnes, And also a&yogh;en manhede hyt ys; es. And sloghþëhede wel for to proue, Vnkyndly, and lowe, to loue.
3.79: &YOGH;yf þou art yn godë wyl To seruë God, and leue alle yl, Repente þe nat, for no feyntyse, Ne be nat heuy to hys seruyse; Þou shuldyst raþer to þe deþ turne Ar þou shust wyþ hys seruyse scorne.
3.80: &YOGH;yf þou bygynne weyl, y rede þou ende, For fyrst and last þou fyndyst hym hende. And &yogh;yf þou bygynne any þyng, Þenk what shal be þe endyng. For þogh þou seruë God to pay, Alle þy lyfe, lyue. boþe ny&yogh;t and day, And at þe laste ende of þy lyffe Þou fallyst a&yogh;ens hym yn stryffe, So þat þou yn þat ychë synne Makyst þan þy þanne þyn. endyng ynne, God forget alle þy gode dede; Of hym þerfor gest þou no mede. Ryght so ys he to þe redy whan þou wylt leue alle þy foly, And come to hym with répentaunce, yn blys he makeþ þy puruyaunce. At þe ende shal boþe dede and þoght Shewe hym self how hyt ys wroght.
3.81: Ne be nat þou þou nat. sorowful, y þe forbede; hyt semyþ, yn Goddys seruyse þan þou hast drede; And dredë wyl make a man slogh To do þe seruyse þat he hogh. oghe. But serue hym gladly with louely chere, Þan ys þy seruyse to hym dere: Þus techyþ vs Dauid þe prophete yn þe sautyr, wurdys swete; "Ne be nat proude þogh þou weyl dous, yn þyn herte to make a rous" boste Þat þou holy lyfë ledys, Yn fastyng, or yn almës dedys. Þe fyrst ys ouer mochë drede, Þe touþer ys O . omits 'ys.' proude hauncenhede. Holde þe euene hem betwene, Nat ouer-drede ne ouer-wene.
3.82: No make no sorowe, ne myslyke, Þat wanhope In þyn hertë styke; For þat ys þe werst poynt of alle; To hellë þyt hyt doþe þe falle. Sloghënes, hyt wyl þe grope To bryngë þe yn-to whanhope; Sloghnes yn allë godë dedys, Ys as moche, as sum men redys, As þogh þou shryue þe of a synne, And þenke no more to falle þer-ynne. &YOGH;yf þou be slogh, and heuy, And doust no gode dede of mercy, Þus seyþ God yn hys gospel, Þat "þou art to me a voyde vessel." Ful lyght þan art þou for to turne A&yogh;en to synne, and to soiurne; Þan art þou wersë þan þou was, Boundë vn-to Satanas; Þan wylle Satanas begynne to prykke, And whanhope yn þy hertë stykke. whanhope, God shelde vs þar-fro, hyt steryþ a man hym self to slo; So ded þe treytur Iudas, And forsoþe, wurþy he was. why was he moste wurþy? For he hadde wanhope of Goddys mercy; For he wendë þat God ne wulde Haue for&yogh;yue hym, þat he he O, god H. hym solde. Syþþen loked God Ihesu. vpp-on Iudas, As who sey, "aske mercy for þy trespas." For &yogh;yf he had asked hyt any syþe, Ihesu hadde graunted hym asswyþe; For hys mercy fayled noght To any man þat hym besoght. Syn God wulde haue ha. be to hym so fre, Þan ys he redy to þe and me: whychë tyme Whych tyme or when. þou wylt hym kalle, For hys defaute þou shalt nat falle.
3.83: Beþenke þe weyl of þe þefe Þat loued nat naght. God, no ne. was hym lefe,— he þat was hanged on a tre Bysydë Ihesu for vylte; he spake o wurde at hys endyng. "lordë, haue on me menyng!" mennynge. And asswyþe he wan þe prys, And was sent yn-to O . omits 'yn.' paradys. he was þe fyrst[ë] þat hyt wan Syn Adam lost hyt, oure formest man.
3.84: Er was þat þefe yn paradys Þan alle alle þe. prophetys þat were of prys. Þat þefe 8 alle manere wys dyd 8 8_8 þat dede al maner. synne, And neuer ere leuyd Ihesu ynne; For a wurde þat he spak so myldëly, he haþ pes, blys, and mercy. And, þarfor, dysmay þe noght For no þyng þat þou hast wroght; For, haue þou do neuer so mykyl, Ne be so fals, ne so fykyl, Ne ley þer-ynnë so long whyle, And do alle maner synnës vyle, &YOGH;yf þou wylt, yn strenkþe and hele, Þy synne forsake and nat noght. wyþ dele, with sorow of herte and répentaunce Þou mayst pay God with lytyl penaunce. God seyþ þys wurde, to shew vs þe wey, "y wyl þat nonë synful deye; To leue hys synne he shal haue space, And turne a&yogh;en to lyfe and grace; what so euer he haue haue he. done, y wyl nat hys dampnacyone."
3.85: To &yogh;yue a sample, a tale here lys, A tale Þat vs telleþ seynt Dyonys.
3.86: [The Tale of the Priest Carpus's Vision, and how merciful God is.] Seynt Dyonys of Fraunce seyþ þus:— hyt was a prest þat hyght Carpus; Þys prest, þurgh prechyng and sawe, Broght a sarysyn to crystyn lawe; A-noþer sarasyn of paynye Haddë þerwyþ grete enuye, And turnede þys man to hym a&yogh;eyn, And oure crystyndom was alle veyn. Þys prest þarëfor was sory, And hatyd þys man felunly, And preydë God he wuld hym sende Dampnacyun with-outyn ende, For he þe crystendom forsoke, And to a fals beleue hym toke; Fast he preyd yn hys atent, þat God on hym veniauncë sent. And God þe prestys prayere herde, And shewed hym þat he mysferde.
3.87: Þys prest lay yn hys bede a ny&yogh;t, And, gostly, he sagh a þys. syght; he sagh a swyþe merueylus brygge Ouer þe depë pytte putte. gan lygge, Þe plank þat on þe bryggë was, was as sledyr as any glas; But yn þe put þat was þer-vndyr, he sagh so moche sorowe and wundyr, Of fendës felë þat þere wore, Þogh y tolde moche, &yogh;yt were þer more.
3.88: But, shortly to tellë fro, Þe man Who had returned to Paganism, and who he had prayd should be damnd. he sagh on þe bryggë go Yn ful gretë perel and kare, And euer yn poynt to mysfare; Yn poynt he was to falle adowne, Of hys hede, heuede. formest þe crowne.
3.89: Þe fendys þat were yn þe pytte Smote vpwarde, &yogh;yf þey my&yogh;t hym hytte; And addres bete hym by þe fete. Þe prest sagh þat, and ful weyl lete; He preydë God þat he shuld falle Down yn-to þe fendys vnto þe deueles. alle, And þer, with-outyn endë be, 'For he turned away fro þe.'
3.90: whan þe prest had seyë þys, He loked vp to heuene blys; Hym þoght þe rofe was cloue yn two, And þe sky opened also, And of Ihesu he hadde a syght, How he was on þe rodë dyght; He sagh hys wundys alle blody, And spak to hym ful sorowfully, "Carpus," he seyd, "se wyþ þyn yne what y suffred for mannys pyne; Man to saue, y lete me slo, why wust þou dampnë hym to wo? why hast þou hym so moche with ylle? And for mankynde y lete me spylle with pyne, and hardë passyoun, My blode y &yogh;af for hys raunsun; why wust þou he hadde hellë fere Syn y haue boght hym so dere? &YOGH;yt were y redy man to beye, Er man with-outyn ende shulde deye. But y haue shewde hym so moche yn dede with my wundes þat þou seest blede, þat y þarfor ne wuldë noght Lese þat y so dere haue boght. A&yogh;ens me ne fyndeþ he no O. omits 'no.' skylle, But &yogh;yf hys ownë wylle hyt wylle. Þogh he be nowe a&yogh;ens me went, &YOGH;yt kepe y hys amendëment; Þarfor, with gode deuocyoun, Pray for mannys saluacyoun." Þan Carpus þanked God almyght Þat he hadde herde and seye þat syght.
3.91: Þarfore shul we be ful mynde To serue hym þat ys to vs so kynde, And shewe hym loue whyle we be here For þat he loveþ vs alle so dere, Þat he ne wulde leue eft, for drede, To deye for vs &yogh;yf we hadde nede. Ne be we slogh, nat slogh. but sone vpryse, Ne dredë vs þan on no wyse, But, hope alle to gode endyng, And serue þat mercyáble kyng, Þat hys mercy be to vs lent At þe day of Iugëmement; Amen! so motë hyt betyde To kepe vs fro sloghnes and accyde!

4.1: Now shul we speke of couetyse, How hy he [hy? for A.S. heo , fem., or the t of hyt omitted.] ys haunted on wykked wyse. Coueytyse ys þe fryst vyce; Þat streyte ys holde, y O. omits 'y.' halte auaryce. Coueytyse ys of vs echone, But auaryce wulde haue echone. Coueytyse, ys desyryng of þoght, But auaryce, wulde þat none had oght. Coueytyse, cumþ oþerwhyle of gode; But auaryce wyþdrawyþ mannys fode. Coueytyse, to gode men mowe hyt charge; But auaryce, ys noþer gode ne large. Coueytyse, ys of wylle, as ys a bayte, But auaryce, ys nygun haldyng strayte; Coueytyse, cumþ of kynde of blode; But auaryce, ys noþer kynde ne gode. As y kan telle, þys ys þe assyse, Betwyxe auaryce and coueytyse.
4.2: Here, y aske at þe bygynnyng, &YOGH;yf þou with wrong &yogh;erned oþer mennys þyng, Or falsly purchased: þat ys grete synne, So with wrong mennys gode þynge. to wynne. &YOGH;yf þou withholde, and &yogh;elde hyt noght, Auaryse to hellë haþ þe broght. Yn O . omits 'yn.' þy lyfe, lyue. y rede þou &yogh;elde hyt a&yogh;en, Þy saluacyun ys ellës alle veyn.
4.3: &YOGH;yf þou madest euer any delay, And ledyst one lyte fro day to day with þy wurdys pryuyly, Or perauenture al on hy, For to haue hys þyng with wrong, Euyl coueytyse þou mengest among. Þogh þou broghtest hyt neuer to dede, &YOGH;yt ys þy wylle moche for to drede.
4.4: Or &yogh;yf þou dedyst euer euer dedest. þy myght To false a chartre, þat ys grete plyght. Þat ys a dede of tresun &YOGH;yf hyt be of dysheresun, dyserytsun. Ouþer of lond, ouþer of rent, Oþer of ouþer gode þat God man haþ lent; But þou þe peynë ny&yogh;t and day To amende þat charge, &yogh;yf þat þou may, &YOGH;yf hyt ne be, þou art to blame; Ordeyned to þe ys mochë shame.
4.5: &YOGH;yf þou yn batayle, or in fy&yogh;t, Toke oght of man with-outë ry&yogh;t, And namely of relygyun, Þe harder ys þy synnë doun: And but þou sone amendë þe, Þarfor mayst þou acumbred be: Hyt ys wurþy hym for to dere Þat holy cherche wyl nat forbere.
4.6: &YOGH;yf þou of rychesse ryches. be wel beforne, And a &yogh;ere or two holdyst haldest. þy corne Þat þou my&yogh;t myghtest. selle hyt ry&yogh;t dere, And to helpe þe pore þou wylt nat here, Salamon seyþ, þat mochë kan, Þou shalt be weryed with many man; For þou &yogh;yuest myys &yogh;yfst mys. to &yogh;ete ete. Þat was ordeyned to for. mannys mete; For who so wyl hys myys wel fede, And spare hyt fro þe pore at nede, hyghly shal he go a-lone To þe deuyl, body and bone.
4.7: &YOGH;yf þou haue of ouþer tresour, More þan susteyneþ þyn onour,— Syluer, cloþes, or ouþer store, Or of ouþer þyngës more,— &YOGH;yf þe pore for defautë deye, And þou mayst hym helpe, y seye, Þou are a-couped of þys vyce Of coueytyse, and of auaryce; And before God, of þeft, a þefe, And for hys deþ, of slaghter grefe.
4.8: &YOGH;yf þou yn falshede so moche &yogh;ede, For coueytyse or for grete mede To consente to a fals Iuggyng, Or hyredyst a voket to for. swyche þyng, Or myghtyst haue sturbled hyt, & wust noght, But for coueytyse þe wrong were wroght, Moche shal God challengë þe, Þat day þat þou Iuged shal be.
4.9: As for Of. lordynges cunseylours, wykked legystrys or fals a-countours, Þey ne recche of no ry&yogh;t fey, Ne more þe lordynges lordes. þan do þey; Cunseyl to wykked lawes þey &yogh;eue, So þat þe pore men mow nat lyue: Þarfor, þey and here lordyngys Doun moche wrong yn many þyngys; Þarfor shul þey and here cunsayl Go to helle, boþe top and tayle. Many man ys broght ful bare For cunseylours þat coueytous are; And many a land yn grete errours Are ouer-turned þurgh cunseylours.
4.10: Among hem, stywardes mow be tolde, Þat lordyngës courtys holde, For nyrhand euery a styward, Þe dome þat þey &yogh;eue, ys ys &yogh;eue. ouer hard; And namely to þe porë man, Þey greuë hym alle þat þey kan. who-so-euer to mercy wyl hym drawe, he seyþ, he shal do hym but lawe; But who so shal þe lawe alle do, And no mercy do þar-to, he may neuer for mercy craue To God whan he wulde mercy haue; For &yogh;yf God shal deme with lawe ry&yogh;t, Shal no man come to heuene ly&yogh;t. But þurgh grace and hys mercy, Þan are we saued certeynly. Þarfor, &yogh;e stywardes on benche, Þer-on shulde &yogh;e allë þenche, '&YOGH;yf þou of þe porë haue pyte, Þan wylle God haue mercy on þe.' For hardë dome and coueytyse y shal &yogh;ow telle of swych a Iustyse.
4.11: [The Tale of the Hard Judge.] Y haue herde, be-&yogh;onde þe see A tale. was a Iustyse, yn a cuntre; Of hym the wurde ful wydë sprong, he &yogh;af harde dome, and oþer whyle wrong. Godë men ofte hym besoght For þe pore, þat he wo wroght, Þat he shulde haue on hem mercy, And pylle hem nat but mesurly; Þat þey my&yogh;t lyue yn pes by hym, And be nat so a&yogh;ens hem grym.
4.12: Þys was hys answere and hys sawe, 'Y shal do hem no þyng but lawe." And many lawes are oute of skylle, But, &yogh;yf þér þyr. be mercy tylle.
4.13: was hyt nat long aftyrward, He fyl yn a sykenes hard; Hyt telleþ of hym swych a chaunce, He hadde no godë répentaunce; Hys sykënes O, syknes H. wax harde and strong, Þat he my&yogh;t nat lyuë long; For allë alle men. hoped weyl y-nogh Þat he he O, om . H. vn-to þe deþ faste drogh.
4.14: Men þat sate a-boute hys bedde were a-gast, and sore a-dredde; And hopyd wel, and vndyrstode Þat here drede was for no gode.
4.15: Allë þey behelde hym faste, And sawe hys coloure ofte ouer caste; And wroth a-boutë, to and fro; Hys bedde hym þoght wulde cleue on two; And crydë with a loudë cry, "Lordë, haue on me mercy!" Þan spake a voycë yn þe sky, Þat alle hyt herde þat stode hym by, "Þou haddest neuer of man pyte, Ne y shal neuer haue noun of þe." Asswyþë he dëyd yn haste; Þere he shulde go, he &yogh;alde þe gaste.
4.16: &YOGH;e domës men þat þys chaunce here, Yn þys talë mowe &yogh;e lere what hyt ys to do euer wreche, And to mercy no þyng reche. Hauyþ yn &yogh;oure þoght, mercy, and se, Þe pore mow nat so weyl as &yogh;e; Beþ mercyáble for &yogh;oure prow Þat God ne take veniaunce on &yogh;ow.
4.17: &YOGH;yf þou haue be so coueytous To mercs mercye. men ouer outraious, And porë men, specyaly, Þat ferde þe wers for þat mercy, Sykyr mote þou be, syre styward, Þy mercyment shal be ful hard. Þy wreched soule þarfor shal dwelle; Þy mercyment shal be þe þyne of helle.
4.18: Þou baylë, owest nat to take (For drede of soule, and þyn oth sake,) Þat þy lordes prow be þe lasse, Ne noun of hys do harder stresse." So shulde eche aturne seriaunt; But many one holde no cunnaunt; cuuinaunt. For, sum some. take ful greuusly, Þat ful sore shal come hem by. Alle þat þey takë now to frest, Þérof shál God take a quest. Þe quest ys take and draght on hym; Accord þe wyþ þy lorde, betym.
4.19: [Of Simony.] To coueytyse longeþ symonye, Þe whych haunteþ almost al clergye. Symonye ys, as men telle, when &yogh;yftys of holy cherche men selle.
4.20: &YOGH;yf þou oþer &yogh;aue or sent Of holy cherche to haue vaunsement, Or any &yogh;af hyt for þe loue of þe, And þou art nat wurþy vaunsed to be, þan art þou come, þurgh þat queyntyse, To symonye and coueytyse. &YOGH;yf þou þan þan þou. þat auaunsement holde, Þou art a wulfe of Goddys folde; A wulf, y sey, take þou gode kepe, For þou shalt answere for þe þo. shepe. A clerk þat hys orders takeþ takþ H, O. For &yogh;yft or present þat he makeþ, makþ. He ys nat wurþy hem to haue, Hym were bettyr to be a knaue, And so were hem þat so hem selles For &yogh;yftys, and for no godenes elles. Þese holy men þat hauë ben, And holy wryt haue red and sen, Sey, þat swych &yogh;yftys are lore, And, now ys noun ware before. For swych men selle þe holy hely. gast To hem þat he loueþ last.
4.21: Coueytous men and lechours, Of holy cherche þey haue onours: Þys mow men se alle eury. day with ye; Cursed be syr symonye!

4.26: [The Tale of Pers the Usurer.] Seynt Ioun Iohan. þe aumenere A tale. Seyþ Pers was an okerere, And was swyþë coueytous, And a nygun and auarous, And gadred pens vnto store As okerers doun aywhore.

4.38: Fro þat tymë þan wax Pers A man of so feyrë maners, Þat no man my&yogh;t yn hym fynde, But to þe pore boþe meke and kynde; A mylder man ne my&yogh;t nat be, Ne to þe pore, more of almes fre; And reuful of herte also he was, Þat mayst þou here lere yn þys pas.
4.39: Pers mette, vp-on a day, A porë man, by þe way, As naked as he was bore, Þat yn þe see had allë hadde al. lore. He come to Pers, þere he stode, And asked hym sum of hys gode,— Sumwhat of hys cloþyng,— For þe loue of heuene kyng. Pers, was of reuful herte, He toke hys kyrtyl of, as smert, And ded hyt on þe man aboue, And bad hym were hyt for hys loue.
4.40: Þe man hyt toke, and was ful blyþe; He &yogh;ede and soldë hyt asswyþe. Pers stode and dyd dede. beholde How þe man þe kyrtyl solde, And was þarwith þarfore. ferly wroþe Þat he solde so sone hys cloþe; He my&yogh;t no lenger for sorow stande, But &yogh;edë home ful sore gretand, And seyd, 'hyt was an euyl sygne, And þat hym self was nat dygne For to be yn hys preyere, Þerfor nolde he þe kyrtyl were.'
4.41: Whan he haddë ful long grete wepte , And a party þerof began began þer-of. lete;— For, comunlych aftyr wepe, Fal men sone on slepe,— As Pers lay yn hys slepyng, Hym þoght a feyrë sweuenyng. Hym þoght he was yn heuene ly&yogh;t, And of God he had a syght, Syttyng yn hys kyrtyl clad Þat þe pore man of hym had, And spak to hym ful myldëly, "why wepest þou, and art sory? Lo, Pers," he sayde, "þys ys þy cloth. For he solde hyt, were &yogh;yt were. þou wroth; Know hyt weyl, &yogh;yf þat þou kan, For me þou &yogh;aue hyt þe pore man. Þat þou &yogh;aue hym yn charyte, Euery deyl þou &yogh;aue hyt me." Pers of slepë outë breyde, of hys slepe vpbreyde. And þoght grete wunder, & seþen seyd, "Blessyd be allë porë men, For God almy&yogh;ty loueþ hem; And weyl ys hem þat pore are here; Þey are with God, boþe lefe and dere; And y shal fonde, by ny&yogh;t and day, Tó be pore, &yogh;yf þat y may."
4.42: Hastly Hastely. he tokë hys kateyl, katel. And &yogh;aue &yogh;af. hyt to porë men echedeyl. Pers kalled to hym hys clerk Þat was hys notarye, and bade hym herk, "Y shal þe shewe a pryuyte, A þyng þat þou shalt do to me; y wyl þat þou no man hyt hyt no man. telle; My body y take þe here to selle To sum man, as yn bondage, To lyue in pouert and yn seruage; But þou do þus, y wyl be wroth, And þou and þyne shal be me loth. &YOGH;yf þou do hyt, y shal þe &yogh;yue Ten pownd of gold, wel with to lyue; Þo ten pownd y take þe here, And me to selle on bonde manere; Y ne recchë recche neuer. vn-to whom, But onlych he haue þe crystendom; Þe raunsun þat þou shalt for me take, Þarfore þou shalt sykernes make, For to &yogh;yue hyt bleþely and weyl To porë men, euëry deyl, And withholde þerof no þyng, Þe mountouns of a ferþyng."

4.50: Now ys Pers bycomë bryche, logh Þat er was boþë stoute and ryche. Alle þat euer any man hym do bade, Pers dyd hyt with hert[ë] glad. he wax so myldë and so meke, A mylder man þurt no man seke; For he meked hym self ouer skyle, Pottes and dysshes for to swele. swyle. To grete penaunce he gan hym take, And mochë for to fast and wake, And moche he loued þolmodnesse To ryche, to pore, to more, to lesse. Of allë men he wuld haue doute, And to here byddyng mekly loute; wulde þey bydde hym sytte or stande, Euer Euermore. he wuldë be bowande; And for he bare hym so meke and softe, Shrewës mysded hym ful ofte, And heldë hym folted or wode, For he was so mylde of mode. 4.70: [The Tale of Lucretius, and how the Devil leapt into him.] Þyr was a man þat hyght Lucrecyus, A tale A swyþë ryche and and a. coueytous; Besyde hym wonèd a mayden wys, Here Here O, He H. name was kalled Beatrys. Lucrecyus þoght on felonye; here landës he wulde algate bye. And, shortly &yogh;ow for to telle, Þys lady wuldë nat hem selle. when he wyst hyt, þan was hym wo; He weyted here, and ded here slo. whan he hád do here þat pyne, Yn alle here landes he toke sesyne, And was þan a ryche lordyng And bare hym stoutë stout. as a kyng. kynge.
4.71: Þys Lucrecyus made a feste, A ryche, with men of noble geste. Þe lordyngës þat he my&yogh;t gete were settë with hym at þe mete; And as he sat yn alle hys pryde, Com a pore womman þat tyde, And bare a chylde yn cloþës loke, Þe pappe yn þe mouþe as hyt had soke; Hyt hade neuer spoke before, saun&yogh; saunt&yogh;. fayle, Þarfor y telle hyt, þe more meruayle. As for grete myrácle, þe chyld seyd þus, "y sey to þe, Lucrecyus, Þat þou hast slayn seynt Beatrys, To haue here lond þat by here þe (here adv. ). lys. Þou art come now vn-to here fe, And syttest þere yn þy pouste; And y comaunde, þurgh Goddys my&yogh;t, Þe deuyl, yn-to þe to ly&yogh;t."

But y my&yogh;t nat so of myne, But y hadde borowed at þe of þyne; Þo þrytty pounde, God haþ me sente, And here þey are now, þy yn. presente; And asswyþe þey shul be payd, No lenger shul þey be delayd."
5.45: Seynt Ihōn called hys chaumberleyn, And tolde hem to Troyle, be by. summe certeyn. Anoun cumforted was Troyle so weyl Þat hys sykenes he forgate eche deyl, And so smartly, yn tyme so lyte, Þat þey allë my&yogh;t wele wyte Þat þe feuer þat hym so shoke was for þe monye mone. þat he toke.
5.46: He dyde on hys cloþys astyte, And to Seynt Ihon he wrote a skryte; Þys skryt scryte. conteyneþ, as hyt seyþ þore, Þese samë wurdës, lesse ne more: "God þe &yogh;elde, my lorde Syre Ihōn, Þe besauntes þat were delte echon, Þat y lente þe, þrytty pounde, Yn hande y haue hem hole and sounde." And Troyle dyde þe skryt scryte. weyl sele, And syþen ros vp yn gode hele; And went hym homë with seynt Ihon; Of euyl felte felt. he no more non.
5.47: But Ihesu, þat seëþ al þyng, Shewed to Troyle þys tokenyng How he hadde lore a rychë holde, And for auaryce he hyt solde.
5.48: Troyle tolde, he sagh þys syght At þe fyrst slepe of þe nyght: Hym was shewed a paleys, So fayre was neuer noun, hyt seys; For alle hyt was of betyn golde, Alle þat euer stode on molde. My&yogh;te no man aymë þe largenesse, largesse. Ne tungë tellë þe feyrnesse. Þer-yn was so noble atyre, Shynyng as golde, flammyng as fyre. Aboute aboue. þe &yogh;atë wrytyn was Þat Troyle beheldë a long space, spas. And ofte he reddë þat wrytyng, And haddë þeryn grete lykyng; Þys was þere wryte,—as seynt Ihōn telles, And as men of þys story spellys,— "Reste and hous with-outyn ende, Þe bysshope Troylë shal to wende."
5.49: Þus þoght Troylë yn hys bedde, As he ofte on þe lettyr lettre. redde. Þan wende Troylë sykyrly weyl, Þe kyng hadde &yogh;yue hyt hym hym hyt. eche deyl; Þarefore syre Troylë was ful gladde Þat he swyche a paleys hadde.
5.50: Vnneþë þenne hys y&yogh;e ye. was glent, Þat one fro God þydyr was sent, And commaunded alle yn rape haste A-wey þat wrytyng for to skrape. Alle þat spakë of syre Troyle was skraped shrapede. a-wey, as who sey oyle.
5.51: Sone aftyrward, with-yn a lytyl, was þere wryte anoþer a nouþer. tytyl; Þys tytyl þat was latter wryte, Þus moche hyt ys for to wyte, "Rest, and hous, and wonyng, Graunteþ, and &yogh;yueþ, &yogh;yfth. heuene kyng, To Ihōn þe patryark so fre, with-outyn ende yn ioye to be, For þrytty poundë þat he boghte, And to almës dede hem broghte."
5.52: And Troylë waked sone anone, And tolde hys dremë to seynt Ihōn, Johone. Euery deyl how he hadde sen, And was ordeyned to haue ha. ben. "Þarfore," he seyde, "fro henne forward Ne shal y neuer be to pore man hard; So feyre ys dy&yogh;te to hem to lyue, Þat blely wyl to pore men &yogh;yue." But algate Troyle þat tyme had tynte Þe fyrst paleys þat God hadde hym mynte.
5.53: &YOGH;e lordynges þat haue y-now, Þys talë haue y tolde for &yogh;ow, Þat &yogh;e ne repente &yogh;ow of largés Þat &yogh;e &yogh;yue to &yogh;oure almés; And þenkeþ on þe bysshope Troyle Þat for large almës made grete doyle, Þat &yogh;e ne lese nat þat paleys Þat God ordeyneþ to alle curteys; For who so &yogh;yueþ &yogh;yfth. curteysly, Hyt fordoþe þe synne of glotonye.
5.54: Of mete, glotonye wyl bygynne; Almës þerof fordoþe þat synne. Almës fordoþ alle wykkednes, And quenchyþ synne, and makyþ hyt les. Almës semeþ hyt cumþ of loue Þat þou &yogh;yuest &yogh;yfst. to man for God aboue, Oþer for hym þat þou &yogh;yuest þore, Or hym þat þou &yogh;yuest &yogh;yfst. hyt fore. Almës, þou wost weyl, ys a &yogh;yfte; And for þe &yogh;yuyng, man ys vplyfte.
5.55: &YOGH;yue gladly, for God, þyn almës here; Hym &yogh;yue þou hyt on alle manere, And for hys loue, to hys meyne, &YOGH;yf þou of hym wylt loued be. So wyl &yogh;yftys louë tylle, And gadyr many one to gode wylle.
5.56: For &yogh;yftys, twey loues mayst þou haue, And boþe be by. tymës mow þe saue. Þe fyrst ys, &yogh;yf þou &yogh;yue þy þynges To hauë louë of lordynges: For þy &yogh;yfte þou mayst be herde, And saue þy godë yn þe werlde; But þat love lasteþ lytyl whyle, And a&yogh;ens God hyt wyl þe fyle.
5.57: Þe toþer loue is noght for þys; Hyt askeþ noght but heuene blys; And þat loue ys, euery deyl, loue of God and pore man weyl. what ys loue vnto men pore? Almës to hem ys recouere; Almës dede of loue ys wey, Noþer mysdo, noþer hem no. myssey; Þan wyl God almyghty loue þe; Þy loue ys þan with charyte.
5.58: Charyte ys, þe certeyn to lere, loue of þyn euyncrysten dere. So sone þerto, noght wyl þe lede, Ne so moche, as wyl almës dede. Charyte ys, þe longyng of loue, As y haue tolde &yogh;ow here aboue; For alle þat euer þou mayst do,— But loue yn charyte be þerto— Alle þat euer hast þou wroght, Stant þe ellës al at noght.
5.59: Se now what seynt Poulë seys Yn a pystyl, þe samë weys,— "Þogh y speke as weyl with tung tounge As any man or aungel haþ song, sounge. And y lyue nat with charyte, No þyng auayleþ hyt to me. For y do þan ry&yogh;t as þe bras, And as þe tympan, þat bete was; Þe bras, to oþer, &yogh;yueþ &yogh;yfþe. grete sown, And bet hym self vp and down. And þogh y speke al yn prephecye, prophecye. And haue þe kunnyng of euery maystrye, And, with gode beleue myght seye Þe hylles to turne yn-to þe valey, &yogh;yf hyt ne be with charyte wroght, Ellës, he seyþ þat y am noght. Þogh y &yogh;yue alle my wurldës gode Vnto porë mennys fode, And &yogh;yue my body for to brenne Opunly oþer men to kenne, teche But &yogh;yf þar be charyte with alle, My mede þarfore shal be ful smalle."
5.60: loke now how many godenesse godenesses. þer are, with-outë charyte noght but bare. wylt þou know Wyltow knowe. þy self, and se &YOGH;yf þou wone yn charyte?
5.61: Charyte suffreþ boþe gode and yl, And charyte ys of reuful wyl, Charyte haþ noun enuye, And charyte wyl no felunnye; Charyte ys nat Irus, wraþful And charyte ys nat coueytous; Charyte wyl no bostful preysyng; he wyl noght but ry&yogh;twys þyng; Charyte loueþ no fantome, No þynges þat euyl may of come; He haþ no ioye of wykkednes, But loueþ alle þat sothfast es; Alle godenes he vp bereþ; Alle he suffreþ, and noun he dereþ; Gode hope he haþ yn ryghtwys þyng, And alle he susteyneþ to þe endyng; Charyte ne fayleþ noght, Ne no þyng þat with hym ys wroght. when alle prophecyes are alle gone, agone. And alle tunges are leyde echone, And alle craftys fordo shul be, Þan Þen. lasteþ stedfast charyte."
5.62: Þus seyþ seynt Poule, and mochë more, Yn hys pystyl of hys lore. Seynt charyte ys ys boþe. gode and hende, lastyng with God with-outyn ende.
5.63: Gode hyt were to loue hyt weyl, And folowe hyt with oure dede sumdeyl. &YOGH;yf we þys charyte wyl haue, &YOGH;yue we þe pore whan þey vs craue; &YOGH;yue we hem, as hyt ys oure my&yogh;t, with-oute myssaw or any fy&yogh;t; Þan ys hyt curteys almës dede; Þank of God þan ys oure mede, And shal stonde ful stalwurþly A&yogh;ens þe synne of glotonye, As y haue tolde &yogh;ow here byfore, And furþer shal y telle &yogh;ow '&yogh;ow' omitted. now more.
5.64: At þe begynnyng y spake of þys, Ete ne drynk but þat nede ys. who so doþ hyt oute of mesure, Hele of body may nat dure, And to hys soule, hyt ys dedly synne, Þat custummable ys þer-ynne; And penaunce harde þarfore shal go, But we kepe vs weyl þerfro.
5.65: Loke yn þys sawe what Catoun seys, Þat ys wyys and ry&yogh;t curteys, "&YOGH;yf þou yn hele wylt dure, Ete and drynk of swych mesure Þat þy strenkþe be nat þe lesse;
5.66: For, drynkyng oute of skylle, Þy body bryng hyt wylle To sorowe and to sykënesse."
5.67: And ouþer spyces haþ glotonye: To ete þy mete ouer brennynglye And lustly, whan þou hyt getyst, And takest noun hede what þou etyst.
5.68: Anoþer spyce ys noght to pay, As a beste to ete al day, And kepyst nonë no. certeyn tyme, Þe settyng at none or pryme, Noþer ouþer tyme þat fallyþ falþ. to man, But as a beste þat no resun kan. Me þenkeþ weyl hyt ys resun To callë swych a man 'glotoun.' Twyys on þe day ys sustynaunce To man þat haþ gode cheuysaunce. Þe cheuysauncë, woste þou how, To man þat haþ metë ynow, Þogh he be man of trauayle, Hyt were y-now with-outë fayle.
5.69: But þo men þat haue no swynk, Þat delyte hem yn mete or and . drynk, Þe apostyl apostole. Poulë spekþ of þo, And dampneþ many one to wo. He seyþ "woo to þo þat erly &yogh;erne, Þat go and hauntë þe tauerne, Yn wyne or ale to haue lykyng; Cursednes hem folowyþ at þe endyng. Of swych, here wombës are here Cryst; kryst. Þat ys here loue, þat ys here tryst." Alle þys he meneþ sykyrly For man þat loueþ loue. moche glotonye.
5.70: &YOGH;ungë chyldryn, þey mow wele, On þe day, etë þre mele; For sum of hem wex ful tyte, Þarefor ys more, here appetyte; And &yogh;yt behoueþ tyme be þar-to, Or men mowe wyþ hem mysdo; For, þus seyþ þe oldë man Yn a prouerbe forbysyn. þat he can, "&YOGH;yue þy chylde when he hyt. wyl kraue, And þy whelpe whyl hyt wyl haue, Þan mayst þou make yn a stounde A foulë chylde and a feyrë hounde." So mayst þou be enchesoun To make þy chylde a glotoun.
5.71: A-nouþer vyce ys &yogh;yt to graunte, Þat rychë men mochyl haunte, Þat many one are so daungerous, Compare the French lines 5811-16. And oute of mesure esquaymous, Þat hys kokë may no day Greyþë hym hys mete to pay. Þat me þenkeþ a feble manere; A vylanye hyt ys to here; For euery coke wulde, at hys my&yogh;t, hys lordës metë were wel dy&yogh;t: wheþer hyt be lorde or lady, Me þenkeþ hyt ys a spyce of glotonye. hyt semeþ, were hyt at þy wyl, Ouer mesure þou wuldest þe fyl.
5.72: Rerë sopers yn pryuyte, with glotonye, echone þey be; And þyr ys mochë wastë ynne, And gadryng of ouþer synne. Þefte behoueþ þe sumdele þore, And glotonye algatë more; And leccherye ys quene or kyng; For hym ys all þat gaderyng.
5.73: &YOGH;yt are þer ouþer rere sopers, with men þat seruë kny&yogh;tys and squyers; For al þe day þan wyl þey be Before here maysters yn soberte; But whan here maysters are broght to bedde, Þan wyl þey fonde þat þey be fedde, And sytte vp þare wyþ recolage rycolage. And &yogh;yt do mochë more outrage; To þe mydnyght ys but a þrowe, But hyt be, tyl þe cok krowe. Þese men are clumbë on a grece To glotonyë with þat spece.
5.74: Also fallë men yn plyght, Þat sytte vp Þat sytte vp on þe Þursday nyght. þe Þarsday at nyght. And ouerlong ete flesshe and drunke Aftyr þat mydnyght ys runge, Or fysshe or flesshe Or whyte or fysshe. þat suffreþ dede, Þat shulde on þe Fryday faste watyr & brede; Swych etyng þey shul sore abeye, But þey amende hem are þey deye. Þe Fryday nyght ys,—þys shalt þou leue,— Aftyr þe Þursday at eue; Þe nyght cumþ byfore þe day, Þat ys now of þe newë lay.
5.75: As y haue tolde of rere sopers, Þe same falleþ of erly dyners; Dyners are oute of skyl and resun On þe Sunday, or hye ar hygh. messe be doun. Þogh þou haue haste, here &yogh;yt a messe, Al holy, and no lesse, And nat symple, symply. a sakare, For hyt ys nat y-now ynogh. for þe, But hyt be for lordys powere, Or pylgrymage þat haþ no pere.
5.76: Are þou oght ete, þys ys my rede, Take holy watyr and holy brede; For yn auenture kas, hyt may þe saue, &YOGH;yf housel ne shryftë þou mayst haue.
5.77: Alle oþer tymes ys glotonye, But hyt be grete enchesun why. On oþer hygh dayys, days. &yogh;yf þat þou may,— Þogh þat hyt be nat Sunday,— Here þy messë ar þou dyne; &YOGH;yf þou do nat, ellys ys hyt pyne.

For to go to a dyner. So ne shuld he do, for no þyng, For loue ne awe of no lordyng, But &yogh;yf hyt were for a grete nede Þat shuld hym falle, or a grete drede.
5.80: Now haue we tolde yn lytyl space how þat glotonye cumþ yn place On many maner dyuers wyse, And how we shul knowe allë þyse.
5.81: &YOGH;yf any seþ hym so coupáble Þat yn þys ys custummáble, leuë hem, and do no more, And askë penauncë þarefore, And God ys curteys, and wul wele For&yogh;yue þe þy trespas euery dele. God graunte vs, for hys swete mercy, To kepe vs alle fro glotonye!

Þou lewed man, knowest also what ys to lete, what ys to do; Þou knowyst as weyl, euery poynt, As þe prest þat ys a-noynt, And wost what peryl ys þerynne; Þou mayst no&yogh;t sey, to fende þy synne.

6.14: [The Tale of St. Benet's Tempta|tion, and how he freed himself by rolling in Thorns and Nettles.] As seynt Benet sate yn hys celle, To tempte hym com a fend of helle Yn a lykenes of a bryd. A 'þrostyl' ys þe namë kyd; hyt come fleyng by seynt Benet, And, mery myry. synggyng, by hym hym set; Noþeles, he hadde grete ferly wundyr Þat hyt flegh hym so ny. Seynt Benet wende he my&yogh;t hyt ha take, For hyt sate by hym so spake. tame he blessed hym fyrst, and bedde hys hande To take þe brydde þat was syttande; As sone as he hadde made þe croyce, Þe bryde flegh furþ, and left hys voys. Þat þrostel sagh he no more; hyt become, he ne wyst whore.
6.15: Þan come on hym so sodenly So grete temptyng of lecchery, Þat neuer er, syn he was bore, So grete temptyng was hym byfore; Þe fendë þan put yn hys þoght Þat he hadde, or seye, or wroght.
6.16: Onës he sagh a feyre womman, And al day yn hys þoght she ran; Swych þoght so hadde hym þoght had hym so. ouercome, Þat þe þoght of God, hyt had ny nygh. fornome; And foule longyng had hym so take Þat hys ermytage he hadde nygh nygh he had. forsake; But Ihesu, þat seeþ al þyng, he sagh weyl hys grete temptyng; Þogh he suffred hym weyl be to-blaste, he suffred hym nat be dowün kaste; down kast. Þe fende may nat but tempte þy wyl, Þe Þy. selfe behoueþ þe dede fulfyl; And for he stode so stalwrþly, O, stalwrly H. Þe holy goste was to hym redy.
6.17: with-oute hys cellë, þornës wore, And netles grewe, þat byten sore; So haddë grace made hym stedfaste, Þat al hys cloþys of he kast, And alle alle he H, al O. naked hym-self he wrappe Among þe þornës þat were sharpe, And among þe netles echone, Tyl hys temptacyun was al gone.
6.18: Þe þornes prykked, þe netles dyd byte, Of flesshly temptacyun þey made hym quyte, So clene, þat neuer aftyrward was he tempted more so hard Of hys flessh, þat was hys fo, he dyde hyt þere so mochë wo. Seþþen, loued louede O, loue H. he Ihesu cryst wel weyl O, wel moche H. more Þan he dede, euer byfore, And hadde to hym more loue longyng Þan byfore hys hard temptyng.
6.19: Þys tale y tolde for þat enchesun, To stand a&yogh;ens temptacyun; For who-so wyl hys soulë saue, Many a fy&yogh;t behoueþ hym haue A&yogh;ens þe spyces of lecchery, Ar he wynne of hym þe maystry.
6.20: Seynt Poule techyþ vs for þat batayle A sykyr fyght þat wyl nat fayle; He seyþ, "y forbede &yogh;ow echoun, with womman for to go alone." For who-so douþ hyt, sone and ly&yogh;tly He consentyþ to lecchery; Þou alone, alone with hyre, þy þoght, by herte, cumþ sone on fyre; Be þou neuer so chaste ne straunge, Be &yogh;e alone, þyn herte wyl chaunge; And God commaundeþ boþe þe and me, me and þe. Oure herte to be. stable yn chastyte. He seyþ nat, to whom he whom þat he. wyl kalle, But spekeþ comunly to vs alle; And þogh he calle alle comunly, Sum are called more specyally; For specyaly þat comandeþ he To men þat are of hygh degre, As to bysshopes, and persones, To prestys, and ouþer relygyons; relygyones. To þese ys specyal comaundement; Þurgh þese to ouþer hyt shal be sent. Þarefore he byddeþ, with wurdës smarte, smerte. Þat þey be allë chaste of herte.
6.21: what ys hyt wurþ wrth. to be, with-outen, clene, whan fylþë ys withynne þe sene? For many one, whan þey to bedde are bro&yogh;t, Delyten hem yn fylþys of þoght. Swych þoghtës are synnës greue, &YOGH;yf þey þè pay, or be þè leue; And &yogh;yf hyt pay þè so, swych foule þo&yogh;t, Þat þe dede were do, &yogh;yf þou moght, Certes hyt ys nat noght. to drede Þat þy wyl ne shal answere for þe þy. dede. For &yogh;yf þou my&yogh;tyst, þou wuldest, do, Þy wyl consenteþ weyl þarto; Þou art a lechoure yn þat kas, Þyn hertëwyl ys grete trespas.
6.22: Anoþer spyce, more synne hyt ys, whan þou sekest þy wyl of flesshe, To þe lust of lecchery, Yn handlyng, or dremyng of foly, Þurgh þoghtes or syghtës þat þou sees, And yn alle ouþer pryuytes; God hym-self forbedeþ alle þys; Þey gete no parte of heuene blys: Yn shryfte forgetë noght of þyse; How ofte þou dedyst, and on what wyse.
6.23: &YOGH;yt þyr ys a-noþer spyce vyce. Þat cumþ of þe fendes malyce, Þat he douþ vs alle falle ynne, yn dreme slepyng þat we are ynne. And þat yche temptacyun May be twey maner of enchesun; Þe fyrste ys syghte, þe touþer ys þoght, with-outë þese, dremest þou noght; For swyche þyng þou mayst se with ye, Þat hyt turneþ to þoght of felonye. Altered to 'vilonye.'
6.24: &YOGH;yf þou þenkest ofte of þat syght, Þat wey of þoght gadreþ my&yogh;t, And knyttyþ harde ry&yogh;t as a seme, And sheweþ on þe ny&yogh;t yn dreme. Yn þat dreme, &yogh;yf þou do lecherye, hyt makeþ þe þoght of vylayné; vylaynye. &YOGH;yf any do hyt ones hyt ones O, hyt H. þurgh chaunce, Þan ys þerfore but ly&yogh;t penaunce; &YOGH;yf hyt be donë þurgh custome, Þan falleþ þarfore harder dome; For euery tyme, at alþer leste, Behoueþ þe shewe to þe preste: Hyt ys a wysdom to shewe hyt alle; Hyt may be moche, þat þe þenkeþ smalle. Þe prestë, prest. he can euene charge, For whyche he shal &yogh;yue penaunce large.
6.25: lecchery ys also grete &yogh;ernyng To be desyred þurgh feyre cloþyng, what wymmen hem tyfe tyffe. with ownë wyl, To foly loue, ouþer men to tylle. &YOGH;yf men, þurgh here feyre atyre, wyþ hem to do foly, haue desyre, Þey shul answere for here synne, For þey are rote, and fyrst bygynne; Noþeles, þe cónsentour Shal be holde for a lechour; Euene peynë shul þey bere, Þe toon þe touþer shal answere.
6.26: &YOGH;yt sey men yn þe oldë lawe, Þat, of a þefe and hys felawe, O dome shul þey boþë haue, Þe toon ne toþer ne þe touþer. shul men nat saue; And &yogh;yt men sey, as men gos, As foule ys he þat halt, as he þat fos. flos.
6.27: Anoþer spyce eke he forbedeþ, Þat many one ful lytyl dredeþ: To suffre a lechour or lechours To hauntë foly yn here hous. Þe prophete spekeþ ful euyl of þo; Þey shul haue part of peyne and wo; And þus seyþ þe prophete Osee, As moche defouled as hordam hordom. shal be.
6.28: A-noþer spyce, þat mochë dereþ, hauntë þey þat erandes bereþ To do a lechour for to spede, Or &yogh;yuen conseyl to do þe dede, Or susteyne one with maystry: Swych men are castel of lechery. Þus seyþ þe prophete seynt Danyel; And holy wryt wytnesseþ hyt wel. weel.
6.29: what sey &yogh;e of þese lordynges Þat a-vowe auowe. here men to do swych þyngys? Þat men dur nat hem nat hem O, nat H. chastyse with holy cherche, ne oþer wyse. Swych men areysen baner A&yogh;ens holy cherches power, And hem self are castel and toure For to manteynë þe lechoure. who so a-voweþ a 'a' omitted. man to do euyl, he ys no sybber þan þe deuyl; For þe fende wulde þat al shulde be Dampned, as weyl as ys he.
6.30: &YOGH;yt of &yogh;ouþe men shulde haue drede, Of þat men donë yn chyldhede; Þat may be turned to lechery, For chyldryn ofte to-gedyr ly.
6.31: &YOGH;yf þou oght dedyst and hopest, hyt ys Yn þy wyt, synne of foule flessh: Y cunseyl þe to telle þe þy. prest, For peryl may fallë, weyl þou seest; Þyn ynwyt telleþ þe þat skyl Of what þou dest þat ys peryl, For comunly, þat men done do. yn &yogh;enkþe, Yn agë haunte þey hyt on lenkþe; And mowe nat leue þat foule vyle (a late may is interlined above mowe ). vsage Þat þey toke yn &yogh;ouþe yn rage. yn a prouerbe of olde Englys Tellë men, and soþe hyt ys, "Þat &yogh;ougþë wones, yn agë mones;" Þat þou dedyst dest. ones, þou dedyst eftsones. Þarefore loke what þy &yogh;ouþë was, And yn þy þyn. age amende þy trespas.
6.32: A-noþer spyce, ware þe fro þys Foly, a womman for to kys; For seldë kys[eth] any frende, Þat lechery ne ys þoght or neuende. kyssyng ys, for loue to wynne, And ys erand for flesshly synne; Man or and . womman, loke for-þy, wharefore þou kyssest, whom, & why.
6.33: &YOGH;yt ys þer a spyce to mene For hem þat shuld be chaste and clene, As þo men þat are of hygh degree, Of holy cherches owne meyne; Þesë men shuld for no þyng Come yn wymmens handëlyng; Ne womman, Ne womman noþer. þat godë couþe, Shuld kyssë any prestys mouþe; For þere may nat but synne aryse; ryse. hys mouþ ys halewed to Goddys seruyse.
6.34: Ne prest oghte no woman touche, For, of foule touchyng, synne men souche. Seynt Ierom seyþ 'he shuld no&yogh;t haue any woman yn hys þoght;' For swych þoght, shal neuer weyl werche, with man þat ys of holy cherche. lestene now what Ierom seyde To hys suster þat hym preyde; She besoghte hym on alle maners Þat he wulde haue here yn hys preyers; Seynt Ierom spake a&yogh;en to hyre, Haluyndele as hyt were yn Ire, "Y prey God, þat mynde of þe, Yn my þoghtë, neuer be."
6.35: wenest þou nat he dred hym nede, whan he to hys suster syster. þus seyde? he dredde hym of sum wykked wrenche whan he ne durstë on here þenche. For soþe þan shulde þey mochë drede Þat are alday with hem yn dede.
