6.37: [The Tale of the Jew who heard some Devils' Reports of their Deeds to Satan; and how the Devil who got a Bishop to pat a Nun on the Back was most praisd. This Tale, says Gaston Paris ( Hist. Litt. de la France , xxviii. 201), is made up from two distinct stories. All that relates to the Jew, the temple of Apollo, the narrative of the devil who tempted the bishop (St. André de Fondi), the saying about the empty and markt vessel (p. 2444, l. 7854: væ! væ! vas vacuum et signatum! ) is borrowd from St. Gregory's Dialogs, III. vii.; but the feats of the different devils, the punishments of some, and the reward of the other, are from the Vitas Patrum, p. 580 (compare p. 576 and 556), which is the source of Wadington's Tale, tho' it substitutes a pagan for the Jew, and greatens the fault of the holy man who is tempted. Guillaume Peraut (Guill. Peraldi, Summa de vitiis: de luxuria, II. 19) tells the two stories, one after the other, with|out mixing them; but we see the mixture going on under our eyes in Libro de los Exemplos (no. 21), which, following without doubt a lost Latin original, tells us, as to Satan's questioning of the other devils: "St. Gregory tells briefly the manner of this questioning; but we can see it more in detail by an example in the Life of the Holy Fathers," etc. This Tale was often retold in the Middle Ages, and a summary of it, after St. Gregory, is certainly found in these verses, De triumphis Ecclesiæ of Johannes de Garlandia (ed. Wright, p. 37) as to the power of the sign of the Cross: Dæmonis in fanum Judæus tempore noctis Venit, et advenit dæmonis horror ei. Se cruce signavit; signatum vas bene dæmon Sed vacuum dixit: credidit ergo timens. Nec præsul tetigit monialem quam tetigisse Proposuit, sicut dixerat unus ibi. One must not then recognise here (as was suggested that one might, in 'Notices et Extraits des MSS.,' t. xxvii, 2 e part., p. 71) the legend of Cyprian and Justine (see p. 258-60 below), or see in Judæus a mistake of the copyists or editor for Julianus . ] Seynt Gregory telleþ, telþ. for gode mennys prew, A tale. Þat sum tyme was tyme þyr was. onës a Iew, And trauayled o tyme by þe cuntre, By iurnes þydyr þat he wulde be. Fyl so, he nyghtede yn a wasteyne, Þere he sagh no stede certeyne; he sagh no stede where wast was. best To lygge a nyght and take hys rest. But an an O, and H. olde temple he sagh stondyng, þat, sum tyme, folke mysbeleuyng Made here sacrifyse þer-ynne To here god, þat hyght Apolyne; Þys Iew restede þere þat ny&yogh;t, And toke hys esë as he my&yogh;t.
6.38: As þe Iew lay þere alone, To hym-self he made hys mone, Þat he beleued on swych a lawe Þat my&yogh;t nat saue hym on wyþ. no sawe. Of Ihesu Cryst, he hadde herd speke, How Iewes dyd hym on þe rodë steke. Þurgh grete þan ynspyracyun, He þoght so on hys passyun Þat oure feyþ yn hys hertë ran, Al be hyt he were no crysten man; So, what for trouþe, and what for doute, He made þe croys hym al a-boute, And seþþen leyd hym downe to slepe; Of ouþer, &yogh;af he no more kepe.
6.39: Sone at þe mydny&yogh;t he gan to wake Þurgh grete noyse and cry, & sore to quake; He lokèd vp, and sagh þere sytte Fendës fele þat fouly flytte; chydde he sagh one syttë yn a cheyre, chayere. Þat foule lokèd, and foule gan bere; He bad hem allë &yogh;elde a-counte, Here dedës what þey wulde amounte; what þey hadde do many &yogh;eres, He aresoned hem on hys maners; To oon he cast enchesoun, gret enchesoun. "Sey þou, felaw, what þou hast doun!" "At a weddyng," he seyde, "y was, And, þere y dyd grete trespas; Y slogh, þurgh my&yogh;t of honde, Boþe þe wyfe and þe husbonde; And y dyd &yogh;yt a-noþer chek, Alle þe ouþer y broght on cuntek, And euery, y made ouþres foo, fo. Þat euery man gan ouþer slo."
6.40: Þe mayster fend gan hym beholde, And sette at no&yogh;t þat he hadde tolde. "For þat, how long lange. hast þou be þore?" "A twelue monþe," he seyd, "and no more." "For þy dede þou getyst maugre, And þarto &yogh;yt shalt þou bete be."
6.41: with hym wulde he no more stryue; He called But calde. an-ouþer furthe belyue; Felunlyche, with y&yogh;en eyen. grym, "where hast þou be?" seyd he to hym. "Yn þe seë, haue y bene, And moche sorow made men betwene; Y haue broght to grete encumbre Shyppes and men with-outë noumbre, what yn cuntek, and yn tempest, Twenty þousand at þe lest." Þe deuyl seyd, "þat ys no doute; how long hast þou be þere-aboute?" "Seuene wyntyr, al to-gydyr, hauë y be haunted hauntynge. þedyr." Satan comaunded, for hys seruyse He shuld be put to hys Iuwyse.
6.42: Þe þred deuyl was forþë fette furþ fet. Byfore Satan, þer he was sette; set. Satan seyd, "where ware þou? How þou hast sped, sey me now." "A-boute a bysshope y haue be long, &YOGH;yf y my&yogh;t hym yn synnë fong; But yn hym ys so grete bounte Þat y my&yogh;t neuer turne hym to þe. But, þys ny&yogh;t y haue so sped, Þat hym with temptyng so fer haue led, Þat y hope, y haue hys þoght A party to my wyllë broght. Þyr com to hym, for hys godenesse, A nunne, y wene a pryores, Sum þyng of hym for to here Þat she perauenture my&yogh;t of lere; Algate, y broght hyt so to an ende, Þat, what tyme þat she shul wende, He smote here a lytyl on þe bak Yn pleyyng, whan he he O, she H. to here spak. God wyst what was yn hys þo&yogh;t And yn hys herte, for y wyst hyt 'hyt' omitted. no&yogh;t."
6.43: Satan asked 'how long whyle he hadde be aboute, hym to gyle.' "Fourty wyntyr, and alle yn drede, &YOGH;yt my&yogh;t y neuer so neuer er so. moche spede, Ne No. neuer er bryng hym to plyght But þat y ded þys samë ny&yogh;t."
6.44: Ful weyl payd was Satanas Þat he hadde broght hym to þat cas: He ros a&yogh;ens hym, and made hym blysse, And profred hym hys mouþe to kysse, And seyd, 'he was weyl wurþy For to come and sytte hym by.'
6.45: Before hem alle, þat ychë tyde, he sette hym by hym, syde be by. syde, And seyd, "ende þat þou hast bygunne; For þat þou hast do, my loue þou hast wunne."
6.46: Þys ychë Iew þat þerë lay, In þe temple with grete affray, Y trowe for soþe he slept slepe. ful lytyl, whan he herde þat grete chapytyl; &YOGH;yf he hadde slept, hym neded awake, &YOGH;yf he were wakyng, he shulde a ha. quake, For Satan asked þere he sat, "who lyþ þere, and what ys þat? who durst so hardy be [6- syll. line ] To lye þere with-oute leue of me? Goþe swyþe, one or two to-gedyr, And, what he be, bryngeþ hym hedyr."
6.47: Þe deuylys come un-to hys bedde, And styrte a&yogh;en, þey were so dredde; Þe bedde, ne no. hym, ne durst þey touche, So had he marked hym with þe crouche. O . has above a ✗.
6.48: Þey turned a&yogh;en to syre Satan, And seyd, þey durst nat brynge þat man. He asked 'why þat chaunce byfel;' Þey seyd, hyt was "a lore ler. vessel, An empty vessel þat marked was From þe and þyne, syre Satanas; Þe vessel, whan hyt þere was leyde, Vn-to vs hyt longed nede. al nede. Alas þe whyle þey gunne to reme! He haþ hys mark þat wyl hym &yogh;eme."
6.49: Þe Iew þey called 'a voyde vessel,' And forsoþë, so hyt fel; Voydë he was of hys lawe, For he forsoke hyt for fyne awe; 'Lore,' Ler. for he hadde nat oure lawe take Seþþe he hadde Harl . hadde nat. hys owne forsake. For þys þyng, y hope þey seyd, And called þe Iew a vessel voyd. But þey my&yogh;t nat 'nat' omitted. do hym no dere, Noþer to Satanas lede ne bere; So hadde he hym with þe croyce blessed, Þat of hym algate þey myssed. Þe fendës and syre Satanas Þan wente awey, cryying 'alas!'
6.50: Þe Iewë þo asswyþe a-ros,— hyt was no wundyr þo&yogh; þogh. hym gros,— dred Vn-to þe bysshope sone he &yogh;ede And tolde hym what he sagh yn dede; Þe crystendome at hym he toke, And, hys fals[ë] lawe forsoke, And beleued oure lawe echedeyl, And þe bysshope amended hym weyl.
6.51: Þys talë to &yogh;ow haue y tolde, how þe fendë halt hym bolde whan he haþ tyced an holy man with any temptacyun þat he kan, hym þenkeþ he haþ do a grete chaffare; And namely þo þat ordred are, whedyr hyt be yn a womman handlyng, Or yn any oþer lusty þyng; Þarefore lordynges þat kun wel se, Amendeþ &yogh;ow, pur charyte, And makeþ nat a-mys þe toye, Þat þe fende of &yogh;ou haue Ioye.
6.52: Prest wel y 'y' omitted. -lettred ys to blame, Þat letteþ nat, for drede ne shame, To pley with wommen, and to rage; For, aftyr pleyyng, cumþ outrage. Ofte men se, and haue herd seye, Þat swyche men go an euyl weye.
6.53: &YOGH;yue þou a-mong hem mayst na nat. lyue, But some algatë on þe clyue, Take þou ensample at seynt Ierom; Do as he dyd, and go fro hom.
6.54: Seynt Ierom wente yn-to deserte, For drede of synne and foly grete. Men asked hym why he þedyr &yogh;ede, Syn he was an holy man yn dede; "y wentë þedyr, synne to fle, Y dredde hyt wlde ha maystred me; Synne of womman wyl with me fy&yogh;t, And y fele me yn moche vnmy&yogh;t. For &yogh;yf y a-bydë þat batayle, Y drede þat y shal falle or fayle; And &yogh;yf y fle þat ychë bekyr, Y hopë þan y may be sekyr:" Þarfore me þenkeþ, foles are þo Þat fy&yogh;t, and mow[ë] be þar-fro, Þat fy&yogh;t[ë] so þe deþ to haue whan þey mow fle, hem self to saue.
6.55: Þarefore, &yogh;e prestes þat dwel at hom, Þenkeþ on þe drede of seynt Ierom, And wommans wommens. felawshepe for to fle For doute of synne, for so ded he.
6.56: But of wymmen hyt ys grete wundyr, hyt fareþ with hem as fyre and tundyr; Comunly forsake þey none Þat euer ys made of flessh and bone. &YOGH;yf she wulde to foly here take, Þe prest algate she my&yogh;t forsake; For þer ys none, þat she ne may Haue a sengle man to here pay. And &yogh;yf she wulde algate mysdo, A knaue my&yogh;t best beseme here to, Þan hyt were to take a prest, For synne and sclaunder were þere lest. But how as euer men preche or spelle, Of prestës wyues men here euer telle.
6.57: Of ouþer wyues y wyl naght say, Þey do nat wrong, but al day; But y dare sey, as y haue herde, On Englys toung tonge. to alle þe werlde.
6.58: &YOGH;yf þyr be oþer mayden or wyfe Þat dysturbleþ þe holy lyfe Of þe prest, þurgh lecchery, A&yogh;ens here shal kalle and crye Alle þat are yn paradys, And alle þat yn purgatory lys; And allë þat are yn þys lyue A&yogh;ens here shul aryse and stryue; For euery prest, aftyr þe sacré, He parteþ þere Goddys body yn þre, þer þe vble yn þre. And offreþ hem to þe fadyr yn heuene On þys wyse, as y shal neuene; The fyrst he offreþ hem to blys, To hem þat yn heuene ys; O. gloss 'ben.' Þe toþer he offreþ for vs alle here, Þat we to hym be boþe lefe and dere; Þe þryde he offreþ to haue memóry For soules þat are yn purgatóry, Þat God bryng hem oute of of here. peyne And brynge to hem to. þe ioye þat ys certeyne.
6.59: Certys, she douþ ful moche a-mys, Þe womman þat dysturbleþ alle þys. For, þo soulës are no þyng wurscheped with þat offryng, Noþer vs to cunseyl, or to rede, Ne hyt helpeþ nat þe dede; Allë þarefore þat now are, And þat shul be, and now are fare, go Shul dampne þat womman to be lore, And curse þe tyme þat she was bore; And þarwith-alle, ne shal she be quyt, &YOGH;yt shal hyre here. dampne hyre owne ynwyt Þat ychë day þat alle shal shal O, þat H. ryse Before Ihesu, þat hygh Iustyse.
6.60: lokeþ, &yogh;e wymmen, what &yogh;e do &YOGH;yf &yogh;e dyd oght, doþe no more so, Or harder penaunce, with bytter teres, Shul &yogh;e do here, or ellës wheres. And shame hyt ys euer ys euer O, ys H. aywhare To be kalled 'a prestës mare.'
6.61: Of swych one, y shal &yogh;ow telle Þat þe fendë bare to helle; A tale Þys chauncë fyl, þat ys so hard, Yn þe tyme of gode Edward,— Edward, syre Henryës sone,— And þe tale ys weyl to mone.
6.62: [The Tale of the Priest's Concu|bine, and how Fiends carried off her Dead Body.] Þyr was a prest ry&yogh;t amerous,— And amerous men are lechours;— Þys prest, þe moste part of hys lyfe, Helde a womman as hys wyfe, Þat no tymë he hare here. lete, Só þoght hym þe synnë swete. Yn synne, and yn foly desyre, Foure chyldryn he gate on hyre. Þese chyldryn, as þey wox woxe. more, He sette hem vn-to scole to lore; So þey lernede, þat þe þre were ordeyned, prestes to be; Þe fourþë sone was a scoler, To lernë more he dyde hys power. when þey were prestys, here fadyr deyde,— Þe prest þat y er of er of O, er H. seyde,— Þys ychë womman lefte a-lyue Aftyr hym foure &yogh;ere or fyue. Þese foure chyldryn had grete þoght How þey were yn synne furþe broght, And how here modyr leued ynne, Alle here lyfe, yn dedly synne; Þey preyde here, for allë chaunce, To be of godë répentaunce, And forþynkë here mysdede with sorow of hert, and wyþ drede.
6.63: But þus answered she to hem alle, "For no þyng þat may befalle, Shal y neuer repentë me whyle y haue &yogh;ow prestës þre Þat for me mow mowen rede and synge, And, ful weyl, me to blys brynge; So may my soule to God be broght For any synne þat I haue wroght; But wylle &yogh;e allë fourë do A þyng þat y prey &yogh;ow to? kepyþ my body, at &yogh;oure my&yogh;t, Þre dayys, and þre ny&yogh;t, Yn þys hous whan y am dede, And y hope be saued fro þe quede, Þogh y haue lyued a synful lyfe, And haue be called a prestës wyfe."
6.64: Þat graunted þey euery deyl, For þey wende ha haue. do hyt wele. Sone aftyrward she euyld, And deyd sunner þan she wylde.
6.65: here chyldryn, as þey hadde here þey here hade. het, To wake here body were þey set: Þe fyrst nyght þat þey shulde here wake, At mydny&yogh;t þe berë gan to quake; Here fourë sonys þat saye hyt stere, leyd on hond, hande. and helde þe bere; Þe ouþer men hadde swychë drede Þat euery man hys wëy &yogh;ede; with mochë drede and hydous syght Askaped þey on þe fyrst ny&yogh;t.
6.66: Þe toþer ny&yogh;t þat þe chyldryn woke, At þe mydny&yogh;t þe berë quoke, And alle þat sate or þerby stode, For dredë wendë ha wox haue woxe. wode: Þat ny&yogh;t shewed he more hys ire, Þat hys power was moche yn hyre. with sorowful sy&yogh;t and grete affray He drogh þe body þere hyt lay, And to þe dore þe fende hyt broght; Þat tymë fyrþer my&yogh;t he noght. Here fourë sones, with mochë peyne, Efte hadde þe body yn a&yogh;eyne; Aboute þe body a rope þey wonde, And to þe berë fast þey hyt. bonde; So algate þe body with hem lefte; At þat ny&yogh;t was hyt nat refte.
6.67: Þe þred ny&yogh;t, moste sorow gan falle; At þe mydny&yogh;t, as þey woke alle, Come fendës fele, with loþely brous, And fylden allë ful þe hous, Þey toke þe body and þe bere wyþ lothly cry, þat alle my&yogh;t here; And bare hyt furþe þat none wyst whore, with-outen ende for euermore. here sones hyt seyd, and hoped wel, Þat body and soule was lore eche deyl.
6.68: Þe &yogh;ongest sone þat was a scolere, He preched þys yn stedys here; sere. Þurgh Ingland, yn euery cuntre, he tolde þys tale of grete pyte, Oueral as he went a-boute, (He spared noþer for shame ne doute) A&yogh;ens wymmen þat prestës take, For hys ownë modyr sake; For to dampne and stroye þat synne, Þat no womman falle þer-ynne.
6.69: &YOGH;e wommen, þenkeþ on þys tale, And takeþ hyt for no troteuale! Goddes veniaunce was hyt, and hys Ire, To amende vs alle for loue of hyre.
6.70: Yn a prouerbe, telle men þys, "He wyys ys, þat ware ys," [6- syll. line ] And wysdom es, ys. and feyre maystrye, To chastyse vs wyþ ouþres folye.
6.71: Of prestës kan y sey no þyng,— So seyd y at þe bygynnyng,— Noþer of clerkys neuer a deyl, Þéy wote wete. what ys ylle and weyl; But þus haue y herde for certeyn, Yn þe worlde ys none so gode skryueyne— Þogh he were wyser þan Salamon And bettyr langaged þat þan. was Mercyon And leued yn age a þousend &yogh;ere— Ne my&yogh;t telle þe sorow and were, dysesc Ne þe peyne, þat þe preste shal drye, suffre Þat haunteþ þat þe. synne of lecchery. Þey are wroth whan any þus precheþ, But holy wryt þus vs telleþ vs þus telþ. and techeþ.
6.72: Now turne we a&yogh;en þere we spak Of handlyng synnë, þat yche lak; Y tolde of handlyng synne as y kouþe, And now wyþ of. foly kyssyng with mouþe.
6.73: kyssyng doþe moche more euyl whan handlyng cumþ of þe deuyl; Some wene þat kyssyng ys no synne, But grete peryl falleþ þer-ynne. Be þou neuer so chaste and straunge, kyssyng wyl þyn hertë chaunge; Hyt ys forbode, be þou weyl ware, But &yogh;yf hyt be here, þat furþe þe þe furþ. bare; Þy wyfë þou mayst kysse with ry&yogh;t, &YOGH;yt yn sum poynt mayst þou falle yn ply&yogh;t. Seynt Ierom, he spekeþ spekþ O . of þys, Ouer moche for to daunte and kysse; Daunte a womman oute of skylle, when no tyme were, she wyl þer-tyl.
6.74: Maner þer ys of foule kyssyng, As ys of dede and of handlyng, Þat falleþ falþ. ofte yn pryuyte, But þat shal nat be tolde for me; Noþeles, hyt mote be tolde Yn shryftë, boþe with &yogh;unge and olde.
6.75: Sum maner kyssyng ys ful grete vyce, And wommens hertys to s&ymacr;nne wyl tyse; And who so delyteþ hym þer-ynne, wommen to foly for so. to wynne, Y do hym weyl to vndyrstande, So may he go yn deuyl hande.
6.76: &YOGH;yt mayst þou synne yn lecherye Yn þe lokyng of þyn y&yogh;e; eye. Beholde nat wymmen ouer mochyl; mykyl. Here sy&yogh;te makeþ mennys þoghtes fykyl; And who-so haþ a feble herte, hys ye eye. ys euer ouerthuerte. Þyn ye eye. ys þyn þy. messager To brynge þy dedë yn powere; Yn swychë sy&yogh;t ys mochë gylte; Shryue þe þerof &yogh;yf þou wylt.
6.77: &YOGH;yt ys þer þyr. more of lecherye Þat ys do with sorsorye, Sorsorye þat ys wycchëcrafte; He þat ys with þe fendë lafte Grete synne hyt ys, hyt ys O, om . H. y &yogh;eue þe a &yogh;yfte; Þenk þer-on yn þy shryfte. To man þat ys yn gode beleue, wycchecrafte shal hym neuer greue; Be þou yn gode lyfe, and byleue ry&yogh;t, And alle þe wecches wycches. wyþ alle here my&yogh;t Shul neuer drecche þe þe O, om . H. where-so þou art with no queyntysë of here artt: Þat sheweþ weyl seynt Cypryene, he was a nygromancyene, how he my&yogh;t neuer a mayden wynne with wycchëcrafte here þoghte to synne: why? For here lyfe was gode and clene, And stedfaste byleue yn here was sene.
6.78: [The Tale of St. Justyne, and how the Sign of the Cross protected her from Devils.] Yn Antyoche, þat noble cyte, A tale. wonede þys mayden of grete bounte; here name men callë seynt Iustyne, For Ihesu Cryst she suffred pyne. whan she had takë crystendam Euery day to scole she nam, &yogh;ede To þe scolë, for to lere Þe loue of God, and haue hyt dere.
6.79: And as she went to þe scole hous, A lorde þat hyghte 'Agladyus'— A gretë mayster and a syre— was a-namourd so on hyre Þat he ne wyst what do he my&yogh;t, She was so semëly by sy&yogh;t. He comë vn-to Cypryene, Þys clerk, þys nygromancyene, And tolde hym al þe enchesun Of hys grete temptacyun.
6.80: Fast he preyde, and hette hym mede &YOGH;yf þat he coudë do sum dede, were hyt 1 godë, were hyt ylle, 1 1_1 wyþ gode, were hyt wyþ yl. Þat he my&yogh;t haue of here hys wylle. "Iustyne," he seyd þan, "hattë hat. she Þe feyre mayden þat marreþ me." And Cypryene hette hym for of hys Þat þe mayden shulde be hys.
6.81: Cypryene made þan hys queyntyse, And ded þe fendys many one manye. vpryse, And comaunded comaundede hem. þat Iustyne were lede Vn-to syre Agladyous bed. Þe forme of here fadyr and modyr þey nam, toke And yn here lykenes to Iustyne cam, And badde, here wyl shuldë be went To Agladyous comaundement.
6.82: Iustyne hadde grete wundyr of þys, And wyþ þe croys she gan here blys, Þan þey And þey O, þan þe H. vanysshed aweye asswyþe; She þanked God and was ful blyþe. Þryys þrys. þey come, on þre manere, Beforë Iustyne to apere; And here cunseyl was euer þus "we rede &yogh;ow take Agladyus." At euery tyme þat þus 'þus' omitted. þey here besoght, Þe croys was euer yn here þoght, And made hyt euer hem betwene, And alle here cunseyl was no more sene; hadde none of hem lenger powere with here to speke, or come here nere. Þryys þrys. ouercomë hadde þey bene, And þus þey tolde to Cypryene.
6.83: Cypryene haddë grete ferly, wundyr And asked 'for whom hyt was, and why Þat þey ne my&yogh;të of here spede, But euer ouercome awey þey &yogh;ede.' Þan spak to hym a fende of helle, "Syker me here with me to dwelle, And þat þou ne shalt, for loue ne eye, Beleue on þat y shal þe seye."
6.84: whan he hadde seyde hym hys certeynte, "Now," seyd þe fende, "y shal telle þe: She beleueþ on one men calle Ihesus, He þat confoundeþ euermore vs; She ouercomeþ vs with a croys; when we se hyt, we haue no voys; Þe sygne þerof euer we fle, And drede we haue when we hyt se; Oure my&yogh;t ys noght, no neuer shal, Ouer any þat blesseþ hym with-al. Iustyne þerwyþ defendeþ here so Þat we ne may haue with here to do; And, for here lyfe ys gode and clene, Oure maystry may ry&yogh;t no&yogh;t be sene; For &yogh;yf she lyued yn wykkednes, Þan my&yogh;te we do to here sum stres."
6.85: Cypryen seyd vnto þat fende, "Ihesus ys nat þan &yogh;oure frende, Hyt may weyl be hym-self haþ my&yogh;t Syn &yogh;e drede hys croys be syght; And ys nat &yogh;yt þe samë tre, Haþ þat tokene more my&yogh;t þan &yogh;e?" "&YOGH;ee," seyde the fendë, "certaynly, Ouer vs alle he hyt. haþ maystry; And euermore so shal be doun For hyt was hys owne passyoun; No þyng þat man may of hym sey, Doþe oure powere so moche a-weye As nemne þat passyun and þat rode Þat he shedde on, hys swetë blode; Heuene and helle þat passyun douten, And creatures allë þarto louten, And specyaly 'Ihesus,' þat name Ys our shenshyp and oure shame."
6.86: when Cypryen þys vndyrstode, He forsoke hem, and bycom gode, And alle þe crafte þat he hadde haunted, And Crystendome to take he graunted; He dyd breke his maumetrye, And dyd hyt brenne byfore hys ye; Seþþen at þe bysshope of þe cyte He dyd hym crysten man to be, Seþþen he was so stedfast Yn þe beleue, þurgh þe holy gast, Þat he was ordeyned dekene hye, And seþþen bysshope he was wurþy; Seþen made he Iustyne, abbas Of alle þe ladyes, as wurþy was.
6.87: Swyche grace fel seþþen seþen fyl. on hom, Þat boþe þey suffred martyrdom; And now now O, om . H. ys Cypryen with God so herd Þat he ys wurschypde yn alle þe werlde; O . inserts— For yn þe pryuyte of þe messe, Hys namë euer nemnede ys:— And she ys callede Seynt Iustyne, A martyr and an holy vyrgyne.
6.88: Þys tale y tolde to &yogh;ow aboute, Þat &yogh;e ne dur no wycchecrafte doute, &YOGH;yf þou be—þat ys to mene— Yn beleuë gode, and lyfë clene. who-so þurgh wycchëcrafte haþ tene, Prey to God and seynt Cypryene And to þe mayden Seynt Iustyne, Þat þey delyuer hem hym. fro þat pyne.
6.89: Þarefore, þou man and þou wyfe, &YOGH;yf þou be of clenë lyfe, Þar þe noght drede no wycchëcrafte Noþer temptyng of þe deuylys shafte; And &yogh;yf þou be yn dedly synne, To hys temptyng he may þe wynne.
6.90: &YOGH;yt þer ys spekyng of vylaynye Þat longeþ vnto vnto O, to H. lecherye, And oftë tyme of foulë speche Falleþ Falþ. þarfor hard[ë] wreche; Of foulë herte cumþ foulë þo&yogh;t; Of foulë þo&yogh;t, foule wurdys are bro&yogh;t. Þe foulë wurde, þe speker dereþ, And þat hyt hereþ and furþ bereþ; Y hauë toldë of þys lak Yn þe fyfþe comaundement, þer y spak, whan y of a nunnë tolde, Þat coudë nat here tungë holde.
6.91: &YOGH;yt ys þyr a spyce of leccherye, Auauntëment of olde folye: A kaynard and an an O, a H. oldë folte, Þat þryfte haþ loste, lore. and boghte a bolte, he shal become[n] a dyssour, And telleþ telle. how he was a lecchour; Ioye he haþ, hym-self to dyffame Of alle hys synnes þat he kan name, And auante hym alle an hye, And make men lagh at hys foly; And þat ys nat þe synnë leste, Auaunte þy synne to hym hem. þat þou sest.
6.92: Sodom sank, and Gomore, For þey kryed here synne aywhore; Þese twey cytees, boþe þey 'þey' omitted. sank, For þey hadde ioye at synne þat stank. Feyrer hyt were, oure synne forhele, Þan make auauntement þer-of to fele; Þe apostle seyþ þys autoryte, "&YOGH;yf þou be art. nat chaste, be þou pryue;" Telle hyt þy prest, and to no mo; For oþer tellyng, ys ys O, hyt ys H. boþe synne and wo.
6.93: &YOGH;yt ys þyr a specyal spece Þat doþ leccherye klymbe by a grece: who so wyllë &yogh;yftës &yogh;yue, On lecheryë he may cleue; clyue. For synne, no &yogh;yftys þou receyue; For doute of gyle þou shalt hem weyue forsake ; For whan a lechour haþ &yogh;yue hys mede, Þan hopeþ he weyl þat he shal spede. Y rede, &yogh;e wommen, &yogh;yueþ gode entent, For medë &yogh;e wyl sone consent; Many one for mede doþ ful euyl, Men sey ofte 'mede ys þe deuyl.'
6.94: &YOGH;yt spekeþ he of a more tresun Þat for lechery ys doun; &YOGH;yf men or womman be so wylde To fordo a getyng of a chylde wyþ wurde or dede, syn hyt ys gete, with mete or drynk þat þey do &yogh;ete, þey ete. Or oþer strenkþë, þat hyt dye, Þan þey doun ful grete folye; with slaghter hast þou þere hyd, Þat þy lecherye ys nat kyd; Gretly yn euyl þou art coupáble Yn twey synnës, and dampnáble.
6.95: A-noþer vyleynye þyr ys, To do a womman synne þurgh stres: &YOGH;yf a womman mete paráuenture Yn pryuë stedë, a lechour, &YOGH;yf he wyl do with here synne, And she ne may a-weyë wynne But she swerë oþys grym A-noþer tyme to come to hym, Or he makeþ here trouth-plyght Anoþer tymë when she my&yogh;t, For þat trouþë, y answere Þat no perel shal she bere; She nat ne. synneþ nat dedly, Hyt ys nó wyl, but maystry; Better ys to skape with an oþe, Þan synne dedly, and God be wrothe. Here-of my&yogh;t men mochë speke, Of trouþë þat men alle day breke, For, fals trouþës, and fykyl, For lechery, are &yogh;yue mechyl.
6.96: &YOGH;yf þou a womman trouþë plyght Out of holy cherchës sy&yogh;t; Men oght nat so for to do Þogh þat frendes consente þarto; For holy cherche oght fyrst for to wyte wete. Of here gederyng, &yogh;yf hyt may sytte
6.97: Of allë folës are þey fyles, Þat gentyl wymmen begylys with a trouþë of tresun To reuë here, here warysun, But she do by here ordynaunce Of hem þat shuldë here auaunce.
6.98: And a womman loueþ ofte yn pryuyte Þat for here falleþ falþ. nat weyl to be; &YOGH;yf she to þat &yogh;eueþ &yogh;yfþ. here treuþe, Þat ys ys to. here ful mochë reuþe; Þat trewþe dar she nat be a-knowe, For drede þat she haþ loued so lowe. Þurgh cunseyl of here frendys wylle, She ys þan &yogh;yue a-noþer vntyl; Y dar sey hyt hardyly, hardyly O, hardly H. 'Þat womman leueþ yn lechery; And þat ychë man also To whom she &yogh;af fyrst trouþë to, &YOGH;yf he any ouþer wedde, Or with any go to bedde, &YOGH;yf þey boþe wulde haue ha. do þat Þat here mouþes to-gedyr spak, And haue ha. fulfylled, at here my&yogh;t, Here pryue trouþë þat þey ply&yogh;t.'
6.99: A wers[ë] spycë &yogh;yt men holdes, To begyle a womman with wordys; To &yogh;yue here trouþë but lyghtly For no þyng but for lygge here by; with þat gyle þou makest here asent, And bryngest &yogh;ow boþe to cumbrement.
6.100: Þarfore now y warne &yogh;ow alle, Man and woman, for þyng may falle, Þat &yogh;e be neuer so fole-hardy To &yogh;yue &yogh;oure trouþe trouþe O, om . H. so pryuyly, Ne wommans trouþë for to take, Ne trouþë &yogh;yue for weddyng sake, Tyl holy cherche haue demyd ry&yogh;t wyþ lokyng of frendes syght.
6.101: Pryuytes manye falle þer her. -ynne; Þyn ynwyt þe telleþ whych ys synne; Sum pryuytes of lechery Yn opun speche are vyleynye; Þarfor wyl y nat hem alle descryue, But alle behoueþ vs þer-of shryue; Þyn ynwyt wote what þou hast wroght, And whych ys synne, and whych ys no&yogh;t; Alle þese spyces þat y haue tolde, On dyuers maners are synnës folde.
6.102: &YOGH;yf þy flesshë ofte aryse Yn wyl or dede to many of þyse, Þat þou mayst nat þy flesshë daunte, Þat sum algate behoueþ þe haunte, Be nat þarfor yn wanhope; Alle may be quenchyde with a drope, &YOGH;yf þou mayst for þy synnë grete, O. gloss 'wepe.' And be yn wyl hyt for to lete. For many a gode man, olde and &yogh;onge, haþ be yn flesshëly temptyng; So was seynt Poule, þe holy man, Hys flesshe was temptyde with Satan; Seynt Benet was so, &yogh;e herde me telle, p. 238. He was yn poynt to leue hys celle; And ouþer men mo of relygyun Haue be yn hard temptacyun; But man behoueþ pryue preue. hys my&yogh;t, A&yogh;ens hys ownë flesshe to fy&yogh;t; For &yogh;yf þou late hyt haue hys þe. wyl, wyltou, neltou, nyltou. hyt wyl þe spylle.
6.103: And y shal telle here, &yogh;yf &yogh;e wyl, A talë for þe þys. samë skylle, skyl. Þat a man myshopë noght Þogh he haue grete temptyng of þoght.
6.104: [The Tale of the tempted Hermit, or How we should never Despair.] Seynt Gregory telleþ, for oure profyte, A tale. How þyr was onys an ermyte: Þys ermyte had grete temptyng yn hys þoght, ouer alle þyng; And as þys temptyng on hym ran, He &yogh;ede vnto an oldë man And tolde hym allë, vp an downe, Of hys grete temptacyun. Þat olde man seyd to hym astyte O. gloss 'anoun.' 'He was nat wurþy to be an Ermyte, Þat swychë þoghtës shuldë þynke, And þoght of womman wulde hym synke.'
6.105: Þys oldë man gan hym so stoute, Þat hys gode hope was alle yn doute; For þe wurdes þat þe olde man gan seye, Yn-to þe wurlde he toke þe weye. As he cam com. goyng yn þe strete, An holy abbot gan he mete; Þe abbotys name was Apollo, And sone he spake þe ermyte to; Þe ermyte hadde so sory þoght, A&yogh;en to þe abbote spake he noght.
6.106: Þys abbot was a ful wys man, And yn hys þo&yogh;t ful sone hyt ran, And be þe semlant of þe ermyte, Þat he was yn grete sorowe and syte; Þe abbot asked hym ones or twyys; At þe At þe H, At O. laste þe ermyte seyd hys auys. "Y am," he seyd, "bro&yogh;t allë down with flesshly temptacyun; And at an oldë man y was, And tolde hym alle my myn. hardë kas; And he seyd, y was nat wurþy, Þe ermytagë to com ny, nyghe. Ne was yn wey me to saue, whyl y shulde swych þo&yogh;tës haue; And, for he he O., H. om . comforted me so yl, Yn-to þe worlde now ys my wyl, And lyue þere þe. best wyse þat y may, Syn y serue nat God to pay."
6.107: Þan seyde þe abbot syre Apollo, "Þe olde man wyst nat what was to do; Þou mayst se now, by my vysage, Þat y am olde, and weyl yn age, And y fele a ful hard prykyl Þat my flesshe tempteþ me mykyl, Vnneþë ys hyt day ne oure Þat y ne am þar-with tempted soure; But þogh my þoght be oute of skyl, To do &yogh;yt wers[ë], y ne wyl; Ne more No more. shalt þou þy self mysdo, Þogh þou be tempted neuer so. Y rede, þat 'þat' omitted. yn godenes þat þou dwelle, And turne a&yogh;en vnto þy celle, And fonde a&yogh;ens þy flesshe to fy&yogh;t, And late hyt nat haue alle þe my&yogh;t." He bro&yogh;te þys ermyte to swyche certeyne, Þat to hys celle he turned a&yogh;eyne.
6.108: Þe abbot knew [wel] alle þe pas where þe olde man wonyng was; Þedyrwarde þe wey he nam. And when he a lytyl besydë cam, He sette hym dowun, and preyd Ihesu Ful of my&yogh;t and [of] vertu, Þat þe olde man my&yogh;t fele sum þyng Of þe ermytes flesshely temptyng, To chastyse hym for hys broþer, Þat he myscumfort eft noun oþer.
6.109: when he hadde leye yn orysun long with grete deuocyun, He ros vp, and byhelde, And sagh a blak man stonde yn þe felde, And to þe olde man arwes arewes. ded shete Ry&yogh;t many, and sum wel ful. grete. So many arwes arewes. to hym he drogh, Þat þe olde man felt temptyng ynogh; Þe arwes were temptacyons, And sharpë sterynges, and felons; So many and smart, he hem hadde, Þat he sate as he hadde be madde, Þat wytte hadde lorë, as he sat, Or was yn a were wer. to do sum-what. Ar he aght seyd, ar dyd any dede, Þe same weye þat þe ermyte &yogh;ede, Þat yche wey þe ermyte &yogh;ede ynne To þe worlde, to do hys synne.
6.110: Þe abbot Appollo say saghe. euerydeyl; And how he was temptede, he wyst hyt weyl, And fonded for to take þe strete, with þat olde man for to mete: he seyd, "olde man! what dost þou here, And why hast þou so mornyng chere? whydyr hast þou þoght to go? Be By. sy&yogh;t hyt semeþ þat þe were wo."
6.111: Þe oldë man seyd ry&yogh;t no&yogh;t, But hyt ran hym weyl yn þo&yogh;t Þat þe abbot had had O, om . H. inspyracyun, And wyst hys hyt. grete temptacyun; For shame he my&yogh;t nat telle how smart smert. Þe temptyng þat come to hys hert; But þe abbot wyst for certeyn, And bad bade O, had H. hym to turne a&yogh;eyn; And shewed hym weyl for two þynges, why þat he hadde no temptynges; He seyd, 'þe fende of hym ne ro&yogh;te, Ne hym to tempte aboutë so&yogh;te, Ne þoght hys lyfe so moche wurþy, For he helde hym self so holy, And blamed oþer for here fallyng,' "Þy lyfe hym þynkeþ ys wurþ no þyng; To gode men ys hyt grete passyun To fele þe fendes temptacyun; And for he tempted tempteþ. þe no&yogh;t here, Yn ouþer stede þou shalt by bye. hyt dere; Ne late þou nat ly&yogh;tly by þo Þat are tempted of flesshly wo, But, þenk weyl þat þey are gode, &YOGH;yf þey þat temptyng with-stode, And are sykerer aftyr temptynges, And kepe hem better with many þynges; And &yogh;yt &yogh;yt O, hyt H. men sey God loueþ hem no&yogh;t, Þat haue no temptyng yn dede ne þoght. Þys temptyng was for þy despyte Þat þou haddest of þe gode ermyte whan he hys hys O, om . H. temptyng to þe shrofe, And þy cumforte awey hym drofe."
6.112: At þys pas 'p' erased. þys tale tolde ys For temptacyons temptacyun. of mannys flesshe, Þat none ne myscumforte hym Þogh þat hys flesshe be brysl and brym. So holy man was neuer none Þat temptacyun ne hat haþ. hym ouergone, were hyt lytyl, or were hyt mykyl, Þat of hys flesshe ne haþ hadde sum prykyl; And þo þat wyl be ry&yogh;t certeyne, Cumforte hem hem O, hym H. weyl to fy&yogh;t a&yogh;eyn, For no man may yn certeyn be, But he fy&yogh;t flesshly lustys lust. to fle.
6.113: God graunte vs allë now fro heþen Oure flesshë so to holde be-neþen, byneþen. And oure soules so to save haue. aboue, Þat God of heuene vs allë loue.

7.1: Of þese dedly synnës seuene, Þat we wraþþe with, God of heuene, Of hem haue we touched neyde nede. As holy men haue wryten and seyd; &YOGH;yt mow[ë] we nát weyl nat. weyl werche &YOGH;yf we forgetë holy cherche, holy cherche, our modyr dere, Of here shul we telle &yogh;ow here, How men synne, and on what wyse, A&yogh;ens þat falleþ to here fraunchyse.
7.2: Þat a&yogh;ens here fraunchyse falles, 'Sacrylegë' men hyt calles; 'Sacrylegë,' frenche hyt ys, Menyng of 'mysdede' or 'mys.' 'Mysdedë to holynes,' 'Sacrylege' on Englysshe ys; Allë þyng þat men with-holde, Stole or reftë, reft. &yogh;yue or solde, with-outë leue of here wytyng, Þat kepë holy cherches þyng, Alle swych þyng ys sacrylege, with-outë leue ys alle outrage.
7.3: Now of þe fyrst þat we haue spoke, Þey þat hauë cherches broke, And stole þo þynges þat were þer-ynne, 'Sacrylage' men calle þat synne.
7.4: &YOGH;yf þyng vnhalewed were forgete, Þat yn holy cherche were lete, Or halewed þyng yn ouþer stede lay, And oght þerof were bore away, where Wheþer. hyt werë &yogh;yue or solde, For sacrylege, alle ys hyt tolde.
7.5: Many vyces þerto her to. longe; Alle are þey synne, but sum are stronge; y shal &yogh;ow telle of on. sum maners As 'manuel pecchés' me lers. manuele pecche . . leres. But, vnkynde and enuyous, Ouerdo, proud, and daungerous, Euermorë fynde þey teyl, Þogh a man sey neuer so weyl; Noþeles, so weyl y nat seyd, But þat to my sawe, blame may be leyd For foule englyssh, and feble ryme Seyde oute of resun many tyme; But God &yogh;elde hem at here endyng, Þat wyl amende myn vnkunnyng; But who so blameþ and wyl nat amende, mende. He doþe nat as þe curteys kende. Go we furþe now now furþ. on oure werk:—
7.6: &YOGH;yf a man yn euyl smyte a clerk, Yn sacrylage he falleþ ylle &YOGH;yf he dyde hyt by hys wylle. &YOGH;yf he be man of relygyoun, Þou art to blame with more resun; Twey skyles are ful perylous, Boþe ordred and relygyous.
7.7: Also relygyous are men are. to wyte, Þat for maystry wyl gladly smyte; Þey ogh oghte. to be suffráble and meke, And no foly on ouþer men seke; Hys tung shuld be hys fauchoun; Hys strokes shulde be hys orysun; &YOGH;yf any be yn foly stoute, Holde yn cloystre, Holde hym yn cloustre. and com nat out.
7.8: Also may he be sore a-ferde Þat doþ vyleynye yn chyrche &yogh;erde, Namly, syn hyt halewed was, Þe more he doþë of trespas. Vnkynde man ys he hardly hardyly. Þat yn cherche &yogh;erde cherche &yogh;erde O, cher&yogh;erde H. doþ vyleyny; Oure long hous hyt ys to come, To reste yn, tyl þe day of dome. Þerfore we shuld, &yogh;yf we were kynde, kepe hyt clene with godë mynde.
7.9: And þese prestes me þynkeþ do synne Þat late here bestys fyle þer-ynne. Þe gres ys hys þat þerë grenes, Þe placë ys þe parysshenes.
7.10: But lordës þat haue seynorye, Þey do þeryn most vyleynye; For þer here. hope ys, whan þey shul deye, Þat yn þe cherche men shul hem leye; And y shal telle a lytyl wy&yogh;t, how a bonde man bourded with a kny&yogh;t; And þe borde ys gode to here, who-so loueþ wurdes to lere. A tale
7.11: [The Tale of the Reproof that a Norfolk Bondman gave a Knight for not respecting the Sanctity of a Churchyard.] Yn Northfolk, yn a tounne, wonede a kny&yogh;t besyde a persone; Fyl hyt so, þe kny&yogh;tes manere was nat fro þe cherche ful fere; And was hyt þan, as oftyn falles, Brokë were þe cherche-&yogh;erde walles.
7.12: Þe lordës hyrdës often lete Hys bestys yn-to þe cherche cherche om . &yogh;erde & ete; Þe bestys dyd as þey mote moste. nede, Fyled oueral þere þey &yogh;ede. A bond man say saghe. þat, and was wo Þat þe bestys shuld þere go; He com to þe lorde, and seyd hym þys:— "Lorde," he seyde, "&yogh;oure bestys go mys; &YOGH;oure hyrde doþ wrong, and &yogh;ourë knauys, Þat late &yogh;oure bestys fyle þus þese grauys; Þere mennys bonys shuldë lye, Bestës shuld do no vyleynye."
7.13: Þe lordes answere was sumwhat vyle, And þat falleþ euyl to a man gentyle; "weyl were hyt do ry&yogh;t for þe nones To wurschyþ swych[ë] cherlës bones; what wurschyp shuld men make Aboute swych cherlës bodyes blake?" Þe bonde man answerëd and seyd wurdys to-gedyr ful weyl ful weyl to-gedyr. leyd: "Þe lorde þat made of erþë, erles, Of þe þat. same erþe made he cherles; Erlës my&yogh;t, and lordës stut, As cherlës shal yn erþe be put; Erlës, cherlës, alle at ones, Shal none knowe &yogh;oure, fro oure, bones."
7.14: Þe lorde lestened þe wurdës weyl And recorded hem euery deyl; No morë to hym wulde he seye, But, lete hym go furþe hys weye; He seyd þe bestys shulde no more, By hys wyl, comë þore. [6- syll. line ] Seþen he closed þe cherche&yogh;erde so Þat no best my&yogh;t come þarto For to ete, ne fyle þer-ynne; So þo&yogh;t þught. hym seþen, þat hyt was synne.
7.15: Þyr are but fewë lordës now Þat turne a wrde so wel to prow; But, who who so. seyþ hem any skylle, Mysseye a&yogh;en, fouly þey wylle. Lordynges,—þyr are ynow of þo, Of gentyl men, þyr are but fo. fewe
7.16: Hyt ys defended yn þe decre, Þat none yn cherche shal beryed be, But bysshope, or abbot of relygyun, Or prest þat ys of gode renoun.
7.17: A man þat haþ no gode fame ryfe ryffe. Of dede, of hew, of holy lyfe, Of gode feyþ, ne of charyte Yn almes dede, ne of ouþer bounte, Me þenkeþ hyt were ful perylous To berye swych one yn Goddes house; with swych ys holy cherche but fyled, And hem self are moste bygyled. &YOGH;yf þe soulë be nat wurþy Þat þe body lygge so solempny, solemply. Þan haþ þe soulë morë more of. peyne; Þat men wurschyp þe body, ys veyne.
7.18: wykked men and vserers, lechours, and lordys of foule maners, Þat mow &yogh;yue pens ful godë wone, Þey shul be leyde yn toumbe of stone, And hys ymáge ful feyre depeynte, Ry&yogh;t as hé were a cors seynt; Þe wrecched soule, þe soþe to seye, Shal a-bye alle þe noblye, And sum for euer be bro&yogh;t to bale; sorow And þerby wyl y telle a tale.
7.19: [The Tale of Valentine, and how Devils puld his Body out of its Grave in the Church.] Þyr was a man þat 'þat' omitted. hyght Valentyne, A tale Playtour he was, and ryche man fyne, For of þe cherche of Myleyne mylon. was he playtour, More for mede þan Goddes onour. Besyde Genë, a noble cytë, Deyde Valentyne, and beryed shuld be; Yn seynt Syxtes cherchë shuld he lye; So ordeyned men whan he shuld deye. Þe fyrste ny&yogh;t þat he was þere leyde, Þe wardeynes of þe cherche vpbreyde, And herd one cry, rewly and shyl, As he were put oute a&yogh;ens hys wyl.
7.20: Þe wardeynes asked what þat my&yogh;t be, "Ryse we vp vp we. alle, and go we se." Þere he was beryed, þydyr þey ran, And sagh many fendes aboute þys man; And of hys graue þey oute vp. hym pulde; Oute of þe cherche, drawe hym þey wulde; Þe deuylys dro&yogh; drowe. hym by þe fete As hyt were careyne þat dogges ete. Þe wardeynes werë sore affryght For þat noysë and þat syght; A&yogh;en to here bedde þey &yogh;ede; Þey durst no lenger dwelle for drede. On þe morne whan þey were ryse, Þey &yogh;ede to þe graue, þere þey were so agryse; Þer-yn alle aboute þey soght, But þe body founde þey no&yogh;t. Þey opende þe dores, and loked aboute, And fonde þe body lygge lyggynge. þere with-oute; Þe fete ybounde to-gedyr ful faste, And as a foulë careyne caste.
7.21: Seynt Gregory seyþ hardly, Þere he lay fyrst, he was nat wurþy; But hys soule hadde pyne þe more For þe pompe and pryde þat he was leyd þore. lordes are besy aboute to haue Proude stones lyggyng an hye on here graue; Þurgh þat pryde þey mowe be lore, Þogh þey hadde do no synne byfore; Hyt helpyþ ry&yogh;t noght, þe toumbe of pryde, whan þe soule fro pyne may hyt nat hyde.
7.22: &YOGH;yf þou euer vsedest halewed þyng, And wystyst hyt fyl to cherches offryng, Hyt ys grete synne, y do þe to knowne, &YOGH;yf þou helde hyt as for þyn owne. &YOGH;yf þou wyþhelde any þyng seþyn Þat hyt was to holy cherche &yogh;euyn, &yogh;yuen. Þyn or ouþres, with-outë leue Of parsone, or prest, or cherchë reue; Hyt ys sacrylage, y þe ply&yogh;t, To wyþholde þat falleþ to cherchë ry&yogh;t.
7.23: &YOGH;yf þou dedyst euer þat vnlawe, A man oute of holy cherche to drawe Seþen þat he toke hym þar-tyl, Þou hast synned yn moche vnskyl. But &yogh;yf he hadde do a&yogh;ens þe assyse Þat fyl to holy cherches fraunchyse, Slayn one þar-ynne, or robbed hyt, Hyt shulde nat þan saue hym, saue hym þan. by my wyt.
7.24: Þe lewed man, holy cherche wyl forbede To stounde yn þe chaunsel whyl men rede: who-so-euer þarto ys custummer, Þogh he be of grete powere, Boþe he synneþ and doþe greuaunce A&yogh;ens þe clergy ordynaunce.
7.25: But &yogh;yt do wymmen gretter folye Þat vse to stonde among þe clergye, 3 Oþer at matyns, or at messe, But &yogh;yf hyt were yn cas of stresse; 3 3_3 Omitted in Harl . For þerof may come temptacyun, And dysturblyng of deuocyun; For foule þoght cumþ of feble ye-sy&yogh;t, And fordoþë grace with ry&yogh;t; And with a tale hyt may be shewed, Þat ys gode boþe for lered and lewed.
7.26: [The Tale of the Temptation of St. John Chrysostom's Deacon.] An holy man telleþ vs þus, A tale Men calle hym Ion Crysostomus; He was a bysshope, and ful gode clerk, Þat shewe hys bokës of hys werk; Swych grace of God, grauntede hym was, At euery tyme þat he song hys masse Þe holy goste to hym was sent whan he shulde receyue þe sacrament; Certeynly, aftyr þe sacrë, Yn a dowue lyknes he my&yogh;t myghte hyt se. se, So whyte and Omitted. so blesful, and so clere, whan he vsed vpp-on þe autere.
7.27: Of þat cumfort, and and of. þat sy&yogh;t, He þanked oftë God almy&yogh;t. Þe fendë hadde þarwith enuye, And wulde shewe hys wykked maystry.
7.28: A day seynt Ion shulde synge hys messe, Þe fende made hym yn womman lyknesse, weyl atyrede, with mochë pryde, And stodë ouþer men besyde.
7.29: Þe dekene þat serued seynt Ion, At here turnyng tymes echon He behelde þys womman weyl, And hys herte chaunged euery deyl; Temptacyun of þys womman, Ouer al yn hys þo&yogh;t hyt ran.
7.30: Þe bysshope, aftyr þe sacrë, Shulde receyue God, as byfyl fyl. to be; As he stode and heylde helde. þe oste, He loked vp aftyr þe holy goste; But þat tyme ne come hyt no&yogh;t. Þou Iangler, take þou godë kepe, hyt were wel bettyr þou were on slepe; &YOGH;yf nyt ne be amended here, O . inserts—Wyþ shryfte of mouth and pen|aunce clere. Elleswere shalt þou a-bye hyt dere.
7.81: Sacrylage also may be for tyþe; yn þat, synne men ful oftë syþe. Of allë þyng, þat þe neweþ, Tyþe ry&yogh;tly, ór elles hyt þe reweþ. Of þe werst þou shalt nat &yogh;yue, For þan lesest þou þy gode yn þy lyue; Ne &yogh;yue hyt nat with wykked wyl, For al þe touþer, mayst þou þan spyl; &YOGH;yue God þe best þat þou mayst haue, And alle þe touþer he wyl þe saue. O . inserts— But þou do so, wyte þou weyl He wyl þe reuë eury deyl.
7.82: Foure þynges are &yogh;yuë specyaly To euery man þat tyþeþ ry&yogh;tly; nota bene Þe fyrst ys, long lyfe to haue; Þe touþer, þe yn gode hele to saue; Þe þryd ys, gracë gode with-ynne; to wynne. Þe fourþe, for&yogh;yuenes of þy synne: &YOGH;yf þou wylt haue any of þyse, Tyþë weyl, and on gode syse. assyse.
7.83: &yogh;yf þou turnedest, for worldes wynnyng, halewed place, or holy þyng, Cherche &yogh;erde, or þere chapyl was, Tymber, stones, eren, or glas, Curteynes, or ouþer vestyment, Or any oþer vesselement Þat falleþ to holy cherches seruyse, And vsest hem on ouþer wyse, Þy wytyng;—þou synnest dedly Yn sacrylage certeynly.
7.84: Þarto shal y preue my sawe By a tale of þe oldë lawe; And þys tale yn þat tyme fyl, fel. Þat was of þe prophete Danyël.
7.85: [The Tale of Belshazzar's Feast, and the Prophet Daniel.] Þyr was a kyng of grete powere; A tale. yn hys tyme was none hys pere; ynogh he hadde of worldës my&yogh;t, And Baltazar Crost out, and 'Nabygodonosore' inserted. hys namë hy&yogh;t.
7.86: Þys kyng was a paynym, and with oste he come to Ierusalem, And robbed þe temple, þys Balta&yogh;are, And þe tresour awey bare; Þe vessel þat was of ryche metalle, Þat Goddes temple was seruede with-alle, þat, and more, he dyd aloyne, And ledde hem yn-to Babyloyne.
7.87: Sone aftyrward, þys ychë kyng Deyd, and madë hys endyng. hys sone reyned yn þat same, And Balta&yogh;arë was hys name; Alle þe vessel with hym lefte, Þat hys fadyr hadd stole and refte.
7.88: A day he made a noble feste with barons and with rychë geste; Þys vessel þat hys fadyr stale, Rychely he dyd hym serue with-alle; Of þe vessel þey ete and dranke, But to God made þey no þanke; But yn alle here moste gladyng, To fals goddys þey made wurschypyng. A kandelstyke stode þe kyng before, Þat oute of Ierusalem was bore; Þe kyng lokede to þat candelstyke, And sagh besyde a grete ferlyke: Vndyr þe kandelstyke, a lytel logh, He sagh an hande wryte on þe wogh; No morë he sagh þan þe hande, But þe lettres were weyl farande; he redde hyt as he sate on þe des, "Mane. techel. fares. phares. " No more þyr was þere wryte; On englys þus ys hyt to wyte, 'To mornë shal shal þe. departyng be, Of þy ryche kyngdom fro þe.'
7.89: Þe kyng vndyrstode no þyng of þys, Ne none of hysë coude hym wys. As he þys hand began to holde, hys herte bygan to tremle and colde; he shewed hyt to alle hys ássemble, And crydë hyt þurgh þurghe out. þe cyte, 'Þat &yogh;yf any coude do hym to wyte, what hyt mente, þat þere was wryte, He shulde haue of hym grete mede, Þat coudë vndo þat yn dede.' But none of alle, forsoþe to wene, Coude telle þe kyng what hyt wlde mene.
7.90: But þe quene seyd sone anone: "Syre kyng, y wotë where ys one, Þat kan do &yogh;ow alle to knowe what ys wrytë on þe wowe. yn þys cyte, yn a strete, woneþ a ful wys prophete, hys name men callë Danyël, he shal vndo þe wrytyng wel."
7.91: Þe kyng aftyr Danyël sente, And þe prophete to hym wente; Þe kyng hym preyd, byfore hem alle, To tellë hem what shulde befalle.
7.92: Þe prophete wuldë no þyng hyde: "Þe hand þat þou sawe yn þe euyntyde, hyt was sent fro God almy&yogh;t, Þat hys wraþþe ys to þe dy&yogh;t, For þou were serued of þe vesseles Þat of hys temple were Ieuwels; Iuelles. Þys day before, of hem þou ete, And no wurschyp of hym hym O, hem H. þou lete, Þat ys God, alle þyng weldande, And þe and þyne haþ yn hys hande; But to fals goddes þou madest onour with vessel of hys owne tresour; And for þou dedyst boþe euyl, and seyd, Þy kyngdom ys yn balaunce leyd, Tyl Tyl H O. ry&yogh;t be-demeþ, be-demede. with euyn hand, To wham hyt shal be &yogh;yue, þy land. Þurgh dome of God, hyt ys so dryue, To twey maner of folke þy land ys &yogh;yue; Medys, and Persys, þy land shul haue; Þe, ne þyne, mayst þou nat saue. Here ys wryte þe samë wyse, Y sey to þe, to þe O, to H. ry&yogh;t as hyt seyse."
7.93: Þe Þat. samë ny&yogh;t þe lande was lore, Þe kyng was slayn, and awey bore.
7.94: Here mayst þou se, euyl-wunne þyng, O . has in margin, 'note. of euill goten goodes.' with eyre shal neuer make gode endyng, Namly, with þyng of holy cherche Shalt þou neuer spede wel to werche. 7.95: Þus fareþ hyt by þese þe. parsones cosynes; Þát þe parsone wynnyþ, þe cosyne tynes; O . gloss 'lest.' yn þe parsones tyme, rychely he lyueþ, Aftyr hym, no man of hym &yogh;yueþ; of hym no man oghte &yogh;yueþ. yn hys tyme, ofte pens he telleþ, Aftyr hym, for pouert, penys he selleþ.
7.96: Also with purchasours ry&yogh;t so hyt fareþ, Alle þat þey bygge, here eyrës bareþ; A purchasoure may beye þyng, & with lawe, with-oute any dede of wrong or sawe; any wronge of dede or of sawe. But lokeþ, &yogh;yue he he O, &yogh;e H. wynne þat katel weyl, wharewith he byeþ hyt euerydeyl. &YOGH;yf he haue wunne þe penys penys O, pens H. ry&yogh;t, Þan haþ he þe lande with-outë ply&yogh;t; &YOGH;yue he haue wunne þe penys penys O, pens H. falsle, with ry&yogh;t to þe lande com neuer he. with fals[ë] weyght, or fals[ë] peys, And many falshede ouþer weys; And &yogh;yt moste, with fals sweryng, wynneþ manyone moche þyng; with swyche þyng, wene þou hyt no&yogh;t Þat þe hous ne lande was ry&yogh;tly bo&yogh;t.
7.97: Vnneþ lasteþ aght þat men bye with þat ys wunne with marchaundye; Yn erytage nat long hyt vayleþ, Þe þred eyre leseþ, lest. þat ouþer trauayleþ; Vnneþe ys any þat haþ gode grace To lyuë weyl with swych purchace, Oþer lyue þey a bysyly lyfe, Or lese hyt hyt O, om . H. for pouert and for for H, om . O. stryfe; For þys men se, and seye alday, "Þe þred eyre selleþ selþ. alle away."
7.98: For sacrylage, alle þys ys tolde, Þat vesselment of cherche ys wyþholde,— Chaleys, cloth, boke, or lome, LOOME or instrument, utensile, instrumentum . Prompt. Parv. — For sacrylage cumþ ofte hard dome; yn alle þe poyntës seyd before, Þat fro holy cherche, oght haþ bore, Or aght mysdo on any wyse Þat longeþ vn-to þe fraunchyse, Y or þou, yn any outrage, we synne dedly yn sacrylage.
7.99: Gode &yogh;yue vs grace so to serue here to serue so here. Holy cherche, oure modyr dere, Here so to serue, and wurschyp make, Þat we be hyre, and she vs take.

0.1: The fyrst sacrament ys holy bapteme, Houe of watyr, and noyted smerede. with creme; 'Crystendom,' or 'crystynyng,' Þat ys on englys, oure spekyng.
0.2: Crystendom, to cryst hyt longeþ, And to alle þat crystendom vndyrfongeþ; Þys ys þe fyrst and pryncypalle, Þurgh þe whych we are saued alle; Saued we are, þurgh crystendam, Of þe heued synne of Adam, yn whych synne alle mankynde ys bore, &YOGH;yt, and shal be, and was byfore.
0.3: Adams synnë was so grefe, Þat þyr was to God, none noun to God. so lefe, Þyt he ne shulde to hellë gone But he were wasshe yn þe fonte stone, yn fonte stone and watyr baptysed, As Ihesu cryst haþ had. dyuysed.
0.4: &YOGH;yf þou beleue þat any wham ys saued with-oute crystyndam, y seye, forsoþe þou hast mys went A&yogh;ens þys holy sacrament.
0.5: Ofte we here þe lewed men seye, Þat And. erre ful moche oute of þe weye, Þat of þe Iewës seye sum oun, 'Þey ne wote wheþer þey be saued or noun;' But of sum prestes ys gretter tene, Þat so of þe Iewës also wene; Certes, þey are alle yn were, And yn þe feyþ þey are nat clere, For, shal neuer Iewe þat deyeþ Iewe, Of heuene blys haue part ne prewe, But he be crystened yn þe holy gaste, And yn þe sacrament be ful stedfast.
0.6: Lo, here a wurde to leue &yogh;oure drede! yn þe gospel þat we rede, Þat god Ihesu vs allë techeþ Þurgh seynt Mark, þat hyt precheþ, "He þat beleueþ and ys baptysed, He shal be saued, so ys dyuysed; And he þat beleueþ nat, forsoþe & ywys, Boþe body and soulë, lore he ys."
0.7: loke Lokeþ. how &yogh;e mow be a-bawed, þat seye þat þe Iewe ys saued! Þe Iewe, þe oldë lawë kan, But þat alone may saue no man; And þarfore was hyt fyled and left, For heuenë blys, vs hyt hyt vs. refte Þurgh Adams synne fro vs echone, Tyl hyt was clensed yn flume Iordone, whan Ihesu was baptysed þer-ynne For to wasshe awey þat synne; And al þat euer to Cryst wyl teme, Behoueþ be baptysed yn watyr and creme: Þan art þou clene, þou shalt beleue, Of Adams synnë, and of Eue.
0.8: Þarfore hyt ys þe fyrst sacrament Þat þou art to, fyrst made present; Lokë þat þou kunne hyt knowe; hyt makeþ þe hygh, þere þou were lowe, hyt makeþ þe fre, þat er were þralle, Fro þe fendës seruage alle, Þat þe þar neuer þe fendë drede But hyt be þurgh þyn owne mysdede.
0.9: &YOGH;yf a chylde be dedë bore— Þogh hyt were quyk yn wombe byfore— And, receyue nat þe bapteme, Of heuene may hyt neuer cleme; with-outë doute, beleue &yogh;e þys, Þat hyt shal neuer come to blys; Ne peyne of hetë, ne of colde, Hyt shal non fele, no ry&yogh;t hyt wolde; Hyt noght mysdyd, ne serued wo, Ne No. to nonë shal hyt go; Þys ys peyne with-outen ende, hyt shal neuer to Ioyë wende. Gretë grace ys to hem lent, Þat here receyue þys sacrament.
0.10: Also, &yogh;e þat heue chyldryn al day, loke &yogh;e be stedfast yn oure &yogh;oure. lay, Þat nonë haue yn hertë doute, Ne to wycchecrafte leste no ne. loute.
0.11: Þou settest þy self yn borghgage To teche þe chylde whan hyt haþ age; &YOGH;yf þou se hyt mysdo or seye, Þou shalt teche hyt better wey, &YOGH;yf hyt be so þat þou maght, Þou þou O, þat H. art holde þat hyt be taght; Quyte þe weyl weyl so. oute of borghgang, Þat þou ne haue for hyt no wrang.
0.12: loke also, &yogh;yf þou euer ware Yn place þere wymmen chyldryn bare; &YOGH;yf þou sawe hyt yn perel of dede, And þou ne coudest do bote ne rede, Ne seyë wurde, ne helpe at nede, So þat hyt to þe deþë &yogh;ede; Þou shalt þerforë perel haue; Vnkunnyng shal þe nat saue; For euery man, boþe hygh and logh, Þe poyntes of bapteme oweþ to knowe, To helpe chyldryn yn many kas; Men wete neuer what nede one has. who so ne kan, y rede hym lere Yn sy&yogh;te, yn dede, and he may here.
0.13: Y shal &yogh;ow teche, as y herde telle Onës a frerë menor spelle: "&YOGH;yf þou se a chylde yn swyche perel Þat none may saue hyt with no wylle, Sey þan þus, &yogh;yf þou haue haste, "y crysten þe yn þe name of þe fadyr & sone & holy gast," And &yogh;yue, what þou wylt, hyt a name, And kast on water; þan ys hyt frame; And &yogh;yf þou &yogh;yue hyt namë none, Noþer Robert, Wyllyam, no ne. Ione, Loke þat þese wurdës be weyl seyd, And water þer-on algate leyde; And þat þyr be none ouþer waste, But yn þe fadyr and sone, and holy gaste; Þese wurdes for&yogh;ete þou naght, Ne watyr, what as euer elles be ys. wro&yogh;t."
0.14: Mydwyuës þat wyþ wymmen wone, Alle þe poyntes, behoueþ hem kone; Prestes shuld teche hem þe ordynaunce, what þey shuld sey and do yn chaunce, And examyne her examyne here O, examyne H. what she couthe, what she shuld do, and seye with mouþe.
0.15: [The Tale of the Midwife who christend a Child wrongly.] Y shal &yogh;ow telle of a mydwyfe, A tale Þat loste a chylde, boþe soule & lyfe. he tolde hyt yn hys sermoun, And &yogh;aue here ofte hys malysoun.
0.16: Þys mydwyfe, whan þe chylde was bore, She helde hyt on here lappe before; And whan she sawe þat hyt shulde deye, She bygan, loudë for to crye, And seyd, "God and seynt Ione Crysten þe chylde, boþe flesshe and bone."
0.17: The next twelve lines, from O, are omitted in H. Þys mydwyffe noghte ellës seyde, [ Bodl. MS. ] And yn þe cherche-&yogh;erde þey wulde hyt haue leyde, As a-nouþer chyld shuld ha be Þat hade receyuede þe solempte.
0.18: Þe prest askede þe mydwyffe, '&YOGH;yfe hyt were cristenede whan hyt hade lyffe, And who hyt cristened, and on what manere, And what was seyde, þat any myghte here.'
0.19: Þe mydwyffe seyde unto þe prest, Margin, 'a note for mydwyffes.' "Þys herde þey þat stode me nest, 'Þat God almyghty and Seynt Ioun &yogh;yue þe chylde cristendom yn flesshe and boun."'
0.20: Þan seyd þe preste, "God and seynt Iame [ Harl. MS. ] &YOGH;yue þe boþe sorow and shame, And Crystys malysun haue þou for-þy, And alle þe ouþer þat were þe by! Yn euyl tymë were þou bore, For yn þy defaute, a soule ys lore." She was commaunded she shuld no more Come eftesones þere chyldryn were bore.
0.21: Mydwyues, y tolde thys tale for &yogh;ow, Þat &yogh;yf &yogh;e kunnat, lerneþ how To sauë þat, God bo&yogh;t ful dere, Þe poyntes of bapteme y rede &yogh;ow lere; Mydwyfe ys a perylus þyng But she kunne þe poyntes of crystenyng;
0.22: Ne beleueþ nat on þese shappers, shapperes. &YOGH;oure mysdede ful mykyl deres; y wolde þo shappers were on lowe, And al þo þat on hem trowe.
0.23: Þe beleue ys, 'þe fadyr and sone & holy gaste;' Alle ouþer beleue ys wykked and waste; Þurgh hem ys alle þyng shape & wro&yogh;t, And ouþer shappers shapperes. ne are no&yogh;t; God ys shapper of alle þyng, he wote þe mydward, and þe endyng; Þe oþer shappers, þat men of seye, Hyt ys a beleue of deuyl weye.
0.24: Þe mete þat &yogh;e leye at þe chyldës hede heuede. For swyche shappers, were bettyr leued; &YOGH;yf hyt for hem þerë lye, Þan ys hyt ys hyt O, ys H. a wykked erysye; heresye. ley hyt for þe loue of þe holy gaste, Fadyr, and sone, oo God stedfaste, As wysly as he become a chylde, Bore of Marye, mayden mylde, Þat he &yogh;yue hyt to lyue yn 'yn' omitted. gode grace, And gode endyng, and se hys face.
0.25: &YOGH;yf þou were euer so vnwys For to crystene a chyldë twys, Or &yogh;yf þou euer consentedest þar-to Þat any ouþer shulde so do,— At home, as yn pryuyte, Anouþer tyme, þat men my&yogh;t se,— For &yogh;yf hyt were baptysed at hame wyþ alle þe poyntes of bapteme name, Þan were hyt a&yogh;ens þe feyþe to werche, Eftesones Eftsone. to baptyse baptyse O, baptysed H. hyt at cherche; But &yogh;yf þou suppose þyr fayleþ a poynte Þat to þe crystendom shuld a-mounte, Þan were hyt nat for to drede For to fulfyl þat shulde be nede; For alle þe poyntes of watyr & creme, Þurgh alle crystendom ys o bapteme, O baptemë, and nat two, Of alle þe þo. poyntes þat þou sest do. Þarfore he þat ys ones baptysed, Ones for euer ys; þus ys auysed.
0.26: Also, &yogh;e þat chyldryn heue, &yogh;e shul nat for&yogh;ete ne leue To teche hyt pater noster & crede; &YOGH;yf &yogh;e ne do, hyt ys to drede.
0.27: To foly þou shalt nat drawe ne wone Þy goddo&yogh;tyr ne þy godsone, Namely to þat vylayny Þat falleþ vn-to lechery, Ne to no foly þat may be; Þou shalt teche hem synne to fle. Ne nat be so fole hardy, Þy goddo&yogh;tyr to lye þe by, Ne for to dwelle a-lone with þe, For perel þat may falle and be.
0.28: Many a pryuy peryl þyr ys, And specyaly yn drunkenes; yn drunkenes men wyl rage, And, ragyng wyl reyse korage; And sonë may a man be shent Þat doþe a&yogh;ens þe comaundement.
0.29: Seynt Gregory telleþ yn hys spelle Of swyche a shame þat onës felle.
0.30: [The Tale of the Bad Bourgeois 'Curialis,' Common-Councilman, bourgeois. who lay with his God-daughter and was kild for it.] A man hefe onës at þe fonte A maydë chylde, as men are wonte; Þys mayde wax, and bygan to belde weyl yn-to womans elde; And at Ester tyme gan hyt falle whan men hadde fastë lenten alle, Þys man bysoghte, for specyalte, Þat hys god-do&yogh;tyr wyþ hym my&yogh;t be, And alle þat ychë Esterday And lenger, &yogh;yf hyt were here pay.
0.31: Þe fadyr and þe modyr graunted sone; Þey þo&yogh;t none euyl my&yogh;t be done. Þys man, for drunkenes & vnry&yogh;t, lay by hys god-do&yogh;tyr þat yche ny&yogh;t: Þys man on þe mornë þo&yogh;t How synfully þat he he O, om . H. hadde wro&yogh;t; Ful grete þo&yogh;te þan was he ynne, Þat he hadde do so greuus a synne; Twey þoghtes yn hys hertë come, To go go O, gode H. to þe cherche, or byde at home: "&YOGH;yf y vnto þe cherchë &yogh;ede, Of venïaunce y haue grete drede; And, &yogh;yf y nat þedyr go, Men wyl wene y haue do sum wo." So algate vnto þe cherche he name; he drede nat God, but morë shame.
0.32: Þe fyrst day, he dred hym sore he shuld be cumbred sumwore, And &yogh;yt a-noþer he lokede ay, whyche tyme þe fende wulde bere hym a|way; Alle þe woke, for worldës shame, He &yogh;ede to þe cherche, but lytyl to frame;
0.33: whan he hadde long a-bydë so, And, no skaþë come hym to, Þys þoght he yn hys herte ful raþe, For he hadde þarfore no skaþe, he wendë God had hyt forgete As ouþer men do þat haue forlete; Or þo&yogh;t þat he hadde hyt for&yogh;yue, And hym neded nat þer-of be shryue, Ne shulde þerof come no myschaunce, For he was of so longe suffraunce.

2.2: Goddës sone, of heuene a-boue, He shewed vs alle, for gretë loue; For whan hys passyun neyghed nye, To hys dyscyplys þat were hym bye, He &yogh;aue &YOGH;afe. hys body hem to fede,— More loue ne my&yogh;t he shewe yn dede,— Þat þey shuldë myndë haue On hym, þat he my&yogh;t hem saue; &YOGH;yt aftyrward he lete hym slo with ful vyle deþ, and pynyng wo; For vs, and hem, ded he þys, To bryngë vs echone to blys, Ne No. more loue ne my&yogh;t he do, Ne neuer man, my&yogh;t so do; For vs he ded hyt, þys ys certeyn, Þat we shuld loue hym weyl a&yogh;en; Þogh we vs self &yogh;af an hundryd syþe, O poynt of loue ne my&yogh;t we kyþe vn-to þe loue þat he haþ vs doun, For hyt ys oure saluacyun; And of vs, askeþ he ry&yogh;t no&yogh;t But þat may weyl y-nogh be wro&yogh;t, No þyng but loue-longyng, To loue hym weyl ouer alle þyng, And for hys loue to leuë synne; hys loue, hys blys, þan mow we wynne; For þou mayst neuer haue hym to þe, But, þou wylt fyrst synnë fle; Alle þyng he loueþ, but synne he hates; &YOGH;yf þou hym louest, with synne þou wlates. steynyst &YOGH;yf þou loue louest. one, þe behoueþ nedes Forsake þat þyng þat he þe forbedes; Elles, hyt ys tolde no loue, And namëly to God a-boue.

2.8: [The Tale of the Priest for whom the Sacramental Bread and Wine were turnd into a Child's Flesh and Blood.] Þyr was a man of relygyoun; Of almës he had grete renoun; But, for þe fende þe fende O, þe H (? þe = they). wulde haue had. hym shent, He beleued nat yn þe sacrament, And seyd 'hyt was nat Ihesu Þat conceyued was þurgh vertu; Ne Ihesu was nat þe oblé vbble. Þat reysed was was reysede. at þe sacré; And þo þat wurschep ded þarto, To beleue hyt, hyt. hyt. was nat to do.'

2.47: Þat prest, y blame ouer alle þyng, Þat with-oute skylle lettyþ to synge; For many a soulë my&yogh;t be saued with þe messe þat he haþ leued; For al[lë] þat yn peynë ys, Abydeþ þe socoure of þe messe; For euery messe makeþ memórye Of soules þat are yn purgatórye; Mochë þanke shal þat prest haue, Þat helpeþ, hem for to saue; For no þyng may hem so moche auayle Of here peyne and here trauayle, As þe sacrament of þe autere, Ne makeþ hem of peyne so clere.

2.49: [The Tale of the Priest who was waited on by a Dead Lord whom he afterwards sang out of Purgatory.] þer was a prest, Felyx was was H, om . O. hys name; Bysyde hys wonyng yn a paþ was a wasshyng yn an hote baþ; Þys prest þedyr ofte þyder. oftë &yogh;ede To wasshe hym whan he haddë nede. Þys prest þere euer redy fonde A man þat serued hym to fote and honde; he drogh hys hosen of, and hys shone, And efte was redy hem on to done; At euery tyme þat he þedyr cam, hys shone and hys hosen, of he nam, And serued hym at euery a tyde, Yn þe water, and eke besyde.
2.50: Þys prest, þat cam com. þedyr so ofte, Þat þys man serued so softe, he ne asked hym neuer more when he was, ne how he come þore; But euery tymë was redy And serued hym peynyblëly. penyblely O, peynybly H.
2.51: Þys prest þo&yogh;t he serued hym weyl, "hys trauayle wyl y quyte sum deyl." On o day he þedyr þo&yogh;t, And, twey loues with hym he bro&yogh;t; yn-to þe baþ, &yogh;ede þe prest, And, wesshe wysshe. hym, as he dyd neste: Þys man was þere hym a&yogh;ayne; To serue hym weyl, he dyde hys mayne;
2.52: Þys preste, whan he shuld furþë go, He &yogh;aue þe man þese louës two, And þanked hym moche, hys seruyse, And more he wuldë ouþer wyse.
2.53: Þys man answered þe prest a&yogh;eyn: "Þys brede þou bro&yogh;test to me yn veyn, For neuer morë shal y ete Bredë, ne noun ouþer mete. Y am a man, þat ys dede, Þat neuer more shal etë brede."
2.54: Þe preste asked "on what manere Ys hyt þat þou wonest þus here?" Þys yche man answered and seyd, "Y was lorde here, are y deyde; And þys seruyse þat y am ynne, ys þe peynë for my synne; But y pray þe, pur charyte, Offre on þe auter þese loues for me; And y beseche þe, ouer alle þyng, Þat syxe messys for me þou synge, For, were þey sunge, y hope to wende Yn-to þe ioye with-outen ende. whan þe syxtë messe ys lefte, &YOGH;yf þou ne fyndë me here efte, know þou þan soþëly ywys Þat for þy prayere y am bro&yogh;t 'bro&yogh;t' omitted. yn blys."

2.58: yn þe seuenþe comaundement [page 73] Toucheþ to þys sacrament, Yn a talë of a kny&yogh;t, How þe prest þat lyueþ nat ry&yogh;t, Of hys preyer ys lytyl prowe, And þere telleþ hyt weyl how; And y shal telle a-nouþer here, Of a messë of a frere. A tale.
2.59: [The Tale of the Suffolk Man who was taken out of Purgatory by two Masses his Wife got sung for him.] A man yn Souþfolke onës deyde Besydë Sudbyry, men seyde. For þat man, swych grace was dy&yogh;t, Þat hym was graunted to come a ny&yogh;t For to spekë wyþ hys wyfe To amende þe defaute of hys lyfe: "&YOGH;yf a messe were for me doun with gode mannes deuocyoun, y hope," he seyd, "to blys go, And be delyuerd of alle my wo; Y prey þe, pur charyte, To trauayle so moche for me."
2.60: She graunted hym þat ychë bone, And ros vp on þe mornë sone, And, vn-to þe frerës &yogh;ede, For þere hoped she best to spede. She cam, com. and spak with a frere, And preyd she my&yogh;t hys messë here, And for here housbunde soule to synge, And she wulde &yogh;yuë hym offrynge.
2.61: Þe frere ded here a messe yn comune, as þe seruyse ys; whan þys messë sungë was She went home a godë pas. "þe messe," he seyde, "þou dedyst be do, A party hyt halpë þer-vn-to; My parte y had, of þat messe, As of þyng þat comune ys; &YOGH;yf one for me were specyale were specyaly for me. seyde, Þat ouþer for me blys had nede,— &YOGH;yf þe prest were of lyfe so gode gode O, go H. 2.62: On þe mornë, sone she &yogh;ede To þe frerës eft god spede, And shewed hyt to þe pryour, And prey[ed] hym of socour, '&YOGH;yf he had any broþer, Þat he hoped, were better þan oþer, Þat wyl syngë me a messe For a man þat dedë ys; And at myn esë he shal haue, To a pytaunce, þat he wyl craue.'
2.63: Þe pryor spake vn-to a frere, And prey[ed] hym on alle manere Þat he wulde a messë synge For þat soule þat she made preyng.

2.67: Þys wyfe come sonë on þe morne, And fyl on knees þe frere byforne, And toldë hym weyl, euery deyl, How he, for hys prayer, yn ioye was weyl; And þe frere ful weyl þarby lete, And þanked God; and 'and' omitted. for ioye he grete. wepte weyl were hym at hys endyng Þat had swych a prest for hym to synge!
2.68: Yn þys tale, þan, shewed ys, Ouer alle gode þan ys þe messe; For þe sacrament of þe autere Oueral passeþ hys powere; Yn þat messe, þey hem affye, Þe Þo. soules þat are yn purgatorye, For hyt makeþ mencyun of þe passyun As Ihesu Cryst to deþ was doun; Þe sone ys offred to þe fadyr yn heuene For þe þo. soules þat þe prest wyl neuene.
2.69: Also, þys talë wyl mene Þat þe preste be gode and clene; Þan wyl Ihesu Cryst hym here, For what þyng he makeþ preyere: Preye he for body, or for soule, soule or for bodye. Þat ys yn pyne, or here yn noye, Boþe wyl God almy&yogh;ty saue, what-so þe godë prest wyl craue.

2.71: [Bede's Tale of Jumna and Tumna; or, How an Abbot's Mass|singing made the Fetters fall off a Knight in Prison.] what tyme seynt Bede was man lyuand, were many kyngës yn þys land; Betwyxë tweyn was grete batayle, For whych þyng y telle þys merueyle; þe toon hyght Edfryde of þe norþe cuntre, þe toþer of Lyndëseye was he: Edfryde had grete seygnourye, seynurrye. Many vságes yn many ledys; For euery kyng, yn þat dawe, Beleued on dyuers lawe; Sum were crystyn, on oure fay, And some beleued on paynyms lay; Þarfore þat tyme was mykyl þro, And ofte was boþë werre and wo; &YOGH;yf any kyng my&yogh;t of oþers men take, He shuld hem selle, or yn seruage make.
2.76: wharfore y telle so of þys kny&yogh;t, þe erle dyd hym bynde euery ny&yogh;t þat he ne shuld[ë] fro hem fle, Ne stele awey to hys cuntre; Noþeles, Noþeles O, Noþele H. for alle þat þey my&yogh;t hym bynde, A-noþer tyme, lose, þey my&yogh;t hym fynde; Só fast, þey neuer neuer þey. hym bonde, Þat lose a-noþer tyme þey hym fonde.
2.77: Þys boundë kny&yogh;t hyght Iumna, And had a broþer þat hy&yogh;t Tumna; þys Tumna was prest relygyous, For he was abbot of an house; So long he leued yn þat estre toune Oxf. gloss 'a toune.' Þat for hys name he hy&yogh;t Tuncestre; Þat tounne, as y vndyrstande, hyt was yn Northhumber-lande.
2.78: þys abbot herd tydyng certeyn Þat Iumna was yn batayle slayn; He come to Trent, þys abbot Tumna, And fonde a body ry&yogh;t lyke Iumna; Onóurablye he dyd hyt graue Yn hys cherche, þere he wulde hyt haue, And song þarforë, day and ouþer, For he went he wende hyt (but he is used for the neuter, see ll. 10586, 10786, &c.). had be hys broþer.
