2.80: Þo men þat had þys man yn holde, Þys wundyr to þe erle þey tolde; Þe erle had þer-of gretë wundyr
2.81: Þat hys bondes bondes O, landes H. were so a sunder, He seyd 'hym self wulde with hym speke, To wytë why hys bondes dyd breke.'
2.82: Before þe erlë was he fette, And þe erle, ful feyre he grette, "Sey me now," he seyd, "bele amye, "kanst þou weyl on sorcerye? Sum wycchecrafte þou doust aboute bere, aboute þou doust bere. Þat þy bondes mow þe nat dere. For soþe," he seyd, "sum what þou dos, Þat euer-more þey fynde þe los."
2.83: he seyd, "on whycchecrafte beleue y no&yogh;t, Ne for me shal none be wro&yogh;t, Ne wyl nat be, be O, om . H. þurgh fendys crafte, Vnbonde, ne with no whycchëcrafte. Syre erle," he seyd, "hyt ys a-nouþer; Yn my cuntre y haue a broþer Þat supposyþ weyl þat y am be. slayn, For y come nat home agayn; For me he syngeþ euery day a messe; Prest, and abbot, for soþe he ys; Y wote weyl, þát ys þe enchesun Þat my bondes are so ondoun, For, no þyng haþ powere A&yogh;ens þe sacrement of þe autere; And &yogh;yf y were dede dede O, de H. yn ouþer werlde, hys preyer shulde for me be herde, To bryngë me of pyne and wo And aftyrward to blys[së] go."
2.84: Alle þe meyne þan, and þe erle, Supposed weyl he was no cherle, As he to hem byfore hadde seyd, whan þey on hym fyrst handës leyd; By hys semblant and feyre beryng Hym semed weyl to be a lordyng; By hys speche, þey vndyrstode Þat he was man of gentyl blode.
2.85: Þe erle toke hym yn pryuyte; Of when wenne. he was, telle hym shulde he; "Sey me þe soþe, and, as y am kny&yogh;t, Þou ne shalt haue for me haue. for me, skaþe ne ply&yogh;t." "Syn &yogh;e me behete &yogh;oure pes and gryth, Y am þe kyngës man Edfryth; Armës y bare yn þe batayle, with alle my powere hym to auayle." "So me þo&yogh;t," seyd þe erle, "Þe semed nat to be a cherle; But, for þát y here þe seye, Þou were wurþy for to deye, For þou hylpë þer to slo, Þat alle my kyn ys dede me fro; But, langer þat y sykerd þe, Shalt þou haue no skaþe for me."
2.86: He &yogh;ede and solde hym for raunsoun At London to a Frysoun,— A Frysoun &yogh;e shul vndyrstande To a marchaunde of Fryslande;— Þys Frysun wulde þys man furþe lede, And, dyd on hym bondes for drede; For he ne shulde skape eschape. by þe weye, He dyd on hym, bondes for to leye; He dede bondes on hym to leye. But hyt auayled hym no þyng Neuer a day, þat byndyng; For yn þat oure þat þe messe was sunge, Þe bondes to-braste, and alle to-sprunge.
2.87: Þys Frysoun þo&yogh;t 'how may þys be? hé may ry&yogh;t weyl fro me fle; Chaunsfullyche hyt vayled no&yogh;t, þe katel þat y wyþ hym hym wyþ. bo&yogh;t.'
2.88: þe Frysoun seyd, "wylt þou weyl Restore a&yogh;en alle my katel, And y shal &yogh;yue þe leue to go To þy cuntre, þere þou come fro; But fyrst þou shalt me trouþë plyght, And trewly holde hyt at alle þy my&yogh;t, To brynge þe katel, and &yogh;yue for þe, And ellës y grauntë þe nat fre." he graunted hym alle þat he seyd, And trouþe yn hande with hand[ë] leyd.
2.89: þys Iumna went to þe kyng Loyre, þat was kyng of Kaunterbyre; he was seynt Audre syster sone, And Iumna was wonte with here to wone; Of alle hys state, boþe wo and wele, Iumna tolde þe kyng euery deyl; Þe kyng þan &yogh;aue hym hys raunsoun, And he bare hyt to Londoun to þe Frysoun.
2.90: Syþen &yogh;ede he home, þys kny&yogh;t Iumna, To hys broþer þe abbot Tumna, And tolde hym of alle hys wo-fare, And of alle hys cumforte yn alle hys care. Þe abbot ful weyl þan vndyrstode Þat hys messe dyd hym grete gode, And þat þe sacrament gan hym borowe Oute of seruage and out of sorowe.
2.91: Þys tale telleþ vs seynt Bede, Yn þe gestys of Inglond þat we rede.
2.92: By þys talë, mow men lere Þat þe messe helpeþ vs weyl here; For vs lyuyng, hyt makeþ memórye, As weyl as for soules yn purgatórye; Euery man shal beleue þat ry&yogh;t, Þat holpe wyl be, as was þe kny&yogh;t.
2.93: Þys sacrament helpeþ nat &yogh;yt a-lone, But deuoute offrynges also echone; Alle þat we offre at þe messe, Alle oure saluacyun hyt ys; Nat onely for to saue þo þat dede beþ, But þe quyke also hyt saueþ hyt saueth also. and redeþ; As weyl haue þe quyke, þe pru, As þe dede, þereof vertu; Quyke and dedë, more and lesse, Alle are saued þurgh þe masse.
2.94: þe offryng ys also a present þat hyt be oure helpe, þe sacrament, To þe fadyr of heuene bysyly, For whom þou offrest, to haue mercy.
2.95: A tale y fondë onës wryte; And as y wote, þan shul &yogh;e wyte; A tale And weyl a-cordeþ yn alle þyng, Þat God ys payd of gode offryng.
2.96: [The Tale of the Miner, and how his Wife's Offerings for his Soul fed him while he was buried alive in a Mine.] Þyr was a man be&yogh;unde þe see, A mynour, woned yn a cyte,— Mynurs, þey make yn hyllys holes, As yn þe west cuntre men seke coles.—
2.97: Þys mynur so&yogh;te stones vndyr þe molde, Þat men make of, syluer and golde; he wro&yogh;t on a day, and holed yn þe hyl; A perylous chauncë to vnto. hym fyl; For, a grete party of þat yche myne Fyl dowun yn þe hole, and closed hym ynne.
2.98: hys felaus alle, þat were hym hende, Þat he were dede, weyl soþely wende; Þey &yogh;ede and toke hem alle to rede, And tolde hys wyfe þat he was dede.
2.99: Þys womman pleyned here husbonde sore— wulde God þat many swyche swyche many. wommen wore!— She hylpe hys soule yn allë þyng, In almës dede, and yn offryng; She offred for hym to þe auter, Ful of wynë, a pecher, And a feyrë lofe with-alle, Euery day as for a pryncypalle; Alle þat twelue moneþ stabëly, But o day þat passed forby.
2.100: Fewe swyche wymmen now we fynde, Þat to here husbondes are so kynde! But þys wyfe, at alle here my&yogh;t, Ded for hym boþe day and ny&yogh;t.
2.101: Fyl hyt at þe twelue moneþ ende, Hys felaws to þe mounteyne gun wende, And comë to þe same stede efte, Þere þey last here werk [i-]lefte. Ry&yogh;t þere, þey fyrst bygan, And perced þurgh vn-to þys man.
2.102: Þe man yn godë state þey fonde, lyuyng with-outë wem or wounde; Euerychone, þey hadde grete ferly, And þat was gretë resun why; Alle þo men were yn grete were, How he had lyued alle þat &yogh;ere. But he tolde hem euerychone How he hadde lyued þere alone; "Y haue lyued gracyous lyfe, Þurgh þe curtesye of my wyfe, For euery day she haþ me sent Brede and wynë to present; But o day certys ete y no&yogh;t, For, no mete was to me bro&yogh;t."
2.103: Þey led ledde. þys man vnto þe tounne, And tolde þys myracle vp and dounne, Fyrst, þur[o]gh þe cyte, And seþþë seþþe O, seþ H. þur[o]gh þe cuntre. Þey asked hym, at þe laste, Þat day þat he dyd[ë] faste; He tolde hem þe day[ë]s name, And hys wyfë seyd þe same; Þat day she offred neuer a deyl; Þe gode fryday, he my&yogh;t be weyl.
2.104: Now mow &yogh;e here, þat almës dede, Gostëly a man wyl fede, And so mow &yogh;e weyl vndyrstande Þat God ys payd of gode offrande.
2.105: But fór alle þys tale, yn &yogh;oure lyues, note . Truste &yogh;e nat moche ón &yogh;oure wyues, Ne on &yogh;oure chyldryn, for no þyng, But makeþ &yogh;e self, &yogh;oure offryng: For, so kynde a womman as y of tolde, lyueþ nat now, be þou bolde; Ne no clerk, þat þys þys O, om . H. ryme redys, Shal fynde a womman of so kynde dedes.'
2.106: &YOGH;e men þat are now yn present, þat haue herd me rede þys sacrament, how ouer alle þyng hyt haþ powere, Þe sacrament of þe autere, As y haue here to &yogh;ow shewed —Nat to lered onely, but eke to lewed,— &YOGH;e lewed men, y telle hyt &yogh;ow, Þese clerkys kun kunne. hyt weyl y-now, Pray we Preye we now. alle oure creatoure, creatour O, creature H. Þe sacrament oure sauyoure, sauueour. Þat body and soule he wyl vs saue, And we hym loue, and he vs haue! The Vernon MS. borrowing ends here.

3.1: The fourþe sacráment ys penaunce, Þat ys for synnë a quytaunce; God graunte vs alle, penaunce to do, For we haue gretë nede þarto.
3.2: A&yogh;ens þys, þan, synnë þo Þat to shryftë onely go with-oute any manér of smert Of felyng, of sorowe of hert; Euery man shulde haue a-fore þo&yogh;t How and whan hys synne was wro&yogh;t, And beþenke hym weyl on of. euery dede, Fyrst are he to shryftë &yogh;ede; Elles, asoyled may he nat be clene, Of for&yogh;etë synnes, y mene. Ouer lytyl fors certys he &yogh;yueþ Of any penaunce, or how he lyueþ; Swychë men, here synne þey synke, þat recchë nat þer-on to þynke. Some men, whan here synne ys wro&yogh;t, Hyt no more more eft. cumþ yn here þo&yogh;t, And &yogh;yueþ no fors, force. þat he for&yogh;eteþ hys synne; and hym þe fend eteþ. leuer ys hym late hem alle weyue, þan any hard penaunce receyue.
3.3: &YOGH;yf þou wylt haue þe sacrament, Þe behoueþ &yogh;yue weyl bettyr entent, And recordë euery dede with sorow of herte, and with drede, And forþynke, with mochë mone, Þat þou ne mayst þenk on echone; And &yogh;yf þou shryue þe euery deyl Of þo, þat þe meneþ weyl, Þat þou ne lettë for no shame To tellë opunly þy blame: Swyche a man þat þus ys shryue, May be asoyled, and penaunce &yogh;yue.
3.4: penaunce may be &yogh;yue to none But he shryue hys synnes echone, And be of godë répentaunce; No prest may elles &yogh;yue hym penaunce; Penaunce pyneþ þy flessh and 'and' omitted. þe fende, And plesyþ God, and makyþ hym frende. Aftyr, &yogh;yf þou þenk on þat Synne þat þou yn shryfte for&yogh;at, Þou art holde to telle hyt þy prest whan þou hast mynde þer-of yn brest.
3.5: whan þou hast þy synne forsake, And þy penaunce þer-forë take, For&yogh;ete nat þan þat þou ne do Þe penaunce þat he he O, om . H. ioyneþ þe to. &YOGH;yf þou for&yogh;etest, þou shalt bey bye. hyt harde yn purgatórye aftyrwarde; For o day þat þou for&yogh;etest here, A &yogh;ere, þere þere O, om . H. þou shalt by hyt dere.
3.6: And &yogh;yf þou fallest eft yn synne, Efte þy shryfte alle newe bygynne, And do gode dedës þer-with-alle, For þat es ys. of penaunce pryncypalle; &YOGH;yf þou ne do, verrement Þou synnest yn þys sacrament; For of þat man, hyt ys grete drede, Þat wyþdraghþ hym fro godë dede.
3.7: Many man also þenkeþ þys þo&yogh;t, 'þat werk of penaunce auayleþ no&yogh;t þe whylys þat he ys yn synne;' But þan had he most nede to bygynne; For godë dedës and penaunce Reysyn a man to répentaunce; For many þyngës, gode hyt ys, Þogh hyt auayle hym naght yn blys.
3.8: þe prest wote neuer what he menes, Þat for lytyl, curseþ hys parysshenes; Þat yche shepard &yogh;yueþ no gode kepe, Þat betecheþ þe wulfe hys shepe; At þe last acounte shal he mysfalle, whan he shal answere for hem alle; And þe lordë shal þe shepard hate, þat wasteþ hys store, and bryngeþ o gate; Þe lordë bo&yogh;t þe shepe ful dere, lese hem nat þan nat þan O, no&yogh;t H. so ly&yogh;tly here; Þo&yogh; þey outrage, and do foly, He shal nat sle hem with felony; he shal hem chastyse with smert lewede. speche, with small baytynges, and nat with wreche.
3.9: As þe gode shepard kepyþ hys shepe, So shalle þe prest, hys parysshenes kepe; Þere shepe gone wrong besyde þe paþ, Þe shepard cryeþ for drede of skaþe; And &yogh;yf þey wyl nat at hys crye Turne a&yogh;en to here pasture nye, Þan setteþ he on hys hounde, And bayteþ hem a wel gode stounde, And bryngeþ hem to her pasture weyl, Ne sleþ he &yogh;yt none, neuer a deyl.
3.10: with þese prestes hyt shulde fare so, whan here parysshenes oghte mysdo; wyþ feyre techyng, and godë spelles, And stoutly, whan þey wyl nat elles, And with ordynaryys of holy cherche, Tyl þat þey wyl ry&yogh;tly werche; Nat with cursyng, þat es ys. slaghter euyl, So sone betake hem to þe deuyl. Haue to hem swych charyte As þou wuldest God hadde to þe; kowardyse hyt ys, and foule maystry, To þrowe a faucoun at euery flye; Of flyes men mow hem weyl spourge, And þrowe to hem naght but a scourge; No more shal no prest þrawe, But a scorge, þat ys loue þat ys loue. awe.
3.11: Lewed man, þou shalt cursyng doute, And to 'to' omitted. þy prest þou shalt nat stoute; Be he wykked, or be he gode, Þou shalt to hym be þolëmode.
3.12: Hyt ys nat a lytyl þyng For to fallë yn cursyng, For hyt reueþ þe þy gostly frendes, And betecheþ þe vn-to þe fendes, And hyt forbarreþ alle gode dedes Þat þe shuld helpe yn alle þy nedes, Tyl þou com to amendëment with penaunce, þat ys, þys sacrament.
3.13: Yn sacrylage, y tolde a tale how cursyng breweþ mochë bale, Þat alle þe &yogh;ere hopped aboute, Þat wulde nat þe prestys byddyng doute.
3.14: Now wyl we leuë, at þys þys O, þs H. tyme, Of penaunce morë for to ryme, For y shal tellë þer-of more At shryftë, whan y comë þore; God &yogh;yue me gracë so to telle, To shamë alle þe fendes of helle!

4.1: NOw of þe fyfþë sacrament, Þe order of þe bysshopes presentement. þys falleþ to þese lordynges, As popës, emperoures, and kynges, And to alle þat clerkys auaunce To holy cherches portynaunce; purtynaunce. Swyche men, þat are of grete nobley, Yn þys sacrament þan synne þey, Þat þey graunte, for mede þat þey take, Vnwurþyly, a bysshope to make, Of whom þat ys þe famë ryfe Þat he ys, of febyl lyfe, Or oþer to auaunce, hyt ys folye, wyþoutyn resonable clergye.
4.2: Clerk behoueþ behouede. hym for to be, Þat shulde receyue swyche dygnyte For to gouerne holy cherche; with clergy, behoueþ hym algate werche. But now ys fulfylled þe prophecye Þat, sorë wepyng, seyþ Isaye, "Ry&yogh;t swych shal be þe prest [6 syllables ] As þe lewed man lyue, þou sest."
4.3: lytyl kan lasse þe lewed man þan some of þesë prestës kan. who &yogh;yuen hem more to worldly þyng þan prestës do, for alle here prechyng?
4.4: &yogh;yf he be clerk, and euyl dous, Of hym ys nat to make no rous. what vayleþ to vndyrstonde þe lettyr, And hys lyfe be neuer þe bettyr? Alle þat clergye, y telle it but lore, when he lyueþ neuer þe bettyr þer-fore.
4.5: But how seyþ Salamon yn hys spellyng, "wo þe land, þere chylde ys kyng!" And wo þe folk, þat kan nat lyue whan holy cherchë ys mys-&yogh;yue! And to þe husbonde, wo ys ys H, om . O. hys lyfe, þat haþ yn hys 'hys' omitted. hous a fole to wyfe!
4.6: &yogh;e lordes, do &yogh;e Goddes ordynaunce, And godë men &yogh;e shul auaunce; To gode men &yogh;yueþ &yogh;oure benefyces Þat kun hem kepe fro wykked vyces; Þan make &yogh;e gode presentëment To order of þys sacrament.
4.7: Also, haþ he wykkedly doun Þat letteþ gode mannes eleccyoun; 'Eleccyoun' ys, 'weyl chesyng A gode man to kepe holy þyng.' Þese hyghë men do grete trespas, Þat chese nat ry&yogh;t, alas! alas! Þát were wurþy, hem þey spare, And þe vnwurþy auaunced are; And, þat ys nat lytyl synne To hem þat hyt &yogh;yuen, and eke so wynne; Hyt may be tolde for symonye, For &yogh;yfte to auaunce þe vnwurþy.
4.8: By a tale, y may &yogh;ow shewe þat hyt ys synne to chese a shrewe; And &yogh;yt ys he yn wers entent, þat letteþ gode mannes auauncëment.
4.9: Seynt Gregory telleþ þarfore a tale A tale. þat telþ many one, what grete and smale, he telleþ mo hymself a-lone, þan alle þe doctours do echone.
4.10: [The Tale of Paschasius's Punish|ment for not agreeing to the Election of the best Man for Pope.] Yn þe cherche of Rome, he telleþ þus, A dekene was þat hyghte Pascasyus, A man of almës þan was he, Þat ofte of þe porë had pyte; Þat yche tyme was elleccyone To chese here pope, as er ere. was wone.
4.11: Twey men were yn choys to take, Oþer Laurence, oþer or. Symake; hys felaus alle, Symakus chese, So þat Laurence hys voys lese; Pascasyus graunted neuer þartyl, But chese Laurence at hys owne wyl; He repented hym neuer no&yogh;t, But yn Laurencë stode hys þo&yogh;t.
4.12: Yn þys popes tyme, syre Symakus, Deyde þe dekene Pascasyus: Þys dekene was an holy man, As yn þe cuntre þe famë ran, And dyd þys myrácle, as &yogh;e mowe may. here: A wode man touched on hys bere, And a party of hys cloþyng, And a-none he hadde botenyng.
4.13: longë, aftyr þat þys was, Fyl of þys dekene a merueylous kas; For þere besydë, yn a paþ was a wasshyng, at an hote baþ; 'Termes' men calle þat watyr wasshele, For many one had þerat here hele.
4.14: Þus þe holy bysshope seynt Germyne Com þedyr to be wasshe þer-ynne; Þere fonde he þys dekene Pascas, And at þe þat. watyr seruyng was: Þys bysshope merueyled yn hys þo&yogh;t, wheþer hyt were Pascas or no&yogh;t; At þe laste, seynt Germyne seyde "Art þou nat Pascas þat deyde, Þat we helde a man holy?" "&YOGH;ys," seyd Pascas, "hyt am y; And at þys water, serue y þus, For y graunted neuer nat. to Symakus, But to Laurence, with alle my my&yogh;t, Þat was nat so gode yn Goddys sy&yogh;t; y ne repented yn alle my hope, nat in al myn hope. For y wulde haue hadde hym pope. But wuldest þou prey for me, Germyne, y shulde come sone oute of þys pyne; And þat þat O, om . H. mayst þou wete yn þys manere, &YOGH;yf þou fynde me no more here."
4.15: Þe bysshope Germyne, home he &yogh;ede, And preyd to God for hys mysdede. Þe nextë tyme þat he come þore, Of Pascas, sagh he no more.
4.16: Lokë, Lokeþ. lordes, how &yogh;e mysdo, Þat eleccyoun dystroubleþ dystourbleþ. so; For a &yogh;yfte, or a presént, &YOGH;e suffre holy cherche to to H, om . O. be shent; &YOGH;ourë synnë shal be greuous, whan þys dekene Pascasyus, For so lytyl, to purgatorye &yogh;ede, For whom was shewed myrácle yn dede.
4.17: A&yogh;ens God, he ys nat quyte, Þat suffreþ for hys owne profyte, Holy cherche, wrongly be &yogh;yue To þo men þat wykkedly lyue; Þey shul be a-couped of tresoun, As traytours yn eleccyoun; Many shul go a deuyl wey, Or be encumbred or ar. þey dey.
4.18: &YOGH;yt shal y telle, among þese talys, A tale þat now late fyl yn Wales: yn þe tyme of seynt Dauy Fyl þys þyng, a grete ferly.
4.19: [A Tale of Warning against buying Bishoprics, and worshipping Bad Bishops' Bodies.] As þe munkës shulde do werche werk þat fyl vn-to here cherche, As þey dalue dowun yn þe clay, Þey fonde a bysshope alle hole lay, with flesshe and blode, and hole sendal, And, wyþ ouþer vestement alle, As fresshë as he were depeynt. þey wende he had be a corseynt; þey toke hym vp, euerychone, And, leyd hym vppon a stone, a tumbe of stone. And wurscheped hyt moche with-alle, For þey wende myrácles shulde falle. At hygh feste tymës of þe &yogh;ere Þey ensensed þe body as as H O,? for 'at.' þe hygh autere.
4.20: A ny&yogh;t, whan þe sekesteyn yn bede was leyd, Hym þo&yogh;t one come, and to hym seyd, "Ensense þe body no more so, Ne do no wurschep þar-vnto."
4.21: Þe sekesteyn, for alle þat defense, &YOGH;yt he &yogh;aue þe body ensense. Anouþer ny&yogh;t, fór þat same, Efte þe sekesteyn he gan blame, and seyd, "holde hyt no more yn prys, þat yche body, þat þere lys." þe munkë seyd, "telle me why þat he to wurschep to be wrshepede. ne ys wurþy." "loke to morne, and þou mayst wyte what lyþ yn hys mytyr wryte."
4.22: þe munkë ros vp on þe morne, And, fonde yn hys mytyr horne Þesë verse wryte on a scrowe, For þat he shulde þe bettyr trowe: Þese are þo ychë twey verse, Þat to holynes are reuers, Quem lapis ille tegit, sandalia viliter emit; Estuat in baratro, pessimus ille latro . "he þat þys stone hyleþ one on. lyche, wykkedly bo&yogh;t hys bysshopryche. yn helle he welleþ pynë yn pyne. grefe, For alþerwerst alþerwest. þan was he þefe."
4.23: Alþerwerst alþerwest. þen shal hem be, Þat for mede come to dygnyte. hyt ys nat to speke, ne to 'to' omitted. preche, Þe clergye werche wercheþ. moche aftyr wreche.
4.24: Ne þou shalt no dedë werche, Noþer to iangle, yn holy cherche; Namely yn tyme of holy feste, Þán shuldë men iangle leste. Þat tyme make many one, gaderyng yn holy cherche of ydul þyng; And of alle shalt þou &yogh;elde acounte, To whos godenesse hyt shuld amounte. y haue touched of þys swych. outrage whan y spake of sacrylage. [p. 292]
4.25: Ne þou oghtes oghtest. nat to be enchesun To sturble mannys deuocyoun. &YOGH;yf þou ne wylte Goddes seruyse here, lette none ouþer of here preyere; Fole ys, þat foly þat 'þat' omitted. wyl nat drede, And more þat letteþ alle oþer gode dede. Ry&yogh;t so so O, om . H. seyþ Salamon þe wyse, Vs alle of foly to for to. chastyse.
4.26: Clerk to bete, or handes on ley yn vyolence, hyt ys grete eye; Hyt longeþ to þys sacrament Þurgh bysshopës commaundëment; yn sacrylagë þer y spake, [p. 280] y touched of þat ychë lak; And yn þe ten commaundëmens, [p. 72, 77] y wene y touched of þys defens; Þarforë, now hyt ys beste, Of þys sacrament to reste.
4.27: God grauntë þesë lordynges, weyl to do yn allë þynges, And late hem neuer here soulës lese For no wrongës no wrons O, wronges H. þat þey chese!

5.1: The syxte sacrament ys matrymony, Þére hyt ys do ry&yogh;twusly; God comaundeþ yn hys boke Þat man shuldë hyt weyl loke; For he stabled hyt yn paradys, hyt ys holde yn þe morë prys; And yn Kana kana of. Galyle He turnede water yn wyne to be.
5.2: A&yogh;ens þys ychë sacrament Do many onë verrement; yn þys, do þo men ful ylle, Þat wedden any a&yogh;ens here wylle; Here wyl behoueþ to-gedyr consente, Are þe prest do þe sacrament.
5.3: Ne þou ne shalt [not] do þy my&yogh;t þat two be weddyd with vnry&yogh;t. Synne þou wystest þat þey shulde no&yogh;t with no skyl togedyr be bro&yogh;t, Þou synnest moche þurgh þys resun, For þey mow neuer be weyl vndoun.
5.4: Ne þou shalt nat, for no gode— þo&yogh;t Þogh. hyt be þyn ownë blode— Dysturble hyt þere hyt o&yogh;t to be, &YOGH;yf þey haue do hére wyl fre.
5.5: &YOGH;yf þou wost þe soþe of euery deyl, Þat two are weddyd, and o&yogh;t nat weyl, But þou shewe hyt, þou dost grete synne To one þat may do bote þer-ynne; For, þus ys þe gospel sawe, And þe same seyþ seyþ þe. landës lawe, 'Þat who so consenteþ to a þefe, Euene peyne shul þey þey shul. haue grefe.'
5.6: Of foly trouþës þat are &yogh;yue, Þare-of byfore y haue &yogh;ow shryue; Y haue tolde hyt as y couþe, How men falsen here trouþes with mouþe; whan y spake of lecherye, [p. 234] Y spakë þer of þat foly, And yn þe syxtë commaundment [p. 58] Þere spekþ hyt of þys asent; Þarfore nedeþ me nat here To spekë more of þys matere; But, y pray euery man þat hys crystendom loueþ, or kan, Þat þey neuer swych þyng graunte, Two to wedde of fals cunnaunte; For many come neuer yn wedlak But for þe fyrst cunnaunt þat men spak.
5.7: Also, for men by-hete hem largely, Are chyldryn wedded ofte for-þy; For þyr are many wedded for gode, And for no stedfast loue of blode, And, þat ys no no O, þe H. ry&yogh;t weddyng; Hyt quemeþ nat to heuene kyng. Many one weddeþ euery deyl For þe loue of syre kateyl; whan hyt ys go, and ys alle bare, þan ys þe weddyng sorowe & kare; loue ande catel þan ys awey, And 'welaweye' þey cry and sey.
5.8: And &yogh;e men þat brekyn cunnaunte, &YOGH;e selfe falsen þat &yogh;e fyrst graunte; Þan ys weddelak þurgh &yogh;ow shent, Þat was þe fyrst sacrament; &YOGH;e shende hyt wyþ &yogh;oure fals behetyng, And þey no&yogh;t weddë but þe þyng; So, betwyxe fals and coueytous, ys welaweyë bro&yogh;t to hous. Of þys my&yogh;t men mochë speke, But leuer ys me my mouþe to steke Þan y spak o&yogh;t oute of skore, For sone y my&yogh;t be blamed þarfore. God &yogh;yue hem grace, þo þat shul wedde, Yn ry&yogh;t wedlak be bro&yogh;t to bedde; And delyuer hem of here wyues Þat oute of skyle chyden and stryues!

6.0: [Of the Seventh Sacrament,—Aneylyng or Extreme Unction.]
6.1: Now of þe seuenþe sacrament: Þese clerkys kalle hyt 'oynament,' On Englys hyt ys 'anelyng' whan man shal make hys endyng; Seynt Iamë stable[d] hyt for to be A sacrament þurgh crystyanyte.
6.2: &YOGH;yf þou aske hyt wyþ gode wyl, Of wykked gostes gest getest. þou noun yl, Ne þe fende haþ no powere þy body for to comë nere. &YOGH;yf þou of dedly synne be shryue, þo þat are venyal beþ þe for&yogh;yue; þou mayst þan sykerly go þy weye, what tyme as euer þat þou shalt deye.
6.3: &YOGH;e þat loue þys sacrament, Here mowe &yogh;e lerne, &yogh;yueþ gode entent. Þat tymë þat Þou trowest þat. þou shalt wende, And draghest vn-to þy lyuës ende, Þou shalt aske deuoutëly Anelyng to þy body; Þo&yogh;t Þogh. hyt be bro&yogh;t redy to þe, Asked behoueþ hyt algate be.
6.4: &YOGH;yf þou vnwetyng hyt haue, hyt helpeþ þe nat so moche to saue As &yogh;yf þou asked askedest. hyt by name; Þus seyþ þe apostle seynt Iame; For whan þou askest hyt with gode wyl, Þou mekyst þe þan to fulfyl Þe sacramentes of holy cherche with beleue, and gostely to werche; Þan ys holy cherche holde þurgh ry&yogh;t To pray for þe boþe day and ny&yogh;t.
6.5: Hyt ys to be holde yn prys, yn gret prys. For hyt saueþ man on twey partys; Þe soule hyt bryngeþ to saluacyoun, And for hele of body hyt ys doun.
6.6: But many one þus hope and seye, 'Anele hem nat but þey shulde deye; For &yogh;yf he turne a&yogh;en to lyfe, He shulde lygge no more no more lygge. by hys wyfe.' Al þo þat beleueþ þys, wykkedly þey beleue beleueþ. a-mys. Holy cherche makeþ no menyng, For swyche þyng defende anelyng; But yn euery an euyl strong— lygge þou shortë whyle or long— Þou shalt aske þys sacrament, with gode wyl and gode entent, Syn hyt auayleþ but lyghtly But hyt be asked derwurly. derwrþely.
6.7: Þy gode wyl shal stonde for oght, &YOGH;yf þou hyt aske, and haue hyt no&yogh;t; For some are now a-lyue þou seest, And dede are he may haue þe preste; Þarfore, askë hyt be tyme, For, deþ cumþ now as yn swyme; yn euery sykenes, aske hyt al-weys; God almy&yogh;ty ys ry&yogh;t curteys, he seeþ þy wyl, what þou wuldest wst. haue, Hys mercy ys þe more þe to saue.
6.8: Ihesu, y þanke þe of þy grace, Þat hast lent me me lent. wyt and space, Þys yn Englys for to drawe, As holy men haue seyd yn sawe; For lewed men hyt may auayle, For hem y tokë þys trauayle.
6.9: Of þys sacrament wyl y blynne; Of shryfte, to telle, y wyl bygynne; God &yogh;yue me gracë so to seye, Of shryfte to shewë þe ry&yogh;t weye, shewe ryghtly weye. Þat we receyue, are we be went, with-outë synne, þys sacrament.

0.1: The ly&yogh;t of grace þat neuer haþ ende, From whom al cumþ, and to al men sende; Of alle godenes, wel and bygynnyng Ys God of heuene, and of erþe kyng, Hym wurschepeþ alle, as wel ys wurþy, Gostly þynges as weyl as dedly, Alle creatures doun hym onoure, Ihesu, þat ryche emperoure; Þou, Ihesu, ly&yogh;t my soule with-ynne, And graunte me swychë to bygynne Þat hyt mowe be, þe to queme, And vs alle fro synnë &yogh;eme! Namly, of shryftë so now. to seye, Þat we mow make vs redy wey A&yogh;ens þe fende, þat ys oure fo, Þarto God graunte vs alle to go.
0.2: See French, 1. 9605, p.351, note e . Tweluë poyntes þyr are yn shryfte, And tweluë graces of here &yogh;yfte, And yn alle þesë, are but þre whych are to do, and whych are to fle.
0.3: To telle hyt shortly, alle al. at gesse, Þe fyrst ys þe grete godënesse, How yt &yogh;yueþ hem grace to þryue, Þo men þat wyl bleþely hem shryue; Syþen, fro what þyng men shulde hem loke Þat shryftë blely vndyrtoke; And how many þynges, behoueþ hem haue, Þat, ry&yogh;tly, here shryfte wyl craue.
0.4: Yn tokenyng, to holde vs lowe, And oure wykkednes for to knowe, Hyt ys ordeyned, þurgh Goddys &yogh;yfte, To man, fór to knowe oure shryfte.
0.5: For vnbuxumnesse of oure fadyr Adam And Eue—þurgh prydë þat fyrst cam, Þat Goddes commaundëment þey brake— knowlachyng behoueþ vs allë make; And þurgh a-nother resun ry&yogh;t gode, Syn Ihesu Cryst toke flesshe and blode, And was cloþed yn oure man-hede, And wyst oure wykkednes & oure nede, To man behoueþ vs to telle oure trespas, Syn he knew alle þat yn man was. For whan we shryue vs to þe preste, To God we shewe vs yn mannes mannes O, goddes H. breste; Þan wotë boþë God and man, Oure lyfe, þat alle may wete wyte. and kan; Now we shul, telle &yogh;ow sone, what ys to leue, and what to done.

1.1: The fyrste poynt of shryfte. Þe fyrst poynt of þy shryfte oweþ to be, 'with þy gode wyl and hertë fre, whan þou art yn þy lyfë best, Awey þou shalt þy synnë kest;' For þan wurschepest þou God aboue, And forsakest þy synne for hys loue. Dauyd seyþ, yn wurde to fulfyl, God shrofe hym with hys hys O, om . H. gode wyl; Abyde nat tyl þou most nedly, For þan hyt ys with fors and maystry; Þou shryuest þe þan for drede, Nat for loue, but more for nede; Þan semeþ hyt þat hyt shulde be Þat þy synne forsakeþ þe. Swyche shryftë made Acor þe þefe: whan he shulde go to pynë grefe, He shrof hys synne, how he hadde stole Þre þyngës þat he hade forhole, A mantle of skarlet, a rolle of golde, And syluer, he hydde vndyr molde; Yn þe byble men mow hyt se, Yn þe story of Iosue.
1.2: The Secunde poynt of shryfte. þe secunde poynt ys next þyr-by, 'þat þou shalt shryue þe hastyly;' For whan þou doust dost hyt. yn longe respyte, hyt ys for&yogh;ete, þat long ys olyte. Seynt Bernard þarfore, to swych chyt, And seyþ 'moche for&yogh;yt, þat longe abyt.' Anouþer skyl ys, þat þou shalt hyt haste, For yn þy synne þy lyfe ys waste; For, as moche as þe tyme doþ amounte, For euery oure, shalt þou &yogh;elde acounte, &YOGH;yf hyt so were, þou my&yogh;test had space, And wuldest nat come to shryfte ne grace. &YOGH;yt, þyr ys þe þred resun See French, l. 9719, &c. last page. þat hastyly shal þy shryfte be doun; For yn þat tyme þat þy synne synne O, shryfte H. ys, Þou art departed fro heuene blys, And fro alle þe felawrede Þat shulde þe helpë at þy nede, And fro þe preyers of holy cherche, And fro alle gode dedes, þat men þer werche; Alle þe prayers, with-outë fayle, To þe blys of heuene, þe mow nat auayle. Algate y rede, þou do gode dede; To ryse fro synne, hyt wyl þe spede, And bettyr wyl hyt pay God almy&yogh;t, And þy penaunce shal be þe more ly&yogh;t, And, þe more grace shalt þou haue, Þe for to shryue and saue. [6 syll. ]
1.3: The þred poynt of shryfte. Þe þryd poynt of þy shryfte, 'Opunly þyn herte vp lyfte:' So byt God to me and þe, Þat opunly shal þy shryftë be. Salamon to vs seyþ, and seyþ & to us. kalleþ, 'Seuene tymes on a day þe ry&yogh;twys man falleþ;' As oftë þan behoueþ þe ryse, &YOGH;yf þou lyue yn ry&yogh;t seruyse. Þus seyþ þe clerke seynt Austyne, Þat was a mayster of dyuyne, deuyn. '&YOGH;yf þou to many prestes atwynne, Al holyche wylt shryue þy synne, Þou shalt fynde grace and for&yogh;yuenes, And mede to þe, for þy mekenes.' Þre þyngës mayst þou fynde, Þat wyl þe oute of synnë bynde; Þe fyrst ys, þat þou mayst lere, And many dyuers samples sample. here, Of euery prest, a lessoun, To knowë þy saluacyoun; &YOGH;yf þou haue herde of many a-pryse, þe morë þou canst, of queyntyse. þe touþer me þenkeþ a gode resoun, Þat quyteþ þe fro dampnacyoun, þe ofter þat þou shewest þy blame, þe more me þenkeþ þou hast of shame; þe shame þat þou hast yn þy shewyng, hyt ys for&yogh;yuenes, to gode endyng. Þe þred, ys, þat þe weyl weres, Glossed 'kepeþ' in Oxf.; 'kepyþ' in Harl., by a later hand. For þou shalt be yn alle preyers Of alle þe prestes þat þe haue shryue, As longë tyme as euer þey lyue, For þey are holdë þar-vn-to; þe order of prest wyl hyt be so; þe mo prestës þat for þe prey, þe sunner soner. art þou yn gode wey; And, at þe day of Iugëment, To God þey shul make þy present, þat þou werë clenë shryue, And þat þey mow be þe for&yogh;yue. þo þat þou hast here hyd, þurgh alle þe werld þey shul be kyd, And askë domë on þe þere, þat þou, of hem, neuer shryuë were; For allë þyng þat euer &yogh;yt was, Shal þe acoupe of þy trespas; Þe synnë hymself shal forwreye; Þyn Inwyt, on þe self, þe dome shal leye.
1.4: þe fourþe poynt of shryfte. Þe fourþë poynt, ful feyre hyt ys, 'yn shryftë to haue mekënes.' She chese þat vertu, oure lady, So seyþ "magnificat," here owne storye, 'Þe gretë mekenes many folde Yn hys hand-mayden, God wlde beholde.' Syn mekenes ys so noble a &yogh;yfte, For-&yogh;ete For&yogh;eteþ. hyt nat yn &yogh;ourë shryfte. So spekeþ þe gospel of þys vertu, How a mesyl come to Ihesu with gode wyl, and on knees hym sette, And ful myldely, Ihesu he grette; "lorde," he seyd, "þou mayst me saue &YOGH;yf þou wylt, and y hele haue." Ihesu sagh hys myldënes, And seyd "y wyl hele, alle þy sykenes." He þat ys yn dedly synne, Gostely he ys a mesyl with-ynne; He þat wyl hys helë seke, To hys prest he mote be meke; &YOGH;yf þou meke þe to þy prest, Þou mekës mekest. þe to Goddës brest; &YOGH;yf þou be to hym ful stour, Þou doust to God grete dysonour; he sytteþ þere, yn Goddys se; To deme þy synne, he haþ pouste; &YOGH;yf he blame þe for þyn euyl, þat þou hast serued moche þe deuyl, Defendë nat þy folye, yn pryde ne yn ypocrysye; Noþer on þy self lye þou no&yogh;t, To seye þyng þat þou neuer wro&yogh;t; Ne forsake nat þy synne to wreye; More and þan. lesse, behoueþ þe seye.
1.5: þe fyueþe Þe fyfþe. poynt of shryfte. Go we now to þe fyfþe fyfþe O, fythe H. poynt: To þe þrydde hyt ys a ioynt, þere y spake of ofte shryuyng, To tellë many prestes a þyng. what men are þo þat shryue hem bleþly, But þo þat synne but ly&yogh;tly? For þo þat haue do synnës grete, Vnneþë Vnneþe O, Vnneþ H. wyl þey any lete. &YOGH;yf þey here any predycacyoun, Or sum ouþer chaunse be doun, &YOGH;yt wyl þey neuer shryue here shame, So are þey bounde yn þe fendës hame. And somë lette, for hard penaunce, For to telle here grete cumberaunce. And somë lette here synne to seye, For doute of prest, þat wyl hem bewreye: No shame my&yogh;t to mochë be To þe 'þe' omitted. prest þat telleþ telþ. þat pryuyte. letteþ nat, &yogh;oure synne to telle; Þenkeþ on þe peynes of helle; what day þat &yogh;e dyd &yogh;oure synne, And how long &yogh;e haue lyued þer-ynne, what tyme, ánd how, hyt was wro&yogh;t; Alle hyt nede nedeþ. þurghout be soghte. Seynt Dauyd, þe holy prophete, Seyþ, þese wurdes, ful swete, "Alle my shryftë and my shame Haþ so couerd and hyd my blame, þat þe fende may haue no sy&yogh;t, Me to bewreyë with no ply&yogh;t; Ne God of heuene wyl nat se Any þyng þat wyl dampnë me." &YOGH;yf þou shryue þe apertly, Þou mayst be sekyr to haue mercy.
1.6: The syxte poynt of shryfte. Þe syxte poynt ys, sorowe of herte; Þat oght to be bytter and smerte whan þou þenkest on þe gode dedes, þat, God haþ do for þy nedes, And þou hast do, as þou weyl wost, Þyng, þat, he hateþ moste. No creatures ne hateþ he no&yogh;t, But synnë þat ys do or wro&yogh;t; Ne he hateþ nat þe fende of helle, Þe crëature of hym y telle, But þe wykkednes, pryde and synne Þat yn hym ys, and wyl nat blynne; Ne was þyr neuer aungel so bry&yogh;t, Ne man so weyl with God almy&yogh;t, Þat, &yogh;yf he had synned dedly, To hellë pyne he was wurþy; Þat oght þey boþe to sorowe and kare, Þat yn dedly synnë are. God hym hym O, hym hym H. self, of mageste, Vnto hys lykenes he formed þe; he made þy soule boþe fayre and clene, And to hys ownë godhede sene; And whan þou synnest, þou turnest wyk, And makest þy soulë black as pyk; Þát God had made to hym so weyl, Þou makest hyt lyke þe fende echedeyl. Sorowe oghte þan, þyn hertë bynde, Þat þou art tó hym so vnkynde; Þou dysonourest hym yn þat outrage, And reuylyst hys feyre ymage. Of þys þyng þan &yogh;yuest &yogh;yfst. þou leste, whan þou cumst laghyng to þe prest; Euyl oghtest þou laghe, coudest þou se How þou bryngest þy dome with þe; Aboute þy nekke, hanggeþ a wyþþe, Þat haþ þe departed fro Goddys gryþþe: Þy self beryst þan, on þy bak, Þy vylë synne þat makeþ þe blak; May nonë fro þat dome þe borowe, But &yogh;yf hyt be with byttyr sorowe. Goddys treytour, and ry&yogh;t vyleyn! Hast þou no mynde of Marye Maudeleyn, How she so&yogh;t oure lorde Ihesus Yn Symundës hous leprous? Opone þyn herte, þy gostly eres, And þenke on herë byttyr teres! She cam nat laghyng to þe com . . . . to þat. feste, Noþer for game, noþer no. for geste; She com wepyng with here yne, Of Ihesu to haue medycyne; She bro&yogh;t a smel of grete sauour, Þat tokeneþ loue and grete onour; with here terës þat she lete, þarwyþ she wyssh Ihesu Ihū. fete: So behoueþ vs with here to grete, &YOGH;yf we, oure synne, wyl truly lete; And, but we haue sorowe for oure for oure O, with here H. synne, Þe mercy of God mow we nat wynne.
1.7: þe Þe O, Te H. seuenþe poynt of shryfte. The seuenþe poynt ys a gode resun, 'Þat þy shryfte be wysly doun,' Þat ys to sey, to a wys man, Þat þy shryfte vndyrstondë kan; Nat to one þat haþ no wyt Of vndyrstondyng of holy wryt. Seynt Austyn seyþ þys skyl, Do þyr-aftyr who so wyl, 'Of synnë, who so wyl hym lese, A wyse shryftfadyr behoueþ hym chese; And þat may byndë and vnbynde, Swych a man behoueþ hym fynde." A prest þat ys no clergye ynne, How can he weyl dystyncte þy synne? But now, oueralle, se we mowne An holywatyr clerk of a tounne, þat lytyl haþ lerned yn hys lyue, he ys ordeyned a prest to shryue. &YOGH;yf he shulde a shryfadyr shryftefader. be, hym behoueþ behouede. haue lerned of sum degre, Or lerned, or herde, of some þat couþe, Ar he had be prest yn hys &yogh;ouþe; And moche behoueþ behouede. hym stody and se, Or lerne at sum, yn pryuyte. he may lyue, as a gode man, Þoghe he lytyl clergy kan; But for to preche, or herë shryfte, Of clergy behoueþ hym sum þryfte. And allë prestes haue nat powere For to assoylë þe ry&yogh;t clere, But hyt be þy parysshe preste, Or haue hys leuë at þe leste, Or at þy parsone or vycary, For þese haue of þy soule maystry: Aske hem leue, and haue no gylt, And shryuë þe þan, where þou wylt.
1.8: The ey&yogh;tþe eyghteþe. poynt of shryfte. The eyghtþe poynt of þe twelue, 'Þy shryfte shal be alle of þy selue,' Of þyn ownë proper dede, And bewreye none ouþer, y þe forbede. Þyn ownë foly þou shalt seye, And none ouþer body bewreye. Dauyd seyþ yn þe sautere Þese wurdes, þurgh Goddys powere,— he spekeþ 2 as weyl to lerned as to lewed, 2 2_2 to lernede as weyl as lewede. — "Myn owne lyfe, lorde, y haue þe shewed; None ouþer mannes y wyl dyscrye, For þat were boþe synne and vyleynye." &YOGH;yue gode tent, to þys poynt, Þou prest þat art a-noynt! &YOGH;yf a man telle þe hys synne, And a-noþer be menged þer-ynne,— As &yogh;yf hyt were yn lecherye, Or hylp to sle, or robborye, For þese may nat a man weyl do Alone, but ouþer be þar-vnto,— Aske aftyr none ouþer name, But lestene wyl hys ownë blame; For &yogh;yf þou any ouþer man namest, Y dar weyl seye þou hym dyffamest; hyt ys grete synne to hym and þe To aske or telle þat shulde nat be; hyt ys bakbytyng, and no shryfte; hyt ys a spyce of euyl þryfte. Þou lewed man, y forbede þe weyl, Þogh þe prest aske, bewreye þou no deyl; Bewreyë weyl þyn ownë dede, But none ouþer, y þe forbede. y tolde langer yn myn auys, Loke algate þy preste be wys. Do nat as þe pharysu, Preydë God a&yogh;ens hys pru; He &yogh;ede to þe cherche with a man Þat men calle a publycan,— A publycan ys, yn oure sawe, A synful man, oute of þe lawe; Þys pharysu ys to mene 'byfore,' As forby alle, and fro ouþer shore,— Þys pharysu bygan to prey, And seyd, as a shrewe shulde sey, "Lordë, þanked mote þou be, See French, lines 10111-15. y am nat, as y ouþer se, Coueytous, ne lecherous of flesshe, And nat as he, þys publycan, ys: Euery woke y fastë twys, And &yogh;yue my tyþes of rychë prys." Loke how he made hys auauntement Of þat gode þat God hadde hym sent; &yogh;e, syre, on a wykked wyse, Oþer men for tó despyce; hys owne godenes, coude he nat sey, But algate ouþer, behoueþ behouede. hym wreye. Besydë stode þe pupblycan, publykan. And knew knegh. hym self a wykked man, And durst nat loke to God vpward, But knokked on hys brest ful harde, And seyd with herte ful drefully, "Lorde, þou haue on me mercy!" Þe þublycan had mochë þanke; Þe pharysu, byfore God he stanke. Þus seyþ þe gospel, þat we alle knowe, "who so makeþ hym hygh, he shal be lowe; And, who loghyþ who so logheþ. hym yn skylle, Gode heghnes he shal come tylle." Some, whan þey here shryfte shryfte O, synne H. bygynne, he shal hepe on God hys synne, And seyþ algate, 'he ne may no&yogh;t kepe hym, but synne be wro&yogh;t.' And some sey, whan þey do euyl, Hyt was algate þurgh þe deuyl; And some sey, as y haue herde, 'A! syre! so synneþ alle þe werlde.' Of þy self, shal nat be seyd; On þe, shal alle þe blame be leyd; God blameþ þe for þy mysdede, why seyst þou þan, 'þe behoueþ nede?' hyt behoueþ be nede. Ne no fende may but temptë þe; Þe dede shal alle þyn ownë be; Ne at þe worlde mayst þou no&yogh;t kest; Do þy self weyl, hyt ys þe best; Here mayst þou se wyþ godë skyl, Alle hyt ys at þyn ownë wyl.
1.9: The ny&yogh;nþe poynt of shryfte. þe ny&yogh;nþë seyþ 'hyt ys foly On þy self for to lye.' Sey of þy self no to. trespas, Ne more synne, þan þou done has; Ne forhele nat þy mysdede; Goddes veniaunce shalt þou drede. [The Bible-Tale of Ananias and Sapphira.] Seynt Luke seyþ hys autoryte, Yn þe bygynnyng of crystyanyte, Þe apostoles wente &yogh;ede. aboute to preche— Þe crystyndom for to preche teche. — how men shuld þe worlde forsake, And what mede þarforë take; Ryche men solde here lande and fee, And come to þe apostoles yn pouerte. A ryche man, þat hyghte Ananye, He solde hys godë plenerlye; al plenerlye. þe syluer þat he þarfore tolde, þerof a party he ded withholde;— Hys wyfe cunseyled wel þar-to Þat he shulde nat awey alle do;— Þe touþer partë, alle he lete, And keste hyt at seynt Peter fete. Seynt Petyr parceyued anoun þat þyr was þere þyr was þere O, þer was H. gylë doun: he seyd, "y comaundë þe, Alle þat þyr was, þou shewe hyt me." Ananyas þan swore hym þore, he solde hys þyng, for no more. Seynt Peter, þan seyd seyde þan. astyt, "why lyest þou on þe holy spyryt?" þys Ananyas fyl dowun dede, As, blak, as any lede. [6 syll. ] Men tokë þe body asswyþe, And byryed hyt, þat ychë syþe. hys wyfe come byfore hem alle,— Saphyra, men here calle;— She cunseyled þat hyt was hyd, But she ne wyst what was betyd. Seyn Peter asked here þe soþe ywys, "hast þou no more þan now here ys?" Saphyra answered and seyd, "Y haue no more þan here ys leyd." "þou lyest," he seyde, "þe soþe y se, And nat &yogh;yt al onely to me, But þou lyest vnto þe holy goste, þat alle þyng wote, and my&yogh;t haþ moste." Asswyþë, yn a lytyl stounde, She fyl dowun dede vnto þe grounde. Men byryed sone here body Besyde here husbonde Anany. Here-fore y rede þat þou soþe seye To þy prest, as þou shust deye. Yn þy shryfte, lye þou neuer a deyl; holy wryt forbedeþ hyt weyl. þou seyst hyt nat vnto þe prest, þou shewest hyt vnto Goddys breste; Boþe to God and to man, Þat oure defaute, seeþ alle, and kan. Gode graunte vs þe soþe to sey, And clene be shryuë ar we dey!
1.10: þe tenþe poynt of shryfte. Þe tenþë poynte of shryfte, þys ys: '&YOGH;yf þou shalt haue for&yogh;yuënes, Þy synne naked shalt þou make, And opunly, hyt forsake.' hyle hem nat with feyrë wurde, Þat semeþ to gadyr þy synnes to hurde: yn tyfed tyffede. wurdys þat slyked are, Semeþ þy synnes þat þey no&yogh;t were; yn swyche wurdys, þe fende ys queynte To make þy shryftë fals and feynte. No queyntyse make þou þerynne, But sey ry&yogh;t as þou dedyst dest. þy synne. þou mayst nat þy synnës wryte, Yn shryftë þe so to quyte, &YOGH;yf þou mayste speke, and haste haue. space To fynde a preste yn any place, with mouþe to speke, and nat noght. to hyde, Elles hyt ys a spyce of pryde: Seynt Austyn seyþ, algate þy lyue, 'wyþ mouþe opunly, þou þe shryue.'
1.11: þe eleuenþe poynt of shryfte. þe elleuenþe poynt shul we we shul. knowe, 'To þy prest þou bere þe lowe, Blelyche yn þy. penaunce for to do Alle þat he ioyneþ þe vnto.' Þou shalt make no fals delay, Penaunce to takë at þy pay; Hyt ys sloghnes and feyntés To take penaunce at þy dyuys; For þy synne, þe ry&yogh;t penaunce Shal be þe prestës ordynaunce: Þus seyþ þe clerk, seynt Austyn, "Þe prestes mercy, þou do þe ynne; Þe prest ys crystys vycarye; Do þe alle yn hys mercy." &YOGH;yf þe prest be of any resun, He wote weyl what shal be doun; he wote what penaunce þe falleþ falþ. to haue, And what þy state ys, and what hyt wyl craue. And, þus þou wost weyl at gesse, &YOGH;yf þou were now yn a sykenes, And al. wuldest þou do, for to lyue, Alle þat þy leche wulde þe &yogh;yue; To þy soule, do þe samë wyse, Þy penaunce, as þe prest seyse. Many a&yogh;ens þe prest þey kaste, Þat þey mowe noþer bydde ne faste, But &yogh;yf þey algate penaunce penaunce O, om . H. shul do, Þan þay seye hyt behoueþ be so; No þyng aftyr hys dedys ylle, But algate at hys ownë wylle. wenest þou so to come to heuene, with lyghte penaunce as þou wylt neuene? But y warne þe of þys cas; Þarto ys many a streytë pas. Þe manhede of God wulde no&yogh;t Haue heuene, but hyt were bo&yogh;t. what wenest þou haue hyt for so lytyl here, whan God and man bo&yogh;t hyt so dere? By heuene with þy penaunce, Or, ellës-where, kepe harder chaunce.
1.12: þe twelueþ poynt of shryfte. þe twelueþe poynt of oure resun: 'Alle holy oweþ þy shryfte be doun; No poynt þou shalt with-holde, For, alle holy, hyt oweþ to 'to' omitted. be tolde; And, þat shal y shewë þe On two maners; þy shryfte al hole shall be. &YOGH;yf þou þe shryue by parcelles, Þe holy man seyþ, þy shryfte þou steles; &YOGH;yf þou shewe one, o party, And anoþer prest þou tellest anoþer foly, Þat shryfte ys no&yogh;t, þy soule ys betrayd, And God almy&yogh;ty ys mys-payd; For to echoun þyn herte was stoken, A synne þou heldë þer-ynne loken; þat þou with-helde, was nat for&yogh;yue; Þou shewedest hyt nat, hyt ys vnshryue. Body ne soulë ys payd weyl Tyl þou haue tolde þy synne synne O, soule H. eche deyl; Telle alle þy synnes, and with-holde noun; Or elles, y seye, shryfte ys þyr noun; For, &yogh;yt haþ þe fende pouste For to make sorowe yn þe. lo here, ensample þat ys certeyn, Þat noun no man. may sey þer-a&yogh;eyn; &YOGH;yf þou yn þy body haue woundës wndes. fyue, Þat, þe leste may for-do þy lyue, And hele hem allë but o wunde, &YOGH;yt may þat on, one. brynge þe to to þe H, to O. grounde. [The Tale of how Shrift made a Woman's unconfest Sin fly out of her Mouth as a 'Blak,' a 'Fende of Helle.'] Of a womman y herde onys spelle, A tale þat alle here synnës wulde nat telle; þys wumman hadde do a synful dede; here shamed to telle hyt for drede. On a o. day, grace was here &yogh;yue, þat she þo&yogh;te she wulde be shryue: þys womman come vnto a frere, And, preyd hym, here lyfe to here. As she sat here shryftë ynne, She þo&yogh;te vppon þys ychë synne; Þe frerë cumforted here weyl, Boldely to sey euery deyl; hys cumforte madë here ry&yogh;t bolde, So þat she furþe þe þat. synnë tolde, þat she haddë longe forhole, þurgh cunseyl of þe deuyl stole; But, at þat ychë breyde þat she furþe þe þat. synnë seyde, Come fleyng oute, at of. here mouþe a blak, Ry&yogh;t as she þe wurdë spak: þe frerë sagh hyt apertly, And þanked God of hys mercy. þat ychë blak, y dar wel telle þat hyt was a fende of helle, þat my&yogh;t no lenger yn here reste whan þe synnë oute gan breste; But as longe as she þe synne forhale, Þe deuyl helde ful stylle hys stale; For euer-more he wyl a-byde whyl o synnë may hym hyde; And, for þat yche resun why, Shryue we oure synnë, alle holy; Nat by parcelles, to prestes atwynne; To one, alle holy, shryue þy synne; To o preste telle telle þou. hyt euery deyl, Þan art þou shryuë holy weyl: At oure shryfte, God &yogh;yue vs my&yogh;t Þese poyntes to kunne, and shewe hem ry&yogh;t. Now haue &yogh;e herde þe poyntës twelue, how euery man shal shryue hym selue, And of þese 'þese' omitted. poyntes lerned sum deyl, how &yogh;e mow[ë] shryue &yogh;ow weyl. Prestës oghte hem alle to kunne, lewed men to teche and monne; And but þey techë hem þys lore, Here perel ys weyl þe more.

2.1: Moche ys shryftë for to preyse; Þe dede, to lyue, he may vpreyse; A soulë þat ys dede þurgh synne, Þurgh shryftë comþ gracë þer-ynne. Many godenesse my&yogh;t men telle, How shryfte confoundeþ þe deuyl fende. of helle. Lesteneþ, godë men, to lere, Þe grace of shryftë &yogh;e mow here.
2.2: The fyrste grace þat shryfte &yogh;yueþ. þe fyrst grace þat þy shryfte shal &yogh;yue, he makeþ þy soulë for to lyue. whan þy mouþe with shryfte ys opun, Deþ and synne are boþe oute lopun. Salamon seyþ, þat ys wys, Yn a bokë of Prouerbyys, "Þe weye of lyue, lyffe. with-outyn ende, Oute of ry&yogh;twys mannes mouþe shal wende." Of þe mouþe þat ys vnry&yogh;t, hyd hys ys. synne fro grace and of. ly&yogh;t; Þy mouþë, no gracë cumþ ynne, whan þyn herte ys ded yn synne: Deþ and lyfe, &yogh;e mowe weyl se, To-gedyr mow þey neuer be. neuer mowe þey be. For somë, whan þey come to shryfte, No more wyl þey here herte vp lyfte To God for grace, but beþ harde as stone, So longe haue þey with here synne gone; Sorowe of synnë haue þey no&yogh;t, So ys here soule beneþë bro&yogh;t. For, a lymme þat ys ded or drye Þurgh sykenes, or smete yn pallësye, Þogh men prykkë hyt wyþ oghte, See French, l. 8729 below. For hyt ys dede, hyt feleþ no&yogh;te; No more of grace, þe soule may fonge, Þat haþ ley yn synne so longe; But Ihesu cryst, þat none wyl tyne, he boghte alle mankynde wyþ pyne, And graunteþ hym grace, hys shryfte by|gynne, And yn hys shryfte, to sorowe hys synne. Þurgh swyche sorow, cumþ þe lyfe of grace, Þe deþ of synne awey to chace. Þan ys þys a feyrë &yogh;yfte, Þe lyfe of euer, þurg þy shryfte; Þy soule þat was for synnë lore, Þurgh shryfte haþ grace and lyfe byfore; Þys ys þe grace and þe fyrst vertu, Þat shryfte doþ to þy soulë pru.
2.3: þe þe O, Te H. secunde grace þat shryfte &yogh;yueþ. A-noþer &yogh;yfte he &yogh;yueþ large; hyt aleggeþ þe of heuy charge; For euery synne, as hyt amounteþ, Shalt þou haue, whan deþ acounteþ; But yn yn H, om . O. euery tyme þat þou shryuest þe, Of pyne shalt þou vncharged be; For, þe prest haþ powere To asoyle þe quyte and clere. &yogh;yf þou for synne mayst haue sorowe, Fro heuy pyne hyt wyl þe borowe; Body and soule moche ys a-legged, whan of of þy. synne þou art a-bregged; kyndly, ys þat man heuy Loke what Iope seyþ, þat was of suff|raunce; Þat haþ synned wykkedly. He spekeþ to God for swyche a chaunce, "Lorde," he seyþ, "weyl y hyt se, My synne ys allë á&yogh;ens me; For, whan y þenke on my synne, Ful of angwys y am with-ynne; For heuy byrdon, þat y of hem bere, Y am confounded, my self to were." And y haue oftë herd men seye, And y wote my self þe certeyn wey, Þat, when men haue synned dedly, Here soule ys mornyng and heuy, And cumbred ful of þo&yogh;t and drede, Ne he haþ no wyl to do gode dede; But whan þey haue be clenë shryue And do þe penaunce þat was hem &yogh;yue, Hem þo&yogh;t hem self wundyr ly&yogh;t, And, lesse dremed on þe ny&yogh;t. Yn alle þys worlde [n]ys Neither of the MSS. has a 'no.' so heuy þyng, As yn synne to haue dwellyng; Þe synne God hateþ, þat on hem hangeþ; And Goddës hatred, helle hyt fangeþ; Þan ys wundyr, þat þe erþe hym bereþ, But onely þat Goddys mercy hym wereþ, And wyl [nat] þat he were cumbred or and . shent, But a-bydeth hys amendëment; So ys þe &yogh;yfte of shryftë large, And leseþ men of heuy charge; Y rede we loue hyt, at alle our my&yogh;t, For body and soule, hyt makeþ ly&yogh;t.
2.4: The þred grace þat shryfte &yogh;yueþ. þe þred grace of hys &yogh;euyng ys, as hyt were, anoyntyng: anoytyng H, anoyntyng O. Anoyntyng ys gode for body sore, And shryfte ys a-noyntyng for euermore; For, shryfte ys ys as a. a sacrament, hyt ys a grace, to alle men lent; And, who-so cumþ weyl þar-tyl, Fourë þynges he haþ þurgh skyl;— Þe fyrst þyng þou shalt beleue ynne, To haue for&yogh;yuenes for of. þy synne, &YOGH;yf þat þou truly þe shryue, And weyl holde hyt yn þy lyue. Mekenes ys þe touþer, men telle, And yn godë hope to dwelle, Þat þe shryfte, þat we to go, Alle oure synne may quenche and slo. Þe þred ys, þat he shal fonde To brynge hym oute of þe fendës bonde; For þus hyt seyþ, weyl y wote, yn a boke þat seynt Austyn wrote: 'Yn wey to heuene, may no man be, But he haue wyl, hys bande to fle.' Þe fourþë þyng þat shal be dy&yogh;t, Alle hole þy wyl, to God almy&yogh;t, Hym to wurschepe ouer alle, Þat he wulde to shryfte þe calle, And brynge þe á&yogh;en to hys grace Þat þou lostest with þy wanlace. whan þou art &yogh;olde to be hys seruaunt, Fals hym nat, but holde hym cunnaunt; Hyt ys alle hys, þat þou lyuest by, Serue nat þan hys en[e]my!
2.5: The fourþe grace þat shryfte &yogh;yueþ. Þe fourþë grace ys weyl to telle, how shryfte shendeþ shent. þe fende of helle. &YOGH;y[f] þou wylt make þe deuyl shent, And with-stonde hys tycëment, with no þyng mayst þou do hym so wo As louë ofte to shryftë go; Þan ys he a-shamed to tempte þe, For þat þou bewreyyst hys pryuyte: Þys seyþ Salamon þe kyng, '&YOGH;yf þou shewe þy frende a þyng, And he þat pryuyte bewreye, furþer bewreye. Þe loue betwenë &yogh;ow shal deye.' Sykyr Syker ynogh. þou be, certeynly, Þe fende þe fleþ ful hastyly: whan þou shryuest þe for hys shame, Þat ys shenshepe vnto hys name; Hym shameþ þat he ys ys so. ouercome, For þan ys moche of hys my&yogh;t ys hys myghte moche. ouernome, And euermore he ys þe more coward For to tempte þe aftyrward. Syn þat God haþ swyche grace lent Þurgh oure shryfte to make hym shent, Fonde we þan, and leuë no&yogh;t, Þat he were to shamë bro&yogh;t; Certys we shuld haue gode wyl To shendë hym þat wulde vs spyl. Anouþer cumfort ys wel to mene, þat shent þe fende, and doþe hym tene: &YOGH;yf he ys aboute to temptë þe To any synne, what so hyt be, &YOGH;yf þou with-stonde þe temptacyoun, And parceyuest what he wld haue doun, Þan halt he hym shamly dysceyued, Þat of hys queyntyse þou art parceyued; Ne he shal neuer efte haue haue eft. þat powere, Of þat synne to tempte þe nere; For þy wyþstondyng haþ hym rafte, Of hys temptyng, alle þe crafte. Blessed ys shryfte with God almy&yogh;t, For hyt confoundeþ þe deuyl doun ry&yogh;t; God &yogh;yue vs grace, þe fende to shende, And vn-to shryfte oure wyl alle wende.

2.7: The syxte grace þat shryfte &yogh;yueþ. H. were redy to haue þat blys That for vs vs alle. ordeyned ys; For þurgh þe manhede of Ihesus, Ys here ioye fulfylled yn vs. Þan ys hyt on þe touþer party whan we synnë synnen. dedly; we lese þe ioye þat þey are ynne, For long lyggyng yn oure synne. Y trowe euery man þat had þys þo&yogh;t, wulde ful sone of synne be bro&yogh;t, Þogh hyt were for noun oþer þyng, But for þe aungelys grete longyng; Shryue we vs þan, most and leste, And make þe aungelys a feyre feste. Shryftë ys þe &yogh;ate of heuene, Hyt ys a wey þat ledeþ vs euene; And at þe þat. entre, ys none forsake Þat ys weyl shryue, and haþ penaunce take; And, þo þat vnshryuë be, þere þey getë none entre. Allas, þat oure synne ys so grefe, Þat leseþ lesseþ. þe ioye þat we are lefe! God graunte vs alle swych shryfte to take, Þat we, þe aungeles, ioye mow make!
2.8: The seuenþe grace þat shryfte &yogh;yueþ. Y rede we &yogh;elde hym þe countre paye, And blyndë we hym fro hys praye. we put oute hys y&yogh;e ye. gostly whan we shryue vs opunly; Certes he may nat knowe vs efte, For oure shryfte haþ hym þe sy&yogh;t refte. þat may weyl y-shewed y-shewede O, shewed H. be with By. a tale of an autoryte. I have read many analogous stories in the religious writings of the Middle-Age, but the present one I have not found.—G. Paris, Hist. Litt. xxviii. 205. ] Þyr was onys an ermyte, A tale. Þat was euer yn Gode parfyte; So moche he hadde of Goddys grace, Þat he coude knowe, yn euery place, whych men were yn dedly synne, And who was godë lyfe with-ynne; And also, he my&yogh;t se weyl Þyng þat was spyrytuele. An halyday fyl, as ys þe acyse, Men to go to Goddys seruyse; Þys erymyte lened hym on a walle, And badde hys bedys, and loked ouer-alle, And beheld þe folke þat come yn þe gate, O. gloss 'wey.' whyche come erlye, and whyche late, whyche come with for. gode deuocyoun, And whyche for ouþer enchesoun: Alle sagh þys ermyte euerydeyl, who come wrong, and who come weyl. As he stode, he toke gode hede, How a deuyl, a man gan lede; with hym he com alle weyl þe gate, And ledde hym to þe chyrchë &yogh;ate, And yn to þe cherchë&yogh;erde; Forþer durst he nat, for ferde. And whan he yn-to þe cherch shuld go, Þan brast þe fendës chayn yn two; Þe fende stode stylle, and loked a-boute, And a-bode þys man wyþ-oute; On hys clawys he helde þys cheyne, And loked what tyme he come a&yogh;eyne. þe holy man &yogh;aue godë tent whyder þat ychë man was went. þat ychë man, þat þat O, 'þat' struck thru in H. was yn synne, And haddë longë leye þer-ynne; Þurgh grace óf þe holy spyryt, he &yogh;ede and shrouë hym astyt, And þo&yogh;t neuer to turne a&yogh;eyn, But sorowed þat hé þer-ynne had leyn. whan þat þys man shryuë was, And was passed þat synful pas, As þys man come outë þere, Þe fende loked aboute euery-where, And coude nat fynde hym, for no nede, Among þe ouþer, þere þey &yogh;ede; Þe sy&yogh;të of hym hadde he he O, hym H. lore, Al þogh he &yogh;ede next hym byfore. Long loked þat foulë wyght, And coude nat se hym with no sy&yogh;t; He stode stylle tyl alle men were goun, But sy&yogh;të of hym hadde he noun. Þys holy ermyte to hym &yogh;ede: "Treytur," he seyd, "for what nede Stanst þou here; telle hyt me, Yn Goddys name, y cóniure þe." Þan answered þat glotoun, "y abyde here my prysoun, Þat long haþ be vndyr my myn. hande, And haue led hym aboute with þys bande; Langer wente he yn fro me, He come nat oute &yogh;yt, þat y coude may. se; Among many, y haue hym so&yogh;te; Me þenkeþ þynke. wundyr, y fynde hym no&yogh;te." Þys ermyte hyed fast and ran, And ouertoke þys ychë man, And, preyd hym a stounde to dwelle, And of hys lyfe, sumwhat to telle: "Y graunte," he seyd, "to þe to seye. To þe cherche, as y wente my weye y felte me charged yn a synne,— And, long had y leye þere-ynne,— y þo&yogh;te y wulde me þer-of shryue, And amende þe trespas yn my lyue. At þe cherche, y shroue me weyl, Plenerly of euery deyl; Blessed be now God almy&yogh;t, Me þynkeþ y am wundyrly ly&yogh;t." Þan þo&yogh;te þe Ermyte astyte, þat whan men haue yn synne delyte, Þan haþ þe fendë enchesoun To byndë hym as a presun; And whan he haþ wyl, hym to shryue, Hys bandys brest, and al to-ryue; And, whan he ys clenë shryuyn, Þe deuyl knoweþ hym no more syþen. Þe holy man come þan to þe deuyl, And bad he shulde do no man euyl, But go to helle, þere he come fro, Euer to dwelle yn pyne and wo. Þarfore, y rede þat we bygynne To shryuë vs of alle our synne.

H. prophesye, "whan man haþ fylled hys soule with ylle Þurgh hys ownë wykked wylle, y rede hym þat he oftë synge wurschyp vn-to oure heuene kynge." Þys song to mene, yn my resoun, Ys trewë shryfte, and oftë doun. Þyr ys no þyng þat man may neuene, Þat more stereþ styreþ. God of heuene, Of vs synful to haue mercy, Þan doþ shryfte, þere hyt ys do trewly. who so syngeþ to God with shryfte, For hys song he &yogh;yueþ hym a &yogh;yfte; Hys &yogh;yfte ys ioye with-outyn wo, Þat þe fendë was kast fro.

For, God forbede þat hym þat. tre, Þat he ne shulde ete þer-of, ne she: Seeþ how he ded, þat God forbede, And dyd aftyr hys wyuës rede; He wulde haue excused hys fame, As who seyþ 'God was to blame;' Þese lewed men sey, and erre ful ylle, And seye 'hyt was alle Goddys wylle.' &YOGH;yf þat hyt Goddys wyl shulde be, why forbede he hym þat tre? 3.4: That þou make nat þy synne lytyl to 'to' omitted. seme. Ry&yogh;t so fareþ forholen synne, As fyre, borë bosum ynne; At þe lastë, hyt hym dereþ, And brennyþ brēnþ. þat hym aboutë bereþ; For no synne may be hyd, Þat hyt ne behoueþ opunly be kyd; &YOGH;yf hyt be shewed here apert, Yn ouþer stede hyt ys couert; And &yogh;yf þou hydë here þy blame, hyt shal be shewed to þy shame. Seynt Austyn seyþ a wurde to charge, Of Goddys &yogh;yfte, how hyt ys large: "Shryueþ &yogh;oure dedës and &yogh;oure þo&yogh;t, For God for&yogh;yueþ alle or no&yogh;t; Oþer for&yogh;yueþ he alle with gladehede, Or alle abydeþ to hys wraþhede. &YOGH;yf þou be allë fully shryue, Forsoþe þan be þey all for&yogh;yue; &YOGH;yf þou þe shryue of alle but one, Noþer he for&yogh;yueþ þat, ne none." Yn ry&yogh;t resun þese clerkys telle, yn þat stede þere God shal dwelle Plenerly, hyt behoueþ be clene, Þat no synnë mowe be sene. whan synne ys shryue, and clene eche deyl Þere wyl God, holde hys hostele; Þe mantel of loue ys leyd ful euene, Þat heleþ Ihesu and kyng of heuene. Yn o stede ne mowe þey reste; God or þe fendë, outë þe toon oute O. keste; One of þese, behoueþ þe chese; Take þe toon, þe touþer þou lese. Y wulde holde hym more þan wode, Þat cheseþ þe wykked, and leueþ þe gode. Take we God on oure party, And fle we þe fendës cumpany.
3.5: That þou make no skornyng yn shryfte. Skorne nat, and seye þou wylt forsake Þy synne, and eft a&yogh;en hyt take. &YOGH;yt wyl y warne þe of o þyng, Yn shryftë make þou no skornyng. Lytyl mayst þou spede þat whyle, &YOGH;yf þou shryuë þe with gyle; For &yogh;yf þou make þy shryftë feynt, Sykyr þou be, þou shalt be a-teynt, whan [þat] þou art nat yn wyl Þe to wyþdrawë fro þyn yl. what doust þou byfore þe prest, And, hast déseyt yn þy brest? Asoyled mayst þou neuer be, But þou wylt þy synnë fle. with skornë wenest þou þe quyte As a fals ypocryte, Þat þou holdest nat cunnaunt, þat þou hetest and takest an hand. "Yn pryde, yn Ire, yn enuye, yn slouþë, slouþe O, slogh H. and yn coueytyse, yn glotonye, and yn lecherye, Y delyte me yn euery vyleynye; Foule flessh dedes þat are ouer rank, More þan ouþer y take to þank; But, pryde algate, and coueytyse, Y may nat leue, ne none of þyse; Ten þousend men dampned be Yn þese two, for loue of me; when y fynde hem custummably Yn þese two synnës alle redy, Ful weyl payeþ me þat synne, And bounde are þey to me þer-ynne; Þan do þey, ry&yogh;t as y wyl, Allë wrong wyþ-outë skylle; Fro wykked to wers, y do hem falle, For y am mayster ouer hem alle; &YOGH;yf þey wulde wake, y do hem slepe, And yn ydulnes to lepe; For whan þey are yn beddë bedde O, bed H. bro&yogh;t, y do hem synne yn ydul þo&yogh;t; yn þo&yogh;t of folye, and foule delyte, "I do hem þenkë þan ful tyte. "Certes y may nat telle hyt alle, þe synne þat y haue do, and more shal. Cryst, loue y neuer a deyl, Ne none þat on hym byleueþ weyl, For, yn euery dedly synne y am bounde, and may nat blynne. Y wyst my self hydus and blak, And no þyng haþ so mochë lak; Þurgh my shryfte, y wende to spede, To haue turned so bry&yogh;t as ouþer &yogh;ede." "Þou art dyceyued, foule treytoure!
